Practically, Calvin urges believers to cultivate humility in the face of societal upheaval, recognizing that their security lies not in political or economic systems but in Christ's promise of redemption. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ's ultimate victory: Babylon's destruction prefigures the final judgment where Christ will dismantle all systems of sin and oppression, establishing a new creation free from corruption. For modern readers, this commentary calls for vigilance against worldly powers that exploit injustice, while affirming that true hope rests in Christ's reconciling work—where the "desolate houses" of Babylon become the dwelling place of God's people in the new heavens and earth. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 13 presents a profound theological vision of divine judgment against Babylon, interpreted as a symbolic representation of human empire and sin. Poole emphasizes that the "burden" of this prophecy reveals God's sovereign authority over nations, where Babylon's destruction by the Medes and Persians serves as a stark warning of God's righteous wrath against systemic idolatry and cruelty. Theodologically, Poole connects the "armies" mobilized by God—specifically the Medes and Persians—as instruments of His judgment, highlighting that true power flows from divine calling, not human ambition. This prophecy finds Christ-centered significance: the "weapons of his indignation" (Isaiah 13:5) point to Christ's ultimate authority and righteous wrath against sin, while the cosmic signs (darkened sun, moon) symbolize the disruption of earthly order in Christ's return. Practically, this commentary urges believers to reject spiritual and moral corruption, recognizing that God's judgment is both a warning against idolatry and a promise of restoration for the righteous. It calls for humility before God's sovereignty, active resistance to sin, and hope in Christ's final victory—where Babylon's desolation becomes a foreshadowing of the end times and the triumph of God's kingdom over all human empires. The passage thus remains a timeless call to live righteously while trusting Christ's ultimate redemption. (278 words)

Barnes interprets Isaiah 13 as a pivotal prophecy of Babylon's destruction, delivered over 170 years before its fulfillment to comfort exiled Jews by foretelling their ultimate deliverance through that city's ruin. Theologically, this passage reveals God's sovereign foreknowledge and power—Babylon, then a colossal, impenetrable metropolis with unprecedented fortifications, was deemed utterly impossible to destroy by human observation, making the prophecy a clear divine revelation rather than human conjecture. Barnes emphasizes that Isaiah's vision presupposed the Jews' future captivity, then pointed beyond it to their redemption through Babylon's complete annihilation, underscoring God's faithfulness to His people despite their temporary displacement. This prophecy's significance extends to Christ connections: Babylon symbolizes any oppressive, worldly power that opposes God's kingdom, and its ultimate overthrow foreshadows Christ's final victory over all systems of sin and rebellion, where the "wild beasts" of the earth (Isaiah 13:21-22) find their place in the new creation. Practically, this commentary encourages believers to trust God's promises even amid present suffering, recognizing that temporary exile or oppression is temporary under Christ's reign. It teaches that true security comes not from human strength or political systems but from God's sovereign plan—just as Babylon's destruction was the necessary step for Israel's restoration, Christ's triumph over spiritual forces ensures our ultimate deliverance. For modern readers, this historical context reminds us that even the most seemingly invincible systems will be consumed by divine justice, urging reliance on Christ's victory rather than worldly power. (248 words)

Henry notes that Isaiah 14 serves as a profound prophetic critique of Babylonian pride, revealing God's sovereign judgment on worldly power while emphasizing divine mercy for the redeemed. The chapter's central theological insight lies in its contrast between the fleeting glory of earthly rulers—like Babylon's king who sought to "ascend above the stars" (14:13–14)—and the eternal destiny of the truly exalted, who is Christ. Henry stresses that the king's hubris, mirroring Lucifer's rebellion, leads inevitably to destruction: "the pomp is brought down to the grave" (14:11), a vivid metaphor for how sin and pride result in spiritual death. This passage underscores a core truth: true honor belongs only to God, who "has purposed" to dismantle oppression and restore righteousness (14:27). Practically, Henry urges believers to reject worldly ambition and the false pursuit of power, recognizing that lasting security comes solely from Christ, not human achievements. The "besom of destruction" (14:23) symbolizes God's final judgment on unrepentant sin, yet His mercy remains active for those who turn to Him. Crucially, this text points forward to Christ—whose victory over sin and death fulfills the prophecy of the "true king" (14:12) who "ascends above the heavens" (John 14:28), yet remains subject to God's will. Believers today must heed this warning: oppose pride and rebellion, embrace humility, and find refuge in Christ's atoning work, knowing His triumph ensures that "the seed of evildoers shall never be renowned" (14:20), while His people inherit God's promised rest (14:4). This vision calls for both sober reflection on sin and confident hope in Christ's eternal kingdom.

Calvin meticulously interprets Isaiah 14:1-20 as a profound prophetic condemnation of Babylonian pride, yet his commentary reveals deeper theological significance beyond the immediate historical context. He emphasizes that the passage's "Lucifer" figure—described as the "son of the morning" who "ascends to heaven" (verse 13)—is not a literal king but a powerful metaphor for the fallen enemy of God, ultimately identifying this figure with Satan's rebellion against divine sovereignty. Calvin stresses that God's sovereignty is absolute: the passage declares Babylon's destruction as divine purpose (verses 24-27), showing how God's judgments refine His people and secure His ultimate victory. Crucially, Calvin connects this text to Christ by highlighting the contrast between the self-aggrandizing "Lucifer" and Christ's humility. Just as the fallen star is cast to earth (verse 15), Christ, though exalted by God, humbled himself to become a servant (Philippians 2:5-8), fulfilling the promise of redemption. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject pride and idolatry, recognizing that all human power—like Babylon—will ultimately yield to God's will. This passage teaches that true security comes not from worldly empires but in Christ, who "makes the earth tremble" (verse 17) through His atoning work. For modern readers, it calls for humility before God's authority, vigilance against spiritual arrogance, and trust in Christ's final triumph over sin and death, ensuring the "poor" and "needy" find refuge in His kingdom rather than in transient earthly powers. (278 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 14 reveals a dual prophetic vision: the immediate deliverance of Israel from Babylonian captivity and the ultimate triumph of God's kingdom over all human pride. The text depicts God's merciful intervention, where He chooses Israel after their exile, destroys Babylon's oppressive power, and establishes Cyrus as the deliverer who enables their return—foreshadowing how God's chosen people would later be restored through divine agency. Poole emphasizes that the "Lucifer" figure (the king of Babylon) represents human arrogance, specifically his boastful claim to "ascend into heaven" and sit above God's stars, illustrating how earthly rulers, like Babylon's king, often project divine authority and ignore God's sovereignty. Theologically, this highlights the universal consequence of pride: the fallen king is reduced to the grave, his glory destroyed by the very forces he oppressed. Practically, this serves as a profound warning against spiritual self-sufficiency, urging humility before God and repentance from actions that elevate oneself above divine order. Crucially, Poole connects this passage to Christ, noting that the "strangers joined with Israel" becomes the Gentiles incorporated into God's people through Christ, while the "rest from sorrow" and "breaking of the wicked's staff" point to Christ's victory over sin and death. The prophecy thus culminates in Christ's reign—a kingdom where the humble are exalted and the proud are brought low, offering believers liberation from spiritual bondage and the promise of eternal restoration through faith in Him. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 14 presents this chapter as a triumphant poetic prophecy of Jewish deliverance from Babylonian captivity, framed as a vivid lament and celebration for the fallen empire. Barnes meticulously outlines the poem's six distinct movements: initial Jewish jubilation over Babylon's destruction, the dead monarchs' scornful rise to mock the fallen king, the king's boastful ambition to "ascend to heaven" and equal God, the taunting witnesses who see him reduced to shame, God's definitive decree of Babylon's ruin, and an Assyrian confirmation of divine power. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes that the "star" (Babylon) symbolizes any arrogant power that seeks divine equality, directly foreshadowing Christ's own exaltation and ultimate descent into humiliation—where the "fallen star" becomes the sinless Lamb who conquers sin and death. This chapter reveals God's sovereign purpose: He preserves His chosen people through judgment on pride, ensuring their restoration and the conversion of captives. Practically, it challenges believers to reject worldly ambition and self-deception, recognizing that true authority flows from Christ alone. For modern readers, this prophecy serves as a profound reminder that God's deliverance from spiritual bondage—through Christ's atoning work—overcomes even the most towering human pride, urging humility and trust in divine redemption rather than seeking power or status. The poem's enduring power lies in its assurance that God's purposes for His people, even in profound darkness, remain certain and victorious.

Henry observes that Isaiah's prophecy against Moab (15:1-9) presents a vivid picture of divine judgment unfolding rapidly, emphasizing God's sovereignty over nations and the consequences of unrepentant sin. The passage reveals Moab's imminent destruction—its cities laid waste, idols abandoned, and entire communities consumed by lamentation and desolation—highlighting a key theological truth: God's justice is swift and decisive against persistent wickedness, yet it also exposes human frailty. Crucially, Henry connects this judgment to Christ's fulfillment, noting that Isaiah's warnings about nations falling into ruin point toward Christ's ultimate triumph over sin and death, where the "fugitives" of Moab find refuge only in redemption, not worldly security. Practically, this commentary urges believers to reflect on their own reliance on God rather than temporal wealth or military strength, as seen in the desolation of Moab's "abundance" being carried away by famine and blood. It also calls for compassionate engagement with enemies, challenging Christians to mourn with those in distress—whether nations or individuals—rather than withdrawing into isolation. The lamentations of Moab foreshadow the need for genuine repentance, where the "weeping" of the righteous (like Christ's suffering) becomes the path to restoration, contrasting sharply with Moab's futile attempts to escape divine wrath through idols. This passage thus serves as both a warning against spiritual complacency and a profound reminder of Christ's redemptive work that transforms despair into hope. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 15 reveals a profound theological warning against complacency and spiritual blindness. Calvin interprets the prophecy against Moab as a stark illustration of God's sovereign judgment falling unexpectedly upon those who trust in their own security and worldly defenses, particularly nations hostile to the covenant community. He emphasizes that the "sudden destruction in the night" (Isaiah 15:1) symbolizes the abrupt and terrifying reality that the wicked, who believe themselves fortified by their status or idols, face divine retribution they cannot prepare for. The imagery of "baldness" and "beards cut off" signifies total spiritual desolation, while the "blood in Dimon" (v. 9) points to the violent, irreversible consequences of unrepentant rebellion. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ's work: Moab's destruction foreshadows God's final judgment on sin and the wickedness of the world, yet simultaneously underscores Christ as the only true refuge. For believers, Calvin stresses that the prophecy serves a vital practical purpose—reminding Christians to avoid the false security of their own strength or idols, recognizing that true safety comes solely through Christ. It warns against attributing calamities to chance rather than acknowledging God's providence, urging humility and dependence on the Gospel rather than worldly alliances or self-reliance. In this way, Isaiah 15 becomes a timeless call to flee spiritual desolation through Christ, whose blood cleanses from sin and whose judgment protects the faithful.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 15 presents a vivid prophecy of Moab's sudden, total destruction, emphasizing God's sovereign judgment upon unrepentant enemies. Poole interprets the "burden" as a warning that Moab, a long-standing adversary of Israel, will face catastrophic ruin—cities like Ar and Kir laid waste overnight, symbolizing the abruptness of divine wrath that catches even the secure in sleep. The imagery of mourning—shaving heads, wearing sackcloth, and howling in streets—highlights the depth of devastation, where even the "armed soldiers" cry for relief from impending doom. Theologically, this passage reveals God's justice: Moab's destruction is not arbitrary but a consequence of their persistent rebellion and idolatry, demonstrating that God's judgment is both precise and universally applied, targeting those who refuse His peace. Crucially, Poole connects this prophecy to Christ, noting that while Moab's fate foreshadows judgment on sin, it ultimately points to Christ's victory over all enemies. The blood in Dimon (Isaiah 15:9) symbolizes the finality of God's wrath against unrepentant sin, yet this judgment finds its ultimate resolution in Christ's atoning death and resurrection. Practically, this commentary urges believers to recognize the immediacy of God's warnings in their lives, to avoid the pride of Moab (rebelliousness against God), and to cultivate genuine repentance and humility before divine judgment. It calls Christians to trust Christ's victory over sin and death rather than fear the consequences of rebellion, understanding that true peace comes only through Christ's redemption. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 15 reveals this chapter as a cohesive prophecy from Isaiah himself, rejecting earlier theories that it was composed by another prophet or later incorporated. Barnes emphasizes the historical context of Moab's long-standing enmity with Israel—rooted in Balaam's sin, territorial disputes, and cycles of tribute and rebellion—positioning Moab as a type of ungodly nation that opposes God's people. Theorically, this prophecy illustrates God's sovereign judgment on nations that reject His covenant, particularly those who exploit or oppress Israel, while simultaneously pointing to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of judgment and restoration. Moab's destruction in the prophecy prefigures the final judgment on all ungodly kingdoms, yet the deeper promise lies in Christ's role as the true "Israel" who overcomes sin and establishes God's kingdom. Practically, this commentary encourages believers to reject ethnic prejudice and hatred, recognizing that God's justice extends to all nations, while also fostering humility in understanding that true restoration comes through Christ, not human alliances. It challenges Christians to avoid the Moabite pattern of self-serving alliances and to pursue reconciliation with enemies, knowing that Christ's triumph over sin and death ultimately transforms broken relationships into unity within the new covenant. This passage thus serves as a timeless reminder that God's judgment is just and His restoration is available through Christ alone. (248 words)

Henry observes that Isaiah 16's narrative of Moab's impending judgment serves as a profound theological warning and Christ-centered illustration. The chapter depicts Moab's pride and rebellion leading to desolation—fields laid waste, vineyards destroyed, and a people reduced to lamentation—yet Henry emphasizes that this desolation reveals deeper truth: the "throne of Hezekiah" (v. 5) symbolizes Christ's eternal kingdom, where true rulership brings divine justice and lasting peace, not worldly power. Moab's fate mirrors sinners who reject God's guidance, becoming like "wandering birds" vulnerable to destruction (v. 2), while those who submit to Christ become "the Lamb" (v. 1), offering themselves as living sacrifices. Theologically, this underscores that God's judgment on sinners is inseparable from the path to salvation through Christ—those who cling to pride and self-reliance face ruin, but submission to Christ's sacrificial death secures eternal life. Practically, Henry urges believers to actively resist pride by showing mercy to the oppressed, embracing humility in the face of worldly chaos, and trusting Christ's kingdom rather than temporary gains. The chapter's call to "send the lamb" (v. 1) challenges modern Christians to present themselves wholly to Christ, recognizing that true security comes not from earthly status but from the Lamb's atoning work. This framework reveals that Christ's coming resolves the tension between divine justice and mercy—his kingdom brings "peace of conscience and eternal life" even amid present suffering, urging believers to live with holy trembling in trials while fixating on Christ's enduring reign. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 16 emphasizes the prophetic condemnation of Moab's persistent unrepentance and the futility of late remorse. He interprets the instruction "Send ye the lamb" as ironic, targeting Moabites who had long rejected God's warnings and now sought futile relief after their inevitable judgment. Theologically, Calvin stresses that this passage reveals God's sovereignty in judgment—Moab's destruction is inevitable for their obstinacy, yet God's mercy remains active through the promise that "the throne shall be established" in the Davidic line, pointing to Christ as the true fulfillment of justice and redemption. Calvin explicitly dismisses the common Christian interpretation linking the "lamb" to Christ (based on Ruth's Moabite ancestry), deeming it implausible and inconsistent with the passage's context of immediate judgment. Instead, he focuses on the universal truth that God's grace is available only to those who repent in timely obedience, not those who delay until punishment strikes. Practically, this commentary urges believers to avoid procrastinating repentance when confronted with spiritual or moral failure, recognizing that God's patience has limits. It also cautions against misinterpreting divine warnings as mere threats to the unrepentent, while affirming that true righteousness involves actively seeking God's judgment and mercy through Christ, who alone offers the only true "throne of righteousness" for the redeemed. Calvin's insight remains vital: genuine transformation requires prompt response to God's call, not the false hope of last-minute salvation after destruction has begun. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 16 presents a compelling dual narrative where the prophet addresses Moab with urgent counsel while simultaneously foreshadowing divine judgment. He interprets the call for Moab to "send the lamb" as a profound invitation to either rectify political injustice by paying tribute to Judah (the rightful Davidic heir) or to pursue genuine piety through sacrificial devotion to the universal God who rules all lands. Theologically, Poole emphasizes that this passage reveals God's mercy actively working *through* human failure—Moab's current pride and rejection of God's guidance (described as "extortioner at an end") contrast sharply with the promise of a restored, stable Davidic kingdom where justice and righteousness will flourish. Crucially, Poole connects this to Christ: the "throne in truth" established in the Davidic tabernacle prefigures Christ's eternal reign, where divine mercy triumphs over human pride and injustice. Practically, this commentary urges believers to actively shelter the outcast (as Moab was called to do), recognizing that true justice requires both political accountability—honoring God's covenantal order—and radical compassion for the marginalized. In modern contexts, it challenges communities to move beyond superficial charity, actively dismantling systems that exploit the vulnerable while trusting God's promise that the "extortioner" (oppression) will cease and His kingdom of righteousness will prevail through Christ's faithful rule. This dual focus on covenantal responsibility and divine mercy remains vital for navigating today's social fractures. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 16 reveals this chapter as a prophetic warning to Moab, urging their submission to Judah through tribute payment while threatening divine judgment for refusal. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes that the "lamb" (כּר) signifies not a sacrificial animal but a substantial tribute of livestock—historically attested in Moabite customs—symbolizing humble acknowledgment of Judah's rightful authority as God's chosen kingdom. This context highlights a critical tension: Moab's pride (Isaiah 16:6) would lead to their downfall, illustrating God's consistent pattern of punishing rebellion against His established order. Barnes connects this passage to Christ by noting the Chaldee rendering's reference to "the Messiah, the anointed of Israel," positioning the future Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of this tributary relationship—where true submission to God's kingdom, not political power, becomes the foundation for salvation. Practically, this commentary challenges modern believers to avoid Moab's prideful resistance to divine authority. It calls for active, humble participation in God's redemptive community—acknowledging Christ's lordship through service and sacrifice—rather than self-reliance or political defiance. In a world of competing powers, the lesson is clear: genuine faith requires recognizing Christ as the true ruler and offering one's life as living tribute to His kingdom, thereby preventing spiritual and societal collapse through obedience. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 17 presents a profound vision of divine judgment intersecting with divine mercy. He interprets the chapter as depicting the destruction of Damascus and the northern kingdom of Israel, emphasizing that God's wrath targets nations and sinners who have abandoned Him, yet simultaneously preserves a holy remnant who turn to the Lord. Theologically, Henry highlights that God's judgment exposes the futility of human pride and idolatry—describing how the "pleasant plants" and "strange slips" of idolatrous worship inevitably wither, while the "gleaning grapes" symbolize Christ's mercy for the few who remain faithful. Crucially, this prophecy points to Christ as the fulfillment: the "remnant of Syria" becomes the Church, the "glory of Jacob" transforms into the redeemed community, and the "Holy One of Israel" is the living Christ who alone offers salvation. Practically, Henry urges believers to examine their hearts, recognizing that God's discipline often separates us from sin and idols, and to cultivate reliance on Christ rather than human strength or false idols. The chapter's stark contrast—where enemies face swift destruction while the faithful experience enduring blessing—challenges us to trust God's sovereignty in trials and avoid the fatal mistake of forgetting "the rock of salvation." In Christ, this divine judgment becomes a call to humility, as the true remnant finds security not in political power but in the Lord who "shakes the olive tree" to bring forth a few precious fruits for His glory.

John Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 17 emphasizes the prophecy's context as a divine response to the temporary alliance between Israel and Syria against Judah, intended to reassure God's people facing oppression. Calvin interprets the destruction of Damascus as a direct consequence of Syria's idolatrous alliance with Israel, highlighting God's sovereign justice in punishing nations that exploit the vulnerable for their own gain. Theologically, Calvin underscores that this prophecy reveals God's unwavering faithfulness to His covenant people—Judah—by demonstrating that even when external threats seem overwhelming, divine protection remains. The imagery of cities becoming pasturelands and the "forsaken bough" illustrates the temporary nature of worldly power, contrasting sharply with the eternal security of the faithful who turn to God rather than idols. Practically, Calvin urges believers to avoid the same idolatrous tendencies described—relying on human alliances or temporary solutions—by cultivating genuine dependence on God's promises. This involves actively rejecting false security and recognizing that true strength comes from the "Rock of salvation." Christologically, Calvin connects this passage to Christ's ultimate triumph over sin and death. Just as Isaiah prophesied the destruction of Syria's kingdom to secure Judah's future, Christ's victory over the forces of evil ensures the restoration of God's people. The "gleaning grapes" imagery points to Christ's ministry of grace, where even the smallest remnants of divine provision are sufficient for those who trust Him. Thus, believers today are called to anchor their hope in Christ, whose victory guarantees that the "harvest" of God's kingdom will endure beyond temporary human conflicts and idolatrous systems. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 17 reveals a profound theological tension between divine judgment and merciful restoration. Poole interprets the chapter as a vivid prophecy of Assyrian destruction—specifically targeting Damascus, Syria, and Israel's northern tribes—fulfilled historically by Tiglath-pileser's conquest, yet framed within a broader spiritual narrative. The passage depicts the complete ruin of these nations while simultaneously highlighting a small remnant of faithful Israel who will turn to God in genuine repentance. Theologically, Poole emphasizes God's sovereignty in using external judgment to expose idolatry and unfaithfulness, contrasting the temporary glory of human kingdoms with the eternal covenant faithfulness of the Lord. This contrasts sharply with the remnant's response: their afflictions become the catalyst for deep spiritual awakening, where they cease relying on false idols or human efforts and instead turn to the "Holy One of Israel." Practically, this calls believers to examine their own reliance on temporal security or self-sufficiency, especially during crises—acknowledging that true strength comes from God alone. Crucially, Poole's commentary points toward Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of this prophecy. The "glory of Jacob" diminished in the chapter becomes the promise of Christ's coming restoration, where the scattered tribes are reconciled to God through His sacrifice. This historical judgment narrative thus underscores that Christ's work resolves the tension between divine judgment and mercy, offering a path to redemption that transcends human failure and secures eternal hope for the faithful remnant. (280 words)

Barnes' commentary on Isaiah 17 emphasizes the prophecy's dual focus on Damascus and Ephraim (Samaria) as allies threatening Judah, delivered during a period of alliance between these kingdoms against Judah under King Ahaz. Theologically, Barnes highlights how this passage reveals God's sovereign judgment on political alliances that oppose His people, particularly the inevitable destruction of Damascus by Assyrian forces (Tiglath-pileser) as a direct consequence of its alliance with Ephraim. This serves as a critical warning against forming temporary alliances that prioritize human power over divine covenant loyalty. Practically, the text instructs believers to carefully discern partnerships that might lead to spiritual or national harm, urging vigilance against political coalitions that undermine God's purposes—especially in contexts where nations or groups form temporary alliances without spiritual accountability. Barnes further connects this prophecy to Christ by noting that the Assyrian destruction of Damascus (a symbol of oppressive power) prefigures Christ's ultimate triumph over all human enemies and the final judgment on worldly powers, where the "ruinous heap" of Damascus becomes a type of the future destruction of all opposing kingdoms under Christ's rule. This Christ-centered perspective transforms the prophecy from historical warning into a timeless promise: God's people are secure when they align with His kingdom, knowing that true alliances will ultimately yield to His sovereign justice and redemption. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 18 emphasizes God's sovereign providence amid human suffering, presenting a chapter often misunderstood yet profoundly relevant. Henry interprets the "scattered and peeled" nation described as one oppressed and vulnerable, whose land is "spoiled" by rivers—symbolizing how God's judgment targets oppressors while protecting his people. The passage reveals God's active care: he "takes his rest" and ensures his people (Zion) receive divine comfort and restoration, contrasting sharply with the temporary trampling of the wicked. Theologically, Henry stresses that God's actions, though seemingly allowing wickedness to prevail, are purposeful and ultimately protective for his chosen community. This foreshadows Christ as the true "rest" for the weary (Isaiah 18:4), where divine judgment clears the way for the church's ultimate vindication. Practically, believers must avoid despair when persecution occurs, recognizing God's sovereign timing and purpose in current trials. Henry urges vigilance in observing God's providential movements—whether through natural signs or spiritual guidance—and active participation in bringing spiritual sacrifices that align with God's will. Crucially, the chapter reassures that God's people are never abandoned; their suffering is temporary, and their ultimate restoration—through Christ—ensures that "the present" (the hope of redemption) will be brought to Zion. This perspective encourages faithful perseverance, understanding that God's judgments refine and ultimately liberate his people, preparing the way for the full reign of Christ. (248 words)

Calvin meticulously examines Isaiah 18, interpreting the "land shadowing with wings beyond Ethiopia" as a sea-coast nation near Egypt, distinct from the Egyptians themselves, likely engaged in deceptive alliances against Israel. Theologically, Calvin emphasizes God's sovereign judgment over nations that form false alliances or seek to harm Israel, portraying this people as "scattered and peeled" (plundered) and their land "spoiled by rivers," symbolizing total devastation. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ's future reign: the "present" (victory and restoration) brought to Zion is fulfilled not in human alliances but in Christ's return, where God's faithful people find true safety. The passage's irony lies in the "swift messengers" being a rebuke to Israel for relying on doomed human alliances rather than God. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject worldly political schemes and false promises, recognizing that true security comes solely from God's promises. This commentary underscores that Christ is the ultimate "present" for a scattered people—his coming brings restoration where human efforts fail, teaching disciples to trust divine sovereignty rather than temporary alliances, and to find their true home in Christ's kingdom, not in the transient power of nations. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 18 emphasizes the prophetic tension surrounding the identity of "Ethiopia" or "Egypt" as a land beyond the Nile rivers, interpreting the text as a divine warning against nations that form temporary alliances to evade God's judgment. Poole carefully argues that the "vessels of bulrushes" symbolize the fragile, unstable nature of such alliances—nations using cheap, swift boats (common in Nile regions) to send messengers seeking refuge from impending calamity. Theologically, this reveals God's sovereignty over all nations: He exposes human attempts to avoid judgment through political maneuvering while simultaneously revealing that true security lies only in His kingdom. Poole underscores that Isaiah's "woe" targets those who falsely claim divine protection through worldly power, contrasting this with Christ's ultimate role as the unifying force who transcends national divisions. Practically, Christians are urged to reject superficial alliances with sinners and instead prioritize unity with God, recognizing that true peace arises from Christ's reconciling work, not human political strategies. The commentary's Christ connection is profound—Isaiah's vision of global judgment finds its resolution in Christ's universal kingdom, where the "land beyond the rivers" becomes the Church, no longer defined by geography but by the Spirit's work. Thus, believers must actively participate in God's restoration, avoiding the pitfalls of temporary alliances while embracing the transformative power of Christ's atoning love. (248 words)

Barnes notes that Isaiah 18 presents one of the Bible's most enigmatic passages, widely debated by interpreters from antiquity to the present due to its highly figurative language and ambiguous historical context. The chapter addresses a "land shadowing with wings" beyond Ethiopia, likely referring to a powerful neighboring nation (such as Egypt or Nubia) that sends messengers to warn of impending divine judgment against a formidable enemy—most plausibly Assyria, as the prophecy aligns with the Assyrian threat during Hezekiah's reign. Theologically, this passage reveals God's sovereign authority over nations and His purpose to dismantle oppressive powers, emphasizing that His justice extends beyond Israel to all humanity. Crucially, Barnes highlights that the prophecy's promise of a "scattered and peeled" nation (possibly Ethiopia) receiving tribute from the defeated enemy points to God's redemptive plan where the oppressed find hope in His deliverance. This foreshadows Christ's ultimate triumph over sin and death—the "enemy" here symbolizing all evil systems is finally overcome through Jesus, whose coming fulfills Isaiah's vision of God's judgment on oppression and restoration for the broken. Practically, believers today are called to trust God's sovereignty amid global instability, recognizing that His judgments protect the vulnerable and His promises of restoration are already at work. This chapter encourages faithful hope: just as God's judgment on Assyria preceded the Messiah's coming, Christ's victory assures us that all opposing forces will be subdued, urging us to live with confidence in His ultimate renewal of creation and reconciliation. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah chapter 19 reveals God's sovereign judgment on Egypt's idolatry and political corruption, followed by a profound promise of redemption through Christ. The prophecy describes Egypt's internal chaos—wars among its people, spiritual desolation, and the drying up of its resources—as divine consequences for rejecting God's authority. Henry emphasizes that this judgment exposes the futility of human wisdom and the devastating effects of idolatry, where even Egypt's famed sciences and rulers become instruments of self-destruction. Crucially, the "in that day" restoration depicts a radical transformation: Egyptians speaking Hebrew, building an altar to the Lord, and acknowledging Christ as their true savior and healer. This vision connects directly to Christ's role as the ultimate fulfillment—where the "cruel lord" becomes Christ himself, who both judges sin and offers restoration through his sacrifice. Theologically, Henry underscores that God's purpose is not mere destruction but a new covenant where nations unite in worship under Christ, breaking barriers of division. Practically, this commentary urges believers to examine their own idolatry, recognizing that spiritual desolation often stems from unconfessed sin or false security. It calls for active participation in Christ's healing work—receiving his grace to transform relationships and communities, just as Egypt's transformation signifies the Gentiles' inclusion in God's redemptive plan. For modern readers, Henry's insight remains vital: true hope lies not in human power but in Christ's promise to restore wholeness, urging faithfulness in a world often consumed by conflict and spiritual drought. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 19 as a profound divine judgment on Egypt, revealing its spiritual decay and false security that had led the Jews to rely on human power rather than God. He emphasizes that Egypt's impending destruction—where idols crumble, rivers dry, and the nation's spirit fails—serves as a direct consequence of idolatry and the refusal to seek the true God. This vision, Calvin argues, exposes how Egypt's prosperity had become a deceptive refuge, causing the Israelites to despise God's promises. Theologically, Calvin highlights that God's judgment is not arbitrary but purposeful: it purges Egypt of its self-reliance to make way for genuine worship, where the nation ultimately acknowledges Christ as the true Savior. Practically, this commentary urges believers to reject false idols—whether cultural systems, material wealth, or political alliances—that promise safety but lead to spiritual death. Christians today must recognize that true security comes only through Christ, whose coming as the "cruel lord" (v.4) delivers from oppression and restores relationship with God. The passage's Christ connection is explicit: the altar in Egypt (v.19) symbolizes Christ's atoning work, where the nation's cry for help leads to his intervention. Calvin stresses that this vision foretells a future where Egypt, transformed by God's sovereignty, becomes a place of worship—mirroring how Christ's cross and resurrection reconcile all nations to God, demonstrating that true restoration flows from divine grace, not human effort.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 19 presents a vivid portrait of divine judgment upon Egypt, emphasizing God's sovereign authority over nations and the spiritual consequences of idolatry. Poole interprets the "burden of Egypt" as a sudden, overwhelming intervention where the Lord arrives "upon a swift cloud," signaling rapid, unavoidable judgment that shatters Egypt's false confidence in its gods and rulers. This divine action triggers internal chaos—civil wars among Egyptians, the collapse of their economic systems (dried rivers, failed fisheries), and the spiritual desolation of a people who turn to sorcery and idols for solace. Theologically, Poole underscores that God's judgment targets not merely physical power but the heart's reliance on false idols, revealing Egypt's spiritual bankruptcy despite its ancient pride. Practically, this prophecy warns against the dangers of self-reliance, cultural idolatry, and political fragmentation—encouraging believers to reject systems that prioritize human authority over divine truth. Crucially, Poole connects this chapter to Christ: the "swift cloud" foreshadows Christ's triumphant return (Revelation 1:7), who will ultimately dismantle all false systems of power and idolatry, restoring unity and purpose. For modern readers, this commentary offers profound insight into how God's judgment exposes spiritual decay while pointing to Christ's redemptive role in uniting fractured nations under His kingdom—a call to abandon idolatrous dependencies and align with the One who brings true restoration through faith. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 19 presents this prophecy as a comprehensive vision of Egypt's spiritual and temporal decline leading to profound transformation. The prophet describes a sequence beginning with Yahweh's majestic arrival causing alarm among Egyptian idols, followed by devastating internal chaos, foreign subjugation, physical calamities like the drying of the Nile, widespread economic collapse, and the loss of wisdom and religious authority—all culminating in the nation's conversion to the true God and a renewed alliance with Judah and Assyria under divine protection. Barnes emphasizes that this prophecy, while historically ambiguous (linking it to periods of Egyptian civil strife under Nebuchadnezzar or the dodekarchy), reveals God's sovereign plan to use national crisis as a catalyst for spiritual awakening. Theologically, it demonstrates that divine judgment is never random but purposeful, designed to break false systems and open hearts to the true God. Crucially, Barnes connects this vision to Christ: the "true religion" and "strong alliance" point to the New Covenant where Christ, as the ultimate ruler and restorer, unites nations under His sovereignty, fulfilling Isaiah's promise that Egypt would become a place of divine blessing and refuge. Practically, this commentary teaches that believers should not fear national or personal trials but trust God's redemptive purpose within them—recognizing that temporary afflictions often precede spiritual renewal and that true strength comes from Christ, who transforms chaos into unity and restores broken relationships with God and neighbors. The chapter thus offers profound hope for enduring faith amid turmoil. (249 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 20 presents a vivid prophetic scene where Isaiah's removal of sackcloth and shoes—a deliberate act of symbolic humility—signifies God's impending judgment on Egypt and Ethiopia through Assyrian conquest. Henry emphasizes this sign as a powerful illustration of how worldly expectations and human pride inevitably lead to shame and displacement. Theologically, Henry underscores that true divine authority transcends human political power; the Assyrian invasion serves as a stark reminder that God's sovereignty overrides national identities and self-reliance. Practically, Henry urges believers to reject false hopes in worldly systems or human strength, instead trusting God's provision in times of crisis—just as Isaiah's temporary humiliation pointed to ultimate deliverance. Crucially, Henry connects this passage to Christ by highlighting how Christ's ultimate victory over sin and death fulfills the prophecy's deeper meaning: the "nakedness" of the nations becomes a foreshadowing of humanity's need for Christ's righteousness, where true strength comes not from earthly power but divine grace. In modern terms, this commentary challenges believers to avoid placing their hope in fleeting temporal solutions, recognizing that only Christ—our Righteousness and eternal refuge—can truly liberate us from the "shame of expectation" and unite us in authentic faith. Henry concludes that such obedience, though initially seeming foolish to the world, secures divine support and points toward Christ's final triumph over all earthly powers. (248 words)

Calvin meticulously analyzes Isaiah 20:1-6, emphasizing its historical context during Sennacherib's Assyrian threat to Israel, where Jerusalem faced imminent destruction while Egypt and Ethiopia were falsely relied upon for aid. The prophet's instruction to walk naked and barefoot serves as a profound symbol of divine judgment: Isaiah's vulnerability reveals Israel's unbelief and idolatry, as their desperate turn to Egypt for salvation exposed their rejection of God's sovereignty. Calvin underscores that this "sign and wonder" deliberately shame Egypt and Ethiopia by prophesying their humiliating defeat—naked, barefoot captives brought to Egypt's shame—highlighting that human alliances are futile against God's purposes. Theologically, Calvin stresses that true faith rejects false reliance on human strength, positioning God's judgment as corrective for idolatry. Practically, this warns believers against cultural or political dependencies, urging humility in recognizing that only God's covenant promises provide true security. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ: Jesus' future humiliation (as the "servant" in Isaiah 53) fulfills this vision, where divine weakness becomes the vehicle of ultimate victory. Just as Isaiah's nakedness exposed Israel's spiritual blindness, Christ's vulnerability on the cross reveals God's power over sin and death. This prophecy thus points to Christ as the true "helper" who defeats all earthly powers, teaching that authentic salvation flows not from human alliances but from faith in God's sovereign redemption, where humility and submission to Christ's cross become the path to true liberation. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 20 reveals a profound theological warning through the prophet's symbolic act of walking naked and barefoot for three years. Poole interprets this visible sign as God's declaration that Egypt and Ethiopia—representing nations Israel had wrongly trusted for deliverance—would face humiliating subjugation under Assyrian power. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereignty over all nations and the futility of relying on human strength or foreign alliances when true salvation comes from divine intervention. It exposes the deep spiritual sickness of idolatry, where people place hope in powers incapable of protection, thereby inviting judgment. Practically, this calls believers to reject false security in political or economic systems during crises, urging instead a posture of humility and reliance on God rather than human promises. Crucially, Poole connects this prophecy to Christ: the Assyrian conquest symbolizes the temporary, worldly oppression Christ will ultimately overcome. Just as Egypt and Ethiopia were rendered powerless by Assyrian force, Christ's victory over sin and death dismantles all false hopes, revealing that true deliverance comes not from national strength but from Christ's redemptive power. This commentary thus challenges modern readers to abandon desperate reliance on human solutions and instead cultivate faith in the one who brings eternal freedom, transforming the "captivity" narrative into a promise of ultimate liberation through Christ alone. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 20 reveals a profound theological warning during Hezekiah's reign when Assyrian forces, led by a general named Tartan, threatened Judah by capturing key Philistine ports like Ashdod. Isaiah's symbolic act—removing his sackcloth (a prophetic emblem of mourning and humility) and shoe, walking naked and barefoot for three years—served as a divine sign to expose the futility of Judah's reliance on Egypt and Ethiopia for protection against Assyria. This deliberate humiliation was not literal nakedness but a powerful visual metaphor illustrating how nations would be stripped of their power and carried captive, demonstrating God's sovereignty over human alliances and the peril of idolatrous trust in human strength. Theologically, this prophecy underscores that true security stems solely from God, not temporal alliances or military might, highlighting the folly of placing hope in human resources during divine judgment. Practically, it challenges believers to avoid false dependencies in crises, especially when facing external threats, and to cultivate faith that transcends political or nationalistic solutions. Christologically, the "three years" symbolically prefigures Christ's three-year ministry before the cross—where He became the ultimate fulfillment of this prophecy by conquering the enemy through sacrificial obedience, uniting all nations under His reign. This passage thus calls Christians to trust God's providence in times of global instability, recognizing that His peace and protection are only accessible through Christ, not human alliances or political maneuvering.

Matthew Henry interprets Isaiah chapter 21 as a prophetic vision of divine judgment and the church's enduring faith, emphasizing Babylon's destruction as a type of the ultimate fall of worldly power opposing God's kingdom. The chapter reveals how God's judgment on Babylon—symbolizing oppressive systems—prefigures Christ's victory over evil, as the "terrible land" (Babylon) falls under the Lord's authority, its idols broken, and its people scattered. Henry highlights the "corn of God's floor" metaphor, where true believers endure persecution like wheat in the threshing floor, yet remain securely owned by God despite trials. This theological insight underscores that God's church, both historically and presently, faces opposition but finds ultimate security in His sovereignty. Practically, Henry urges vigilance: the watchman's cry—"The morning cometh, and also the night"—calls believers to abandon complacency, actively seek repentance, and prepare for spiritual storms before they become devastating. Christ connects directly here: Babylon's fall foreshadows Christ's triumph over the "powers of darkness" (Col 2:15), where the true Church is the "corn" that will be perfected through suffering. Henry's commentary thus challenges readers to embrace Christ's authority, avoid worldly security, and live with the assurance that God's judgment purifies His people while His kingdom endures. In a world of chaos, this passage calls for urgent spiritual readiness—knowing that Christ's victory ensures the faithful will be preserved and ultimately transformed, not destroyed. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 21 as a prophetic warning against misplaced hope in worldly powers, emphasizing God's sovereign judgment on nations that exploit others. He views the "burden of the desert" as a vivid declaration that destruction originates from a "terrible land" (Judea), revealing how God's wrath targets those who rely on human strength rather than divine mercy. Theophorically, Calvin stresses that Babylon's fall—declared by the watchman—symbolizes God's ultimate retribution for oppression, while the "chariots" represent military violence that ultimately fails. Theologically, this passage underscores God's active sovereignty: He disciplines nations to restore justice and protect His people, contrasting human pride with divine purpose. Practically, Calvin urges believers to remain spiritually vigilant, avoiding false security in political or economic systems, and to cultivate humility before God's judgment. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ: the "Babylon" of the passage (representing corrupt systems of power and idolatry) finds its final destruction in Christ's victory over sin and death. This ensures that the watchman's declaration—Babylon's fall—points not to human defeat but to Christ's ultimate triumph, where God's kingdom replaces all oppressive structures. Believers are thus called to trust God's promises, remain alert to spiritual threats, and find true security in Christ alone. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 21 reveals a profound theological narrative where the prophet's vision of Babylon's impending destruction by the Medes and Persians serves as a powerful metaphor for God's sovereign judgment over earthly empires. Poole interprets the "desert of the sea" as Babylon's plain geography near the Euphrates, symbolizing how even a mighty city like Babylon—once prosperous—will be reduced to desolation. The prophet's visceral reaction—his "pangs of child-bearing" and terror—highlights the spiritual anguish of anticipating divine judgment, a suffering that finds its ultimate resolution in Christ. Theophatically, this passage underscores that all human power systems, no matter how formidable, are transient and subject to God's will. Poole emphasizes that Babylon's downfall foreshadows Christ's ultimate triumph over all earthly kingdoms and systems of oppression, where the "treacherous dealer" (Babylon's rulers) and "spoiler" (the Medes/Persians) will be decisively overcome by Christ's kingdom. Practically, this commentary urges believers to avoid the false security of Babylon's "feasting" culture—where pride and complacency lead to spiritual blindness—by cultivating vigilant watchfulness (like the watchman in the passage) and recognizing that true peace comes only through Christ's return. It challenges modern Christians to reject worldly power structures that exploit and oppress, instead living in hope of the kingdom where Christ's victory brings lasting restoration, not temporary destruction. Thus, Poole's analysis bridges ancient prophecy and present reality, showing that our spiritual health depends on aligning with Christ's sovereign purpose rather than succumbing to the chaos of earthly empires. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 21 reveals a vivid prophetic oracle centered on Babylon's impending destruction by the Medes and Persians, delivered as both a historical warning and a profound comfort for exiled Jews. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes this passage as a divine assurance that God's sovereign hand will dismantle Babylon—the symbol of idolatrous oppression—fulfilling the promise of liberation for God's people. The striking imagery of "whirlwinds" from the "desert of the sea" (verse 1) portrays Babylon's sudden collapse, contrasting its past splendor with its inevitable desolation, thereby illustrating God's judgment on sin and worldly power structures. Barnes connects this prophecy to the broader context of Isaiah 13–14, underscoring that Babylon's fall was not random but a deliberate act of God to end Israel's bondage. Practically, this text calls believers to vigilance and trust: just as the watchman in verse 7 alerts of impending disaster, Christians must remain alert to spiritual threats while fixing eyes on Christ's ultimate victory. Crucially, Barnes identifies Christ as the true fulfillment of this prophecy—Babylon's destruction prefigures the final defeat of sin and death through Jesus, whose coming brings the "threshing" (verse 10) of the church, purifying believers from worldly corruption and securing their eternal deliverance. This oracle thus serves as a timeless reminder that God's faithful promises, even in times of exile, point to the cross and resurrection, urging believers to find hope in Christ's victory over all opposing forces. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah chapter 22 presents Jerusalem's impending devastation as a profound warning against spiritual complacency and worldly pride. Henry emphasizes that Judah's physical preparations—fortifying walls, securing water, and counting houses—reveal a dangerous contempt for God's sovereignty, where earthly security replaces divine dependence. This self-reliance, Henry argues, stems from a fundamental unbelief in the afterlife, leading to spiritual ruin. The chapter's vivid imagery of Shebna, the treasurer, symbolizes human leaders who hoard power and status, only to face violent overthrow and disgrace. Crucially, Henry connects this narrative to Christ's ultimate authority: Eliakim's elevation as a "nail in a sure place" (v23) prefigures Jesus as the eternal foundation of God's kingdom. Christ holds the "key of David" (v22), enabling him to open and shut gates—symbolizing his absolute authority over life and death, both in the present and eternal realms. Theologically, Henry shows that true security lies not in human structures but in Christ, who is the sole "sure place" that endures beyond death or destruction. Practically, this calls believers to reject worldly power dynamics, cultivate humility, and anchor their identity in Christ alone—understanding that all human authority, like Shebna's, will fade, while Christ's kingdom remains unshakable. For modern readers, this means rejecting the false promise of earthly glory and actively seeking Christ as the only foundation that brings true peace and purpose. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 22 as a profound warning against spiritual complacency within Judea, where the "valley of vision" metaphor signifies God's illuminating truth that the people had perverted despite their privileged access to divine revelation. He emphasizes the passage's central contrast: the city's rulers, exemplified by the corrupt treasurer Shebna, have become spiritually blind, prioritizing human power over divine covenant, while the Lord's judgment reveals the futility of their self-appointed authority. Calvin stresses that this prophecy's climax—the anointing of Eliakim as the rightful leader—points unmistakably to Christ, who will ultimately "open and no one shall shut" the kingdom (v.22), fulfilling the Davidic promise by establishing a new, eternal authority beyond human systems. Theologically, Calvin underscores that true spiritual health requires humility before God's sovereignty, rejecting the false confidence of the "valley of vision" that mistakes divine favor for self-sufficiency. Practically, this calls believers to reject worldly power structures and ecclesiastical pride, recognizing that God's authority—embodied in Christ—must govern all things. The passage's Christ connection is explicit: Eliakim's "key" (v.22) symbolizes Christ's exclusive authority over the church and kingdom, ensuring no human system can ultimately hold dominion. Calvin's insight warns that without Christ's transformative rule, all human leadership collapses under divine judgment, urging faithful communities to align with God's eternal design rather than perpetuate systems of corruption. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 22 reveals a profound theological critique of Judah's spiritual bankruptcy amid impending Assyrian/Mede invasion, emphasizing that God's judgment stems not from political failure alone but from the people's abandonment of divine truth. He interprets the "valley of vision" as Jerusalem—a place of divine revelation where prophets saw God's will—now being shattered by human pride and false hope. The text vividly depicts Judah's leaders fleeing, cities collapsing without battle deaths (signifying spiritual desolation), and the people's desperate, futile reliance on human "armour" like fortified walls instead of God's protection. Poole stresses that this calamity arises from profound spiritual deception: the people wrongly believe their physical defenses or human strength can shield them from divine judgment, ignoring that true security comes only through Christ. Theologically, this passage underscores God's sovereignty in punishing spiritual complacency while simultaneously foreshadowing Christ as the ultimate "valley of vision"—the one who reveals God's kingdom and redeems the broken. Practically, it warns against mistaking temporal safety for divine provision, urging believers to examine their trust in human systems versus Christ's sufficiency. In modern contexts, this commentary challenges Christians to avoid the "treading down" of spiritual anxiety by anchoring hope in Christ's victory over all enemies, rather than worldly powers or self-reliance, ensuring we cry not to mountains but to the Living God who turns chaos into redemption. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 22 presents a dual prophetic vision centered on Jerusalem's crisis during Sennacherib's 700 BCE invasion, emphasizing the city's spiritual and moral failure amid physical defense preparations. The prophet vividly depicts Jerusalem's panic—people fleeing to rooftops, moral decay amidst despair, and futile efforts to repair walls and secure water sources—while condemning the populace's abandonment of divine trust in favor of reckless revelry. Barnes clarifies this prophecy specifically refers to Sennacherib's siege, not Nebuchadnezzar's later destruction, citing historical alignment with 2 Chronicles 32:2. Theologically, this passage reveals a profound truth: true security arises not from human ingenuity or temporal defenses but from reliance on God's covenant promises. The "valley of vision" metaphor underscores Jerusalem's role as the prophetic center where divine revelation occurs, yet its collapse symbolizes the consequences of spiritual blindness. Practically, this calls believers to avoid panic-driven excesses during crises, prioritizing spiritual preparation over frantic materialism. Crucially, Barnes connects this to Christ: the prophecy's focus on the "shepherd" (v22) and the "new covenant" points forward to Christ as the true city that endures, whose leadership replaces human rulership and provides eternal refuge from spiritual and temporal enemies. This historical context underscores that Christ's fulfillment resolves the prophecy's tension—delivering divine protection where human efforts fail, offering a model for faithful endurance in present-day uncertainties. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 23 presents Tyre's destruction as a profound divine judgment revealing the transient nature of human glory and the dangers of worldly pride. The text depicts Tyre, a global trading hub renowned for its merchants' wealth and revelry, as a cautionary example where spiritual blindness led to its eventual ruin by the Chaldeans (likely Assyrians). Theologically, Henry emphasizes that God's sovereign action—destroying Tyre's "strong holds" and "crowning city"—demonstrates His absolute power to dismantle human pride and vanity, particularly when nations reject His warnings. This event serves as a stark reminder that earthly prosperity, like Tyre's "harvest of the river" and "merchandise," is temporary and ultimately subject to divine judgment. Practically, Henry urges Christians to avoid spiritual idolatry by viewing wealth not as an end but as a sacred trust; true prosperity flows from Christ's kingdom, not worldly trade. Crucially, the prophecy's 70-year desolation culminates in Tyre's restoration where her "merchandise and hire" become "holiness to the LORD," pointing to Christ's fulfillment: when believers use their resources for God's purposes—feeding the hungry and providing durable clothing—earthly wealth transforms into divine blessing. This underscores that Christ's coming will ultimately replace worldly systems with a kingdom where true wealth is found in service to Him, not in the fleeting triumphs of human ambition.

Calvin interprets Isaiah 23 as a profound divine judgment on Tyre's commercial arrogance, emphasizing God's sovereignty over earthly powers. He argues the prophecy targets Nebuchadnezzar's conquest, not Alexander's later storming, to ensure Tyre's destruction aligns with the Jewish context and serves as a warning against nations oppressing God's people. Theophatically, Calvin sees Tyre's ruin as God's deliberate dismantling of worldly systems that exploit the poor—its "merchandise" (v. 18) symbolizing human wealth that becomes holy only when redirected to Christ's kingdom. Crucially, Calvin connects Tyre's 70-year desolation to Christ's fulfillment: Tyre's eventual restoration as a "holy city" (v. 18) prefigures Christ, who dismantles corrupt systems and establishes a new covenant where true prosperity comes through divine provision, not human trade. Theologically, this underscores God's justice—oppressors face judgment while His people find restoration in Him. Practically, this commentary challenges believers to reject worldly wealth and power structures that prioritize human gain over divine love. In a modern context, it urges humility before God's sovereignty, encouraging faith that true security stems from Christ's kingdom rather than temporal empires. Calvin's insight reveals that Christ's coming completes God's promise: the "holy merchandise" of the redeemed becomes the means of sustaining the faithful, not the accumulation of earthly riches, inviting believers to align their lives with divine restoration rather than human ambition. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 23 presents a profound theological critique of Tyre's hubris and divine sovereignty. He interprets the prophecy as God's judgment against Tyre—a once-mighty city of trade and naval power—destroyed twice (first by Nebuchadnezzar, later by Alexander) for its pride and reliance on worldly wealth rather than God. Poole emphasizes that Tyre's destruction, revealed through the lament of "ships of Tarshish" (merchants) and the "land of Chittim" (global trade networks), illustrates how human empires inevitably collapse when they reject divine authority. Theologically, this underscores God's absolute control over human history and the futility of earthly power structures, as Tyre's "revenue" from Egypt's grain (the "seed of Sihor") became a symbol of temporary prosperity that ultimately served destruction. Crucially, Poole connects this prophecy to Christ: Tyre's final destruction prefigures the ultimate triumph of Christ over spiritual and political powers, revealing that true security comes not from earthly trade or dominance but from Christ's kingdom. Practically, this commentary warns believers against the seduction of wealth and worldly influence, urging humility and reliance on God rather than human systems. In modern contexts, it challenges Christians to avoid building their identities on temporary economic or political success, instead finding lasting purpose in Christ-centered community and service—where the "sea" (the church) remains a place of refuge, not a site of temporary trade.

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 23 presents a clear historical and theological framework for Tyre's prophetic destruction. Barnes emphasizes that the prophecy specifically foretells Tyre's downfall by Nebuchadnezzar's siege (not Alexander the Great), detailing God's judicial sentence against this proud, luxurious city that had become a global trading hub. Theologically, this passage reveals God's sovereign authority over nations and His consistent pattern of judgment against worldly power and materialism—Tyre's hubris and commercial opulence, which led to spiritual decay, serve as a stark warning that no city or empire escapes divine retribution when it prioritizes wealth and independence over righteousness. Barnes connects this to Christ's redemptive work: Tyre's destruction foreshadows the ultimate triumph of Christ over sin and death, where the "wealth" of the world is ultimately consecrated to God's service, pointing to the New Covenant where true prosperity flows from Christ, not earthly empires. Practically, this commentary challenges believers to avoid the same pitfalls—chasing temporary wealth, self-reliance, and worldly status—by anchoring their lives in Christ. It urges humility before God's sovereignty, encouraging a focus on spiritual wealth and community rather than material dominance, and reminds Christians that God's judgment is both a warning against idolatry and a promise of restoration for those who submit to Him, culminating in the Church as God's renewed community. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 24 presents a profound theological vision of God's judgment on a sin-corrupted world, where human rebellion has turned creation upside down. He emphasizes that sin's pervasive pollution—breaking covenants, corrupting systems, and shattering natural order—triggers divine desolation: the earth "mourneth and fadeth away," worldly joy vanishes, and the powerful are destroyed, leaving only desolation and weeping. This judgment reveals the transient nature of earthly prosperity, where even the "mirth of tabrets" and "strong drink" become bitter without God. Crucially, Henry contrasts this universal decay with a divine remnant—believers who, though scattered like "gleanings of the olive tree," find unshakable joy in Christ. Their hope isn't in temporal security but in the covenant of grace, which remains "everlasting." Theologically, this underscores God's sovereignty: He permits temporal ruin to expose sin's consequences while preserving a faithful few who "rejoice in the Lord." Practically, it calls believers to mourn sin, reject worldly pursuits of pleasure, and anchor their joy in Christ's promise of restoration. Christologically, Henry links this passage directly to Jesus' return: the "new heavens and new earth" (Isaiah 24:23) foretells Christ's ultimate reign where the "moon shall be confounded" and "the sun ashamed," fulfilling God's promise that righteousness will dwell. For the Christian, this means enduring present trials with confidence, knowing that Christ's kingdom—where "the righteous" sing—will ultimately replace the broken world, transforming suffering into eternal purpose. (248 words)

Calvin interpreted Isaiah 24 as a profound prophecy of universal divine judgment, not limited to Israel alone but encompassing all nations where human sin has corrupted the earth. He emphasized that the "earth" refers to the known world systems of the ancient Near East—Jews, Egyptians, Assyrians, and others—each facing desolation as God's curse consumes sin's consequences. The passage reveals theological insight: human transgression shatters covenant and divine order, causing the land to "mourn" and "fade" (v. 4), while social structures collapse equally—priests, rulers, and commoners experience mutual ruin. This underscores that sin's devastation extends beyond individuals to entire societal frameworks. Practically, Calvin urged believers to confront their own pride and economic injustice, as the text depicts usury, corruption, and broken relationships mirroring the "treacherous dealers" (v. 16). The vivid imagery of the vineyard and wine turning bitter (v. 7–9) serves as a stark warning against empty joy and spiritual complacency. Crucially, Calvin connected this prophecy to Christ's ultimate triumph: the "moon confounded" and "sun ashamed" (v. 23) symbolize Christ's sovereign reign where sin's power ends and God's kingdom is established—first in Zion, then globally. This foreshadows Christ's victory over death and the new creation, where the "earth" is renewed under divine rule. For modern readers, this commentary calls for humility before God's justice, active resistance to systemic sin, and hope in Christ who transforms desolation into restoration, fulfilling Isaiah's vision of God's righteous judgment and eternal peace. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 24 presents a profound theological vision of God's judgment on Israel and its universal implications, emphasizing the earth's defilement through sin and the subsequent desolation. Poole interprets the "earth" specifically as the land of Canaan and Israel, noting that the prophecy's context centers on Judah's transgressions—breaking God's eternal covenant through unfaithfulness to divine law and worship. This defilement (Isaiah 24:5) results in the land being "utterly emptied" (v. 3), where the "haughty people" and "merry-hearted" lose all joy, their cities reduced to desolation (v. 12), and the "new wine mourns" as hope vanishes (v. 7). Crucially, Poole stresses that this judgment is not merely local but reveals a universal truth: sin corrupts all relationships, and God's wrath consumes the unrepentant, leaving only a remnant who praise Him (v. 13-15). Theologically, this underscores that true restoration flows from covenantal obedience, not human effort; the "shaking of an olive tree" (v. 13) symbolizes God's purifying judgment that precedes renewal. Practically, Christians must examine their own "defilements" in worship and ethics, recognizing that temporary desolation (like the "city of confusion" in v. 10) is a sign of spiritual decay, not divine abandonment. The Christ connection is implicit: this prophetic desolation points to Christ's ultimate redemption, where the "remnant" becomes the Church—those who endure judgment to experience God's new covenant, as the "vintage" (v. 13) is finally gathered in resurrection hope. Thus, Poole's commentary calls believers to humility, repentance, and trust in God's promise that even in desolation, His faithful remnant will praise Him. (245 words)

Barnes interprets Isaiah 24 as part of a unified prophecy (24–27) depicting divine judgment followed by redemption, centered on Nebuchadnezzar's invasion and Babylonian exile as the primary historical context. The chapter vividly portrays the land's desolation—earth "emptied" and "upside down," scattering inhabitants and shattering social order—while emphasizing that even the righteous will experience shared calamity. Barnes highlights the profound theological insight that God's judgment is not random destruction but a necessary purification process, ultimately leading to renewal. This vision points directly to Christ: the "Lord of hosts" reigning on Mount Zion (v.23) foreshadows the Messiah's ultimate kingdom, where divine judgment transforms the land into a place of God's sovereign rule. Practically, this commentary encourages believers facing modern crises—natural disasters, social upheaval, or personal trials—to anchor hope in God's promise that temporary desolation precedes restoration. Just as survivors in Isaiah's vision lifted "songs of praise," Christians are called to maintain community resilience and worship amid suffering, trusting that God's deliverance will purify the people and establish His eternal reign. Barnes stresses that this prophecy's enduring relevance lies in its reminder that even in the deepest desolation, God's sovereignty ensures that His kingdom will triumph, offering a foundation for hope that transcends historical contexts and points steadfastly to Christ's return. (247 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 25 emphasizes Christ's ultimate triumph over death and spiritual enemies as the central theme, interpreting the chapter's promises through a New Testament lens. He highlights how verses 1-5 reveal God's protective nature for the humble, contrasting the temporary power of worldly strength with Christ's enduring refuge, while verses 6-8 present the "feast" as a divine invitation to all nations—Jew and Gentile alike—through the gospel's power to transform the dead in sin into living believers. Theologically, Henry stresses that Christ's victory over death (verse 8) and the "wiping away of tears" signify complete redemption, where the curse of sin is fully lifted, and the brokenness of the present world is healed in the believer's hope. Practical applications center on finding present comfort in Christ's finished work: believers today experience the "feast" through forgiveness and the Spirit's renewal, while enduring sorrow or persecution should be met with steadfast trust, knowing God will ultimately dismantle all opposition—symbolized by the "trodden down" enemies in verses 10-12. Christ is explicitly the fulfillment of this passage: his resurrection conquers death, his atoning work dissolves the "veil" of sin, and his coming reign brings the eternal joy described, urging believers to persevere in hope, knowing their labor in Christ is not in vain. This commentary thus anchors present hope in Christ's definitive victory, transforming suffering into purpose. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 25 as a profound response to impending divine judgments, where the prophet shifts from lamentation to triumphant thanksgiving after experiencing the terror of God's wrath against nations. Theologically, Calvin emphasizes that God's judgments are not arbitrary but purposeful—intended to subdue rebellious humanity and pave the way for universal redemption. This chapter reveals Christ's ultimate triumph: death is "swallowed up in victory" (v. 8), a direct promise of resurrection power, while the "feast of fat things" (v. 6) symbolizes Christ's atoning work, offering eternal life and communion with God. Calvin underscores that this hope transcends national boundaries, as God's mercy dismantles all barriers—reducing "the fortress of the high fort" (v. 12) and lifting the oppressed, reflecting Christ's role as both refuge and refiner of humanity. Practically, Calvin urges believers to embrace this perspective when overwhelmed by trials: when distress arises, as Isaiah did, we must immediately turn to God as the source of both strength and salvation. The "feast" calls us to trust Christ's victory over death and despair, while the promise of tears being "wiped away" (v. 8) reminds us to find joy in God's promise of restoration. This commentary teaches that true security comes not from avoiding judgment but from clinging to Christ's finished work—where God's faithfulness in the cross and resurrection delivers a world shattered by sin, offering hope that death itself is conquered for all who believe. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 25 reveals a profound theological vision where God's unwavering faithfulness and sovereign power are central. He interprets the chapter as a declaration of God's past deliverance from enemies like Babylon, His present protection of the vulnerable, and the imminent triumph of His kingdom. Theologically, Poole emphasizes that God's ancient promises—rooted in eternal truth—ensure future fulfillment, while the destruction of hostile powers (v. 3–5) signifies Christ's victory over sin and death. The feast described in verse 6, a "feast of fat things" and "wines on the lees," symbolizes the full communion of believers—Jew and Gentile—enriched by God's grace and the spiritual nourishment found in His church. Crucially, verses 7–8 directly point to Christ: His promise to "swallow up death in victory" (v. 8) reflects His resurrection power over mortality, and the wiping away of tears signifies His redemptive work that heals suffering and removes the "rebuke" of persecution. Practically, this commentary urges believers to live in confidence of God's sovereignty, especially amid current struggles. It calls for active hope in Christ's finished work, recognizing that His victory dismantles the forces of oppression and death. As Poole notes, this promise transforms how Christians respond to adversity—trusting that God's faithful reign brings ultimate restoration, joy, and the assurance that all tears will be wiped away through Christ's triumphant return. The chapter thus serves as both a divine declaration of hope and a practical invitation to participate in God's kingdom through faith. (247 words)

Barnes interprets Isaiah 25 as a prophetic song of praise emerging from the context of Jerusalem's desolation in Isaiah 24, anticipating God's triumphant deliverance of Israel from Babylonian captivity and His future reign on Mount Zion. The chapter's core theological insight centers on Yahweh's active faithfulness: He has already destroyed Babylon (a "heap" and "ruin") to liberate the oppressed, establishing Himself as the unshakable refuge and strength for the poor and needy in their distress.
