Critically, Barnes emphasizes that verses 6-8 reveal a profound Christological dimension through the declaration that death will be "swallowed up in victory" (v. 8), a promise directly pointing to Christ's ultimate triumph over sin and death through resurrection power—a fulfillment of God's ancient covenant promises. This vision of divine sovereignty overcoming all opposition and securing eternal life for the faithful forms the chapter's foundation. Practically, believers today are called to live in the assurance of God's ongoing deliverance from spiritual and temporal bondage, recognizing Him as their present refuge during life's "storms." The chapter challenges Christians to actively participate in the global redemption Christ inaugurated, trusting His victory over death and the enemy to bring hope and peace where fear and despair prevail, embodying the song of praise that anticipates the full restoration of God's kingdom. (248 words)

Matthew Henry interprets Isaiah 26 as a prophetic declaration of God's eternal strength and the secure refuge found in Christ, emphasizing that true peace and deliverance come solely through divine covenant. He highlights how the "strong city" described in verse 1 symbolizes the church, whose walls are God's unchanging promises—contrasted with the temporary, unstable nature of worldly security. Theologically, Henry underscores that perfect peace (verse 4) arises not from human efforts but from surrender to God's sovereignty, particularly for those whose hearts remain fixed on Him. Crucially, he connects this chapter to Christ's resurrection as the definitive "earnest" of future deliverance (verse 19), revealing that believers are already raised with Christ and empowered by His victory over death. Practically, Henry urges Christians to actively seek God's peace in trials, avoiding reliance on fleeting earthly comforts. He stresses the necessity of secret prayer during affliction (verse 20), modeling how believers should retreat into God's presence for safety and renewal, rather than succumbing to worldly anxieties. This Christ-centered perspective transforms suffering into an opportunity to deepen dependence on the living God who "ordains peace" (verse 12) and who ultimately "will punish the inhabitants of the earth" (verse 21) for iniquity—yet offers eternal security to those who trust Him. Thus, Henry's commentary calls believers to rest in Christ's resurrection power, finding enduring peace and purpose even amidst present trials. (248 words)

Calvin emphasizes that Isaiah 26:1-21 presents a song of hope sung *before* the exile, intended to fortify the Israelites during their captivity by affirming God's ultimate protection and resurrection power. Theologically, Calvin highlights the contrast between fleeting earthly strength and God's eternal sovereignty: the "strong city" (v. 1) symbolizes divine preservation, not human defenses, while verses 5-6 reveal how God dismantles oppressive systems—both the "lofty city" and the "feet of the poor"—affirming that true security comes from Him alone. Crucially, Calvin connects this chapter to Christ through its resurrection promise (v. 19), where "dead men shall live," pointing to Christ's victory over death as the foundation of eternal life. This hope transcends historical context, as Calvin notes the song was meant for present trials, not just future deliverance. Practically, believers today find application in trusting God's "perfect peace" (v. 3) amidst chaos, resisting the temptation to seek strength in worldly systems, and understanding that Christ's coming judgment (v. 21) purifies the earth while His resurrection power offers present comfort. Calvin urges Christians to "hide themselves" (v. 20) in faith during spiritual desolation, knowing that God's active care—exemplified in Christ's triumph—guarantees ultimate restoration. This commentary thus anchors hope in Christ's finished work: the true city of God is built on resurrection life, not temporal power, inviting believers to live with confidence that God's peace and justice will prevail.

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 26 emphasizes a profound theological vision of God as the ultimate refuge and source of enduring peace for His people. He interprets the "strong city" as the church—both the redeemed community and the spiritual fortress of God's kingdom—where divine salvation replaces physical walls, signifying God's active protection and provision. This vision finds its deepest fulfillment in Christ, who becomes the "lofty city" (symbolizing worldly power and sin) brought low through His sacrificial victory, while the "righteous nation" (the church) enters God's presence with steadfast faith. Poole highlights that true peace arises not from human security but from a heart fixed on God through trust, a state secured by Christ's eternal nature. Theologically, this reveals God's sovereign role in both judgment and redemption: His judgments refine the righteous, yet His ultimate purpose is to bring righteousness to the world through His people. Practically, believers are called to seek God in times of trial, trusting His "everlasting strength" to maintain peace amid life's chaos—just as the prophet urges active longing for God's presence "in the night" of affliction. Christologically, this passage underscores how Jesus' triumph over sin and death transforms the church into a city of peace, where the "way of the just" (characterized by Christ-like integrity) is made straight by the Spirit. For modern readers, Poole's insight encourages daily reliance on God's promises rather than worldly power, fostering resilience through Christ-centered hope that even in judgment, God's purpose for righteousness remains active and accessible. (278 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 26 presents a post-exilic song of praise celebrating the Jewish restoration to Jerusalem, where God's protective presence transforms the city into a "strong city" (v1). Theologically, this chapter reveals a profound paradox: true security and peace emerge not from human strength or political power, but from unwavering trust in Yahweh, who humbles the proud and safeguards the righteous (v5-7). Barnes emphasizes that this peace is found in the mind "stayed" on God—meaning sustained by Him amid suffering—contrasting sharply with the wicked who reject divine action (v9-11). Crucially, the chapter anticipates Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of this promise. The "everlasting strength" (v4) points to Christ, the unchanging Rock who remains steadfast through all trials, while the "strong city" becomes the New Jerusalem where God's people find eternal security. Practically, this commentary urges believers to cultivate present trust in God's active protection during crises, especially when facing persecution or displacement—just as the exiles maintained faith despite captivity. It challenges modern Christians to abandon self-reliance, recognizing that true peace flows from Christ's finished work, not human efforts. The assurance of resurrection (v19) and God's final judgment on oppressors (v21) remind us that faithful submission to Christ secures both present comfort and future restoration, making the "righteous nation" (v2) a community united in hope under the cross.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 27 presents a powerful Christ-centered vision of divine victory and the church's enduring purpose. The chapter depicts God's decisive action against chaos—leviathan, the great serpent—symbolizing Satan's ultimate defeat through Christ's powerful sword, the cross. Henry emphasizes that this victory is achieved not through human strength but through Jesus' death and the gospel's preaching, which conquer the "dragon" of death and rebellion. The church, described as a vineyard requiring constant divine care, faces trials but is sustained by God's faithful protection and grace; without this ongoing watering of spiritual life, believers wither. Crucially, Henry connects this imagery to Christ's role as the reconciling power: just as God offers peace through Christ's sacrifice ("let him take hold of my strength"), believers must rely on this salvation to avoid spiritual destruction. Practically, this calls for daily dependence on Christ's strength amid persecution, recognizing that God's afflictions refine and purify, not destroy. The commentary also highlights Christ's ultimate restoration promise—where the gospel gathers scattered people (Jews and Gentiles) into worship at Jerusalem—underscoring that true peace comes through Christ, not human efforts. Henry stresses that the church's fruitfulness depends on persistent faith, avoiding self-reliance, and embracing the cross as the only means of reconciliation. This vision challenges believers to actively seek Christ's grace, trusting his victory over sin and death to endure trials and bear spiritual fruit in a world of chaos. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 27 as a profound declaration of God's sovereign judgment against Satan's pervasive kingdom, using the metaphor of "leviathan" to represent this fallen power. He emphasizes that God's "sore, great, and strong sword" will decisively destroy this formidable enemy, not through physical violence alone but through divine authority that pierces deception and dismantles Satan's corrupt systems. Theologically, Calvin stresses that this passage reveals God's protective care for His people—ensuring their sustenance and defense—while simultaneously exposing Satan's deceptive nature and the temporary strength of his dominion. This judgment is not final destruction but a necessary purification: God's action purges sin and false worship (v.9), preparing the way for true restoration. Practically, Calvin urges believers to recognize the ongoing spiritual warfare against deceptive forces, trusting God's daily protection and vigilance against the "briers and thorns" of sin and worldly temptation. The passage's Christ-centered significance lies in its fulfillment: Christ Himself is the ultimate "sore and strong sword" who defeats the serpent (Satan) and establishes the New Covenant. Calvin connects this to Christ's victory over death and the resurrection, where God's judgment becomes the foundation for reconciliation and the renewed community of God's people. Believers are called to participate in this restoration, awaiting the day when God's kingdom fully triumphs, as the "great trumpet" signals the gathering of all exiles to worship in Jerusalem—a promise fulfilled in Christ's redemptive work and the hope of eternal restoration. (248 words)

Poole interprets Isaiah 27:1-13 as a profound declaration of God's sovereign judgment and protective care for His people, emphasizing that the "leviathan" and "dragon" symbolize formidable human enemies—historically Assyria or Babylon—whom God will decisively punish with His "sore and great and strong sword." Theologically, Poole highlights God's active covenantal commitment: He personally "keeps" His vineyard (His church), guarding it from destruction by enemies, drought, or natural calamity while simultaneously restraining His wrath to prevent total devastation, demonstrating grace through restraint rather than destruction. This divine protection culminates in the promise that God's people will "take root," flourishing spiritually and multiplicatively, reflecting Christ's role as the true vine (John 15:1) whose believers bear eternal fruit. Poole's Christ connection is central here: the "dragon" (a sea-monster) represents the ultimate enemy, but Christ's victory over sin and death fulfills this prophecy, ensuring believers' security and future prosperity. Practically, this commentary urges believers to trust God's active defense in current struggles, actively seek reconciliation through Christ's strength (as in the "wrestling" of Jacob), and cultivate deep spiritual roots in community—knowing that God's covenantal care ensures their flourishing despite present enemies. When persecution looms, this passage encourages reliance on Christ's victory, not human strength, to endure and multiply faith. (278 words)

Barnes argues that Isaiah 27 functions as a direct continuation of Isaiah 24–26, focusing on the Babylonian captivity and subsequent deliverance as the central event. He interprets the chapter's core as God's decisive action against Israel's oppressive enemy—identified by Barnes as Babylon or its tyrant (the "leviathan," a crocodile-like sea monster symbolizing a fierce, voracious oppressor)—through His "sore and great and strong sword," signifying both divine judgment and His active power in history. The subsequent vineyard song reveals God's purpose: His people will be purified from idolatry through this deliverance, experiencing His mercy despite suffering. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes the tension between God's righteous judgment (the "piercing serpent") and His redemptive intent to restore His people to holiness and the holy mountain. This purification process, while painful, ultimately secures their return to Jerusalem and genuine worship. Practically, believers are called to trust God's sovereign discipline as He uses trials to refine faith, avoiding fear of present oppression. Crucially, Barnes connects this chapter to Christ: the "leviathan" represents sin and Satan's dominion, while Christ's crucifixion becomes the "piercing" victory that destroys the enemy and enables the ultimate spiritual purification and restoration of God's people—fulfilling the promise of a renewed community in the New Covenant. This commentary thus underscores that God's judgments are purposeful, leading to lasting renewal through Christ.

Henry warns that Isaiah 28 reveals the peril of spiritual pride and drunkenness, particularly among God's people, who mistake temporary prosperity for lasting security. The "crown of pride" and "drunkards of Ephraim" symbolize self-reliance and worldly indulgence that inevitably lead to ruin—like a fading flower or hasty fruit consumed before maturity. Theologically, Henry emphasizes that true life and strength come not from human effort or false confidence but from Christ as the "tried stone," a sure foundation that withstands all judgment. This Christ-centered foundation contrasts sharply with the "covenant with death" and "agreement with hell" that those who trust in their own righteousness or false teachings embrace, which ultimately proves futile. Practically, this commentary urges believers to reject spiritual complacency and the false refuge of self-sufficiency, instead seeking Christ's wisdom through consistent, repeated engagement with Scripture—precept upon precept—so that the "weary" find rest in Him alone. Henry insists that only faith in Christ's finished work provides true security, as His righteousness disannuls the "covenant with death" and offers a refuge that no worldly power can destroy. This demands a humble reliance on Christ, not human systems, where the "bed" of self-righteousness is too narrow for true peace, while Christ's cross becomes the only foundation that "shall not be moved."

Calvin interprets Isaiah 28 as a stark warning against Ephraim's spiritual degeneracy, where pride and drunkenness—symbolizing self-reliance and false security—lead to divine judgment. He emphasizes that the "crown of pride" (v.1) and "drunkards" (v.7) represent those who trust in worldly systems rather than God, their "glorious beauty" a fleeting "fading flower" destroyed by spiritual intoxication. Theologically, Calvin highlights God's dual action: His wrath against rebellion (the "hail and flood" of v.2) and His promise of true restoration for the obedient ("crown of glory" v.5). This passage reveals a critical truth: human sinfulness renders all human efforts futile ("tables full of vomit," v.8), while genuine understanding comes only through patient, step-by-step instruction ("precept upon precept," v.10–11), not quick solutions. Practical applications demand vigilance against spiritual complacency—avoiding false prophets, rejecting idolatrous covenants with "death and hell" (v.15), and embracing humility to receive God's Word. Crucially, Calvin connects Christ as the "tried stone" (v.16) and "precious corner-stone" of God's kingdom, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy of a foundation that "he that believeth shall not make haste." This Christ-centered interpretation shows that the "strange work" God accomplishes (v.21)—the cross and new creation—exposes the futility of human rebellion while offering salvation through faith in the perfect, enduring Word. True disciples, like the "wheat" not crushed by false teachings (v.27), find security in Christ alone, whose judgment transforms sinners into God's living temple.

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 28 presents a vivid critique of Ephraim's spiritual and moral decay, interpreting the "crown of pride" as Ephraim's self-congratulatory kingdom and the "drunkards" as those ensnared by spiritual blindness and pride, symbolized by excessive wine. The chapter underscores how this state of unteachableness and rebellion—exemplified by priests and prophets who "err in vision" and "stumble in judgment"—leads to divine judgment, as the "fading flower" of Ephraim's glory is swiftly consumed by enemies. Poole emphasizes that this destruction serves a profound theological purpose: it contrasts the temporary, fragile glory of human ambition with God's eternal provision. While Ephraim faces ruin, the "residue of his people" (Judah) receives God's "crown of glory," a promise of divine wisdom and strength for the faithful remnant. Crucially, Poole connects this prophecy to Christ, identifying the "sure foundation" in Isaiah 28:16 as Christ himself—whom Poole sees as the true "crown of glory" that transcends human destruction and provides eternal security. Theologically, this reveals God's consistent pattern of judgment on spiritual complacency while offering redemption through Christ. Practically, it warns believers to avoid the "drunkenness of Ephraim"—the false confidence in self-sufficiency and worldly glory—encouraging humility, sobriety in spiritual matters, and active pursuit of Christ's wisdom. In a modern context, this commentary urges us to examine our own pride and addiction to fleeting pleasures, recognizing that true security comes only through Christ's foundational work, not human efforts.

Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 28 reveals this chapter as a prophetic warning delivered during Ephraim's (Samaria's) moral decline, predicting its destruction due to widespread sin—particularly spiritual drunkenness and pride—while simultaneously affirming God's preservation of Judah. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes God's sovereign dual action: judgment on the unrepentant (Ephraim) and corrective love for His people (Judah), illustrating that divine discipline is not punitive but purposeful, aimed at cultivating genuine holiness. The "fading flower" imagery (v2) poetically conveys how human pride and sin lead to rapid destruction, while the "corner stone" metaphor (v16) foreshadows Christ as the true foundation of salvation—something only the Messiah would provide enduring security. Practically, this calls believers to reject false security and worldly alliances, recognizing that true strength comes from Christ, not human alliances or self-reliance. The farmer's analogy (v28-29) underscores that God's discipline—like careful harvesting—is necessary for spiritual maturity, urging believers to embrace correction as an expression of divine love rather than fear. Christologically, this passage points to Jesus as the fulfillment of the "corner stone" (v16), whose sacrifice resolves the consequences of sin that the prophets warned about, while the judgment described here finds its ultimate purpose in Christ's redemptive work, where true security comes not from human strength but divine grace. Believers today must therefore cultivate humility, seek Christ for true strength, and understand that God's discipline, though challenging, is essential for spiritual growth and eternal life. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 29 reveals a profound theological tension between superficial religious ritual and genuine spiritual transformation, with Christ as the ultimate fulfillment. Henry interprets Ariel (Jerusalem) as a symbol of the city's spiritual condition, emphasizing that outward religious practices—like sacrifices and lip service—cannot escape divine judgment without inner repentance. The "sealed book" metaphor (29:11-12) illustrates how sinners, whether learned or unlearned, remain spiritually blind, unable to comprehend Scripture without the Spirit's intervention. This blindness contrasts sharply with Christ's role as the one who breaks spiritual darkness: the "deaf hear" and "blind see" (29:18) through His redemptive work, fulfilling the prophecy of a "wonderful work" (29:14) where the meek find joy and the rebellious are consumed. Theorically, Henry stresses that true worship requires heart transformation, not ritual compliance; the "fear of the Lord" must replace "the precept of men." Practically, this calls believers to abandon hypocritical religiosity and actively seek Christ's enlightenment—just as the "erring in spirit" are led to understanding (29:24). Christ's victory over spiritual blindness (the "terrible one" and "scorner" being "brought to nought") shows that God's grace transforms the broken into a "fruitful field" (29:17), where the meek experience profound joy. For modern readers, Henry's warning against superficial worship and his focus on the Spirit's transformative power urge a personal, Christ-centered response: abandoning self-deception to embrace the living God who turns the "desert" into "fruitfulness" through faith. This dynamic connection between Isaiah's vision and Christ's redemption remains vital for authentic spiritual life today. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 29 as a profound warning to Jerusalem, emphasizing the city's spiritual blindness despite its religious rituals. He argues that the "woe" pronounced on Ariel—David's city—highlights a critical contrast: external sacrifices and temple rituals (which the people deemed invincible) are meaningless without genuine repentance and inner transformation. Calvin focuses particularly on the vivid metaphor of the "dream" in verse 8, where nations fighting against Zion wake to emptiness—symbolizing the futility of human efforts to secure divine favor through power or ritual. This imagery underscores a core theological insight: true worship requires a transformed heart, not merely external observance. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment. The "book sealed" in verses 11–12, initially inaccessible to the unlearned, finds its true interpretation through Christ—the living Word who breaks spiritual blindness (Isaiah 29:18–19). Christ becomes the "true altar" where divine revelation is now accessible, fulfilling the promise that the meek and poor will "rejoice in the Holy One of Israel" (v19). Practically, Calvin stresses that believers must actively pursue spiritual awakening, rejecting false religious systems that prioritize ritual over relationship. This involves humility in confronting personal sin, openness to Christ's transformative power, and active participation in the community of faith where "the deaf hear" and "the blind see" through Christ's redemptive work. The passage thus calls for a Christ-centered response: abandoning empty religious performance to embrace the living God who brings true understanding and hope. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 29 reveals Jerusalem ("Ariel," the "strong lion") as the target of divine judgment due to its self-reliance and spiritual hypocrisy. Poole interprets the "woe" as a direct threat to the city where David dwelt, emphasizing that the people's persistent sacrifices ("add ye year to year") fail to appease God because their worship is rooted in pride and a false sense of security. Theologically, this exposes the futility of ritual without genuine repentance—God's judgment ("distress," "heaviness") targets the city's spiritual blindness and the people's "drunkenness" (not with wine but with divine wrath), showing how human efforts to maintain order through sacrifice or military might are ultimately futile against God's sovereign will. Poole highlights the "dream" metaphor (Isaiah 29:8), where enemies' victories against Jerusalem feel satisfying but leave them spiritually empty, underscoring the hollowness of human self-defense and the inevitable consequence of rejecting God's authority. Practically, this calls believers to examine whether their religious practices serve true devotion or mere ritualism, avoiding spiritual complacency. Christologically, this prophecy finds its fulfillment in Christ—whose sacrificial death replaces the temple's rituals (as Poole notes the altar's "devouring" nature), bringing true restoration where human efforts fail. The judgment on Jerusalem points to the ultimate triumph of Christ's kingdom, where the "sacrifices" of the cross become the only lasting remedy for spiritual emptiness, offering hope that God's judgment purges false worship to reveal genuine conversion.

Barnes observes that Isaiah 29 focuses exclusively on Jerusalem, historically termed "Ariel" (a name Barnes interprets as signifying "the altar" rather than "the lion," linking it to God's public worship), and presents a dual message: imminent divine distress followed by sudden deliverance, contrasted with a stern reproof of the people's spiritual infidelity. The chapter's first section (v1-8) describes God's active engagement in besieging Jerusalem, inducing profound sorrow, yet promises the enemy's abrupt collapse—symbolized by thunder, tempest, and flame—ensuring the city's deliverance from Sennacherib's invasion. This divine intervention underscores God's sovereign power to protect His people from immediate threats while exposing their deep spiritual blindness. The second section (v9-24) sharply critiques the city's pervasive hypocrisy: their rituals lacked genuine devotion, their judgments were unjust, and they attempted to conceal wickedness through elaborate schemes. Barnes emphasizes this reproof reveals a universal human condition—external religiosity without inner transformation—contrasted with God's promise of a transformative renewal where the truly obedient find comfort. Theologically, this chapter affirms that true worship demands relational integrity, not ritualistic compliance, and that God's deliverance operates through His active judgment to purify the heart. Practically, it warns against complacency in spiritual life and calls for humility before God's sovereignty. Crucially, Barnes connects this prophecy to Christ: the "sudden deliverance" anticipates Christ's triumph over sin and death, while the reproof of hypocrisy points to the necessity of Christ's work to dismantle spiritual blindness and restore authentic relationship with God, offering hope beyond temporal crises.

Henry's commentary on Isaiah 30 presents a stark warning to Israel's spiritual rebellion, emphasizing their perilous choice to seek security in Egypt's worldly power rather than divine reliance. Henry observes that the Israelites, despite God's prior provision, rejected His authority, actively pursuing false confidence in human strength and foreign alliances—this self-reliance inevitably leads to destruction, as their sins become a "breach ready to fall" (v.13) that shatters their very foundation. Theologically, Henry connects this to Christ's sufficiency: the "strength to sit still" (v.7) described in the passage points not to human effort but to Christ's unshakeable righteousness, which alone provides true refuge from spiritual chaos. Practical application demands humble submission—rejecting idolatrous strategies and trusting God's quiet provision rather than frantic human schemes. Henry stresses that only Christ, as the "Holy One of Israel" (v.18), offers genuine restoration: His healing power (v.26) and the "light of the moon as the sun" (v.26) symbolize Christ's transformative illumination that dispels spiritual darkness. For the modern reader, this means abandoning futile worldly alliances and cultivating quiet faith in Christ's atoning work, where true security comes not from external strength but the inner peace found in divine grace. As Henry concludes, those who wait on Christ—through repentance and persistent prayer—will experience His mercy and restoration, weeping no more for the "breach" of their sin (v.19), revealing Christ as the sole refuge from spiritual ruin.

Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 30 presents a stern warning to Israel's rebellious generation who reject divine counsel and cling to false security in Egypt. He emphasizes that the people's sin—seeking strength in Pharaoh's power rather than God's Spirit—creates a covenant breach that invites divine judgment. Calvin identifies this idolatry as a profound spiritual rebellion where the people dismiss God's word, demanding false prophecies and refusing to heed the "Holy One of Israel." Theological insight reveals that true salvation hinges not on human strength but in God's mercy, as Calvin notes the promise of "returning and rest" (Isaiah 30:15) when Israel turns from oppression. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ: the "light of the sun seven-fold" (Isaiah 30:26) symbolizes Christ's unparalleled illumination, healing the spiritual "wound" of rebellion and restoring Israel's relationship with God. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject worldly idols—whether political or spiritual—by actively seeking God's guidance ("a word behind thee," Isaiah 30:21), discarding false comforts, and trusting in Christ's redemptive power. This applies today by moving away from self-reliance toward dependence on Christ, whose healing and provision surpass human efforts. Calvin's core message remains: only through Christ's mercy—waiting for God's "grace" (Isaiah 30:18)—can the rebellious find true restoration, transforming suffering into hope. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 30 reveals the Israelites' profound rebellion against God's sovereignty by prioritizing human alliances—specifically Egypt—over divine covenant. He emphasizes how the people "take counsel not of me" and seek protection "not of my spirit," adding spiritual and moral sin to their existing transgressions through misplaced trust in Pharaoh's power. Theologically, Poole underscores God's wrath against those who reject His authoritative guidance for national salvation, framing the "rebellious children" as a people who profess divine connection yet actively choose idolatry and self-destruction. Practically, this warns believers today against relying on worldly strength or temporary alliances for security, urging instead to heed God's warnings and cultivate spiritual humility. Crucially, Poole connects this chapter to Christ's fulfillment: the "Egypt" the people trusted becomes the symbol of worldly power that Christ overcomes. Jesus, as the true "Holy One of Israel," provides the only refuge from sin's consequences—unlike Pharaoh's shadow of protection, which leads only to shame and destruction. This prophecy thus points to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise, whose strength replaces human reliance and delivers salvation from the "land of trouble and anguish" of sin and death. Believers are called to reject false security and trust God's word, knowing Christ alone is the "everlasting foundation" for true deliverance.

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 30 reveals this chapter as a prophetic warning delivered during Hezekiah's crisis, when Jerusalem's leaders sought alliances with Egypt against the looming Assyrian threat instead of trusting God. Barnes emphasizes the profound theological insight that this rebellion—relying on human strength and foreign powers—directly contradicts God's covenant promises and the distinct identity of Israel as a people set apart. The chapter exposes a dangerous pattern: when communities abandon divine sovereignty for temporary alliances, they invite self-destruction and national shame, as the Egyptians' inability to deliver (v3-7) and the resulting spiritual confusion (v3-4) demonstrate the futility of such reliance. Practically, this warns modern believers to avoid idolatrous dependencies—whether political alliances, material security, or cultural trends—when facing crises, urging instead to anchor hope in God's promises. Theologically, Barnes connects this passage to Christ's fulfillment: the "wall that falls" (v14) foreshadows Christ's triumph over human enemies, while the "deliverance" from Assyria (v27-33) prefigures Jesus' victory over sin and death. This prophecy underscores that true peace comes not from human strength but from divine intervention, where Christ alone is the "protector" who dismantles oppression. For contemporary readers, the application is urgent: in times of fear or division, resist the temptation to seek solutions from worldly powers, recognizing that God's sovereignty and timely deliverance—through Christ—remain the only reliable foundation for enduring hope and restoration. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 31 powerfully warns against Israel's dangerous reliance on Egypt's military might and human strength, contrasting this with divine sovereignty. He emphasizes that those who trust in chariots, horses, and human power—rather than the Holy One of Israel—face inevitable destruction, as God actively opposes such futile alliances. Theologically, Henry underscores God's transcendent authority: He is not a passive observer but a sovereign defender who will act decisively, using the "Lion of the tribe of Judah" (a clear Christological reference to Christ as the ultimate protector) to secure Jerusalem. This imagery reveals God's compassionate yet authoritative intervention, where His defense is both decisive and protective, like birds guarding their young. Practically, Henry urges believers to abandon idolatrous dependencies—whether material possessions, political alliances, or self-reliance—recognizing that true security comes only through Christ. The commentary highlights a profound application: in times of crisis, we must turn from our own strength to the Lord, who will "pass over" to preserve His people. Henry connects this passage to Christ's ultimate victory over all enemies, particularly the Assyrian threat symbolizing worldly power, which will be defeated by divine power (not human might). For modern readers, this calls for humility in crises, rejection of false idols (including spiritual complacency), and active trust in Christ's protective power—knowing that His defense ensures enduring safety for those who align their hearts with His covenant. This passage remains a vital reminder that lasting security is found exclusively in God, not in human systems. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 31 sharply condemns the Israelites' dangerous reliance on Egypt for military aid, emphasizing their failure to turn to the Holy One of Israel. Calvin identifies this as a profound idolatry, where the people trusted mortal strength—chariots, horses, and human warriors—while neglecting God's sovereignty. Theologically, Calvin stresses that true security cannot come from human alliances or physical power, as these are temporary and inherently flawed; Egypt represents false hope that obscures divine provision. He contrasts this with God's wisdom, noting that He will ultimately dismantle the "help" of the wicked, including the Assyrian threat, revealing the futility of human strength against His purpose. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ: the "Holy One of Israel" is Christ Himself, the true refuge who fulfills the promise of salvation beyond human weakness. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject all false security—whether political, economic, or relational—and actively seek God's guidance rather than relying on worldly systems. This involves dismantling idolatrous attachments (like false allies or self-reliance) and trusting Christ's victory over all enemies, as the "fire in Zion" and "furnace in Jerusalem" symbolize His divine protection and ultimate triumph. In modern contexts, this means resisting the allure of human solutions in crisis, centering faith in Christ's finished work, and abandoning idolatrous dependencies for genuine spiritual security. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 31 powerfully critiques the Jewish leaders' foolish reliance on Egypt for military aid, highlighting their profound idolatry by neglecting God's sovereignty. Poole emphasizes that the Jews' trust in Egypt's horses and warriors—contrary to God's command—revealed a dangerous spiritual blindness, where human strength replaced divine dependence. Theologically, this passage underscores God's absolute sovereignty: He alone will defend Jerusalem (verse 4), not through human alliances but through His own mighty intervention, mirroring the lion's confidence in His prey. Crucially, Poole connects this to Christ, noting that the "LORD of hosts" who fights for Zion is the same Christ who fulfills Isaiah's prophecies—Christ as the true, eternal "help" that surpasses all human efforts and idols. Practically, this commentary urges believers today to reject false security, whether political, economic, or relational, and to turn from self-reliance to Christ as the only reliable source of salvation and protection. Just as the Israelites must abandon their silver and gold idols (verse 7), modern Christians are called to discard systems of human trust that lead to spiritual peril, actively seeking God's kingdom where His strength, not human might, becomes the foundation of hope and deliverance. This passage remains a vital reminder that true security comes only through Christ's active intervention and the cross. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 31 presents a powerful prophetic warning against the Israelites' planned alliance with Egypt during a crisis, emphasizing God's sovereign authority over human alliances and temporal power. The chapter condemns the perilous reliance on Egyptian military might—described as "men" without divine spirit and "horses" devoid of spiritual strength—while asserting that Yahweh alone would protect Jerusalem through decisive, unyielding action. Barnes highlights the prophet's dual metaphors: the lion, unafraid of overwhelming numbers, symbolizing God's fierce, protective purpose; and the birds, swiftly defending their young, illustrating Christ's active, sustaining care. Theologically, this underscores that true security stems not from human strength or alliances but from God's character—wise, sovereign, and actively involved in His people's salvation. Practically, this calls believers to reject worldly dependencies (political, economic, or technological) in crises, recognizing that God's protection operates through spiritual allegiance rather than temporal power. Crucially, Barnes connects these prophecies to Christ: the "Lion of Judah" (Revelation 5:5) embodies Christ's victory over enemies, while the bird imagery prefigures Christ's role as the sustainer of His church (John 15:16). For modern readers, this means trusting God's promises in times of conflict or uncertainty, avoiding the trap of seeking human solutions that ultimately fail, and living with confidence in Christ's protective care—knowing that His kingdom operates through spiritual strength, not military might. This chapter remains a vital reminder that true security and deliverance come exclusively from Yahweh, who acts as both the sovereign defender and the faithful Shepherd. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 32 presents a vivid contrast between spiritual desolation and divine restoration, centered on Christ's sovereign reign. He emphasizes that Christ, the ultimate righteous King, offers profound refuge and renewal—comparable to life-giving rivers in a dry land or the protective shade of a great rock—sustaining believers through life's trials. Henry underscores that true spiritual refreshment and protection come exclusively from Christ, who bears the storm's weight to shield His people. The commentary sharply contrasts the "vile person," whose deceitful actions cause harm to the vulnerable and corrupt the soul, with the "liberal" individual who cultivates genuine generosity and spiritual wisdom through Christ's grace. Henry connects this passage to Christ's coming work: the promised "pouring out of the Spirit from on high" (v.15) foretells the Holy Spirit's empowering presence, transforming barren lands into fertile fields where righteousness becomes tangible peace and security. Theologically, this reveals that Christ's kingdom actively dismantles spiritual desolation, making righteousness the foundation of eternal peace. Practically, believers are called to flee self-deception, actively cultivate Christ-like generosity, and trust His protective power—especially in times of spiritual drought—rather than succumbing to hypocrisy or worldly self-indulgence. Henry's insight that "the work of righteousness shall be peace" (v.17) challenges us to live righteously not for fleeting comfort but for the enduring peace only Christ's righteousness can secure, ensuring true rest in Him. (248 words)

John Calvin interprets Isaiah 32 as a prophetic vision of God's restoration of His people through righteous governance, emphasizing that true flourishing arises from divine leadership and moral renewal. He stresses that this passage depicts a king reigning in righteousness and princes ruling with judgment—not merely political order but a system where justice actively protects the vulnerable, as seen in the contrast between the "vile person" who spreads hypocrisy and injustice and the "liberal" who cultivates righteousness. Calvin connects this vision to Christ's coming kingdom, noting that while Hezekiah's reign served as a historical type of restoration, the text ultimately points to Christ as the ultimate king who will establish "judgment in the wilderness" and "righteousness in the fruitful field." Theologically, Calvin underscores that God's restoration requires both individual transformation (e.g., clear eyes, discerning hearts) and communal renewal, rejecting social structures that perpetuate inequality. Practically, this calls believers to actively resist hypocrisy and injustice, particularly in systems that exploit the poor, while cultivating generosity and truth in daily life. Christians are urged to sow for God's kingdom—like the "sowing beside all waters" in verse 20—by building communities of peace and justice that reflect Christ's coming reign, trusting that His righteousness will transform barren places into thriving, secure dwellings where true peace prevails. This vision anchors hope in Christ's redemptive work, reminding believers that God's restoration is both a present promise and a future reality. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 32 presents a dual perspective: a prophetic vision of righteous kingship fulfilled in Hezekiah's reign as a type, yet ultimately pointing to Christ. Poole argues that while the prophecy addresses Hezekiah's era—critiquing his tendency to rely on Egypt and his need for moral purification—it transcends historical context to reveal Christ's kingdom. The core theological insight lies in this typological lens: the "king" ruling in righteousness (v. 1) is not Hezekiah himself but Christ, whose coming fulfills the promise of a just government where princes act as protective "hiding places" from oppression (v. 3), offering relief like water in a desert. Poole emphasizes that true righteousness requires rulers with unclouded vision and hearing (v. 4), transforming the "rash" (those acting impulsively) and "stammerers" (those speaking obscurely) into people of clarity and honest speech. Crucially, this prophecy condemns the "vile person" who speaks ill and exploits the vulnerable (v. 6), revealing that Christ's kingdom eliminates hypocrisy and corruption. Practically, Poole urges leaders to purge unrighteous influence and cultivate genuine discernment, while believers should seek spiritual awakening—wherein Christ's Spirit replaces selfish motives with compassionate action. The commentary's enduring power lies in its Christ-centered application: the restoration promised in Isaiah 32 is not merely political but spiritual, where God's kingdom dismantles oppression and restores hope through Christ's sovereign rule, urging contemporary communities to embrace justice, transparency, and the transformative power of divine truth. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 32 emphasizes this chapter as a prophetic vision following the Assyrian threat, primarily envisioning the restoration under Hezekiah's righteous rule after Sennacherib's defeat. Theologically, Barnes highlights how the imagery—princes ruling in justice, a refuge from calamity like "rivers in a dry place," and the shadow of a great rock—paints a picture of divine restoration where God's sovereignty actively protects and sustains His people. This contrasts sharply with the preceding desolation and idolatry, underscoring that true peace and prosperity stem not from human power but from righteous administration aligned with God's character. Barnes notes the prophecy's focus on immediate restoration under Hezekiah, though it implicitly points forward to Christ, as the ultimate fulfillment of "princes ruling in judgment" and the "hiding place" from spiritual storms. Practically, this calls believers to reject temporary worldly security and luxury, recognizing that true refuge comes only through God's righteous rule. It challenges modern society to pursue justice and community over isolation, especially in times of crisis, and to cultivate the spiritual resilience that endures without the fleeting comfort of human systems. The chapter thus reveals a timeless truth: God's kingdom, once established through a faithful ruler like Hezekiah, finds its ultimate perfection in Christ, who brings the enduring "shadow of a great rock" of divine protection and righteousness that no storm can destroy.

Henry's commentary on Isaiah 33 reveals God's sovereign judgment on treacherous behavior while simultaneously offering profound hope to the righteous. The text vividly depicts the consequences of sin—those who exploit others and act deceitfully face divine retribution, as God's justice "pays sinners in their own coin" (v1-14), emphasizing that moral failure inevitably leads to self-inflicted destruction. Yet Henry pivots to a powerful promise: those who walk with integrity—rejecting corruption, refusing bribes, and actively choosing righteousness—find security in God's steadfast love. Crucially, Henry connects this passage to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of the "arm" described in verse 3: Jesus is the true source of salvation and strength, whose rising power (v10) delivers believers from the "devouring fire" of sin and judgment (v11-12). The "broad rivers and streams" in verse 21 symbolize the Holy Spirit's life-giving presence, while the assurance of healing and freedom from sickness (v24) points directly to Christ's redemptive work. Practically, Henry urges daily surrender—recognizing that without consistent reliance on God's strength, we are "undone" (v3). Believers must actively resist sin, trust Christ's provision, and find their identity not in human achievements but in His unchanging character. This commentary reveals that true security comes through Christ alone: His righteousness shields us from the wrath of God and ensures our eternal dwelling place in His presence, where "the inhabitant shall not say, I am sick" (v24). In this dual vision of judgment and grace, the Christian life is defined by daily dependence on Christ's finished work.

Calvin observes that Isaiah 33:1-24 delivers a powerful warning against exploitation and treachery, particularly targeting those who oppress others without facing consequences. He interprets the "woe" passage as a divine rebuke to conquerors like the Babylonians or Assyrians, emphasizing that persistent injustice will ultimately lead to reversal—those who plunder become plundered, and treacherous actions invite similar treachery. Theologically, Calvin highlights God's active role as both just judge and merciful Savior: He promises protection for the righteous who walk uprightly, shunning corruption and violence, while simultaneously condemning the wicked whose actions cause societal collapse. This passage reveals a core tension in God's character—justice met with compassion. Practically, believers are called to actively reject exploitation in their relationships, cultivate integrity in speech and conduct, and trust God's sovereignty rather than succumbing to fear or despair. Crucially, Calvin connects this text to Christ's fulfillment: the "spoiling" described here points to Christ's victory over sin and death, where His sacrificial death resolves the consequences of human treachery, and His kingdom brings true peace and security—free from the chaos of rebellion. Today's believers, therefore, find hope in Christ's promise that the "glorious LORD" will establish a place of enduring rest for His people, where righteousness replaces oppression and the city of God becomes a sanctuary beyond destruction.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 33 emphasizes a profound theological contrast between divine judgment and covenantal security, framed through the lens of historical events like Sennacherib's invasion of Judah. Poole interprets the "woe" passage as a warning to those who act treacherously while exploiting others—like Sennacherib who plundered Judah but remained unopposed—highlighting God's reversal of such power: when the oppressor ceases their actions, they themselves become vulnerable. This passage underscores that true security for the righteous comes not from human strength but from God's active presence, as seen in the "arm of God" promise where divine help is continually available, especially in moments of crisis. Poole connects this to the church's need for steadfast trust in God's judgment against enemies, noting how the "earth mourneth" and nations fall under divine wrath, yet Zion is filled with righteousness. Theologically, this reveals God's sovereign authority over chaos and the promise that faithful obedience secures divine protection. Practically, believers are called to cease their own destructive patterns—whether in sin, deception, or unfaithfulness—and actively seek God's guidance, recognizing that His justice against adversaries is part of His redemptive plan. Christologically, Poole's interpretation finds its ultimate fulfillment in Jesus as the "arm of God" who defeats all enemies through His death and resurrection, transforming divine judgment into salvation. This commentary thus urges contemporary readers to embrace Christ's victory, trusting that God's reversal of power in judgment brings restoration and peace, rather than self-reliance or treacherous actions. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 33 presents this chapter as a distinct comfort prophecy responding to the Assyrian threat under Sennacherib, specifically reassuring the Jews that divine protection would secure Jerusalem despite overwhelming invasion. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes God's sovereign intervention as the central theme: the chapter contrasts the treacherous Assyrians (v1), who plundered without provocation, with the righteous Jews who find security in Yahweh's faithfulness (v15-19). This stark dichotomy reveals that true safety comes not from human alliances or wealth (as seen in Hezekiah's failed silver and gold offering, v7) but from trusting God's active care in crises. Practically, it calls believers to avoid the Assyrian pattern of deceptive power—prioritizing genuine relationship over temporary concessions—and to maintain steadfast hope when threats loom, recognizing that divine protection operates through faithfulness rather than human strength. Crucially, Barnes connects this prophecy to Christ: the "arm" God promises as deliverance (v2) prefigures Christ as the ultimate protector and fulfillment of divine promises, whose victory over enemies (v20-24) resolves the ancient fear of destruction. This chapter thus offers enduring hope—showing that God's justice and mercy actively secure His people, even in the face of seemingly insurmountable chaos, pointing ultimately to Christ as the one who defeats all opposition through the power of the Holy Spirit. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 34 presents a vivid prophecy of divine judgment against nations opposed to God's church, emphasizing its righteousness and ultimate purpose. He interprets this chapter as a solemn warning of the Lord's wrath against all who resist His people, particularly the Edomites symbolizing the forces of antichrist and persistent opposition to Christ's kingdom. The imagery of desolation—land turned to pitch, cities becoming wastelands for wild animals—highlights how sin's consequences transform fertile places into eternal desolation. Crucially, Henry connects this passage to Christ's fulfillment: the "sword of the Lord" described here foreshadows Christ's sacrificial work and divine judgment against evil, yet it ultimately delivers the church from enemies. The prophecy underscores that God's judgment is not arbitrary but a necessary recompense for sin, ensuring the church's preservation while condemning the opposition forever. Theologically, Henry stresses that this judgment is part of God's sovereign plan to vindicate His people and restore righteousness, with Christ's victory over sin and death being the ultimate resolution. Practically, believers are called to patient trust in God's timing, avoiding premature judgment of others or the church, and focusing on Christ's mercy rather than earthly conflicts. This passage challenges us to seek God's kingdom actively, knowing that while present judgments are harsh, Christ's return will bring final restoration and eternal peace to His people.

John Calvin interprets Isaiah 34 as a vivid, present-focused prophecy of God's impending judgment against nations that have oppressed His people, particularly Edom, serving as a stark warning to all who resist divine authority. He emphasizes that this passage describes not distant future events but an immediate divine response to human rebellion, where the "indignation of the LORD" targets hostile nations whose armies are utterly destroyed—symbolizing the futility of human pride and the certainty of God's sovereignty. Calvin notes the profound imagery: the land transformed into burning pitch, wild animals claiming the desolate territory, and the complete absence of human habitation, illustrating a state of utter desolation where God's justice eliminates all opposition. Theologically, Calvin connects this passage to the core theme of divine retribution for sin, revealing that God's judgment is not arbitrary but a necessary consequence of human wickedness. Crucially, Calvin links this judgment to Christ's ultimate work: the "sacrifice in Bozrah" (a place near Edom) points directly to Christ's atoning death, where the blood of the Lamb purifies the land and redeems humanity from the judgment described. Practically, this commentary urges believers to reject the cycle of vengeance and hostility, actively seeking reconciliation with neighbors and enemies, recognizing that true peace flows from Christ's finished work rather than human retaliation. Calvin's insight reminds Christians that while God disciplines the unrepentent, His ultimate purpose is restoration through Christ, calling believers to live in hope of His redemptive kingdom rather than fear of divine wrath. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 34 presents a vivid portrayal of God's final judgment against all earthly enemies, emphasizing divine sovereignty and the inevitable desolation of rebellion. Theologically, Poole interprets this passage as God's decisive wrath against nations that oppose His people, where the land becomes utterly desolate and the heavens themselves undergo upheaval—symbolizing the dissolution of all false systems and the temporary dissolution of creation's order. This imagery, he argues, underscores humanity's fleeting nature (comparing people to "mushrooms" in Genesis 3:19) and the certainty of divine retribution for unrepentant opposition. Crucially, Poole connects this eschatological scene to Christ's fulfillment: the "sword bathed in heaven" (Isaiah 34:5) points to Christ's blood poured out for the church, while the "heavens rolled like a scroll" (Isaiah 34:4) anticipates Christ's return and the renewal of all things in the New Heavens and New Earth (Revelation 21). Practically, this commentary calls for universal repentance—nations must heed God's warning before being consumed by His judgment, as the desolation of Edom (a type for all enemies) serves as a stark reminder of the consequences of pride and rebellion. It challenges believers to live with humility, recognizing their temporary existence and the ultimate triumph of Christ's kingdom over all opposition, thereby urging active participation in the church's mission of reconciliation rather than passive fear. Poole's insights thus bridge Old Testament prophecy with the cross and resurrection, showing how Christ's victory dismantles the powers of sin and death that Isaiah foretold would be utterly destroyed. (248 words)

Barnes interprets Isaiah 34 as a dual prophecy culminating in Christ's fulfillment, emphasizing God's sovereign judgment on enemies followed by Messianic restoration. The chapter presents a sweeping condemnation of all Israel's foes—particularly Edom, symbolizing persistent hostility—where God's wrath transforms the land into a desolate wilderness overrun by wild beasts, a stark image of total destruction. Theologically, this underscores God's absolute authority over nations and His purpose to purify the earth through final judgment before the kingdom of peace arrives. Barnes connects Edom's fate to the broader pattern of God's deliverance from historical adversaries (like Assyria and Babylon), revealing that Christ's coming resolves this cycle of conflict by achieving perfect victory over sin and death. Practically, believers are called to view present conflicts through this lens: God's justice is not arbitrary but part of His redemptive plan, urging trust in His ultimate triumph rather than fear of current struggles. The prophecy's hopeful conclusion—where the "wilderness blossoms" and the "ransomed return to Zion with songs"—points directly to the New Jerusalem, where Christ establishes His eternal kingdom. This promises profound spiritual renewal for the redeemed, freeing them from the shadow of enemy oppression. Thus, the chapter challenges believers to find hope in Christ's finished work, knowing that God's judgment on evil precedes the restoration of all things under His sovereign reign, offering enduring joy in the midst of present trials. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 35 presents a profound vision of spiritual renewal through Christ, where the "wilderness" symbolizes the desolate state of the soul before conversion. He interprets the chapter as a promise of God's active work: the spiritually barren will blossom with joy, the blind see, the deaf hear, and the lame leap, all enabled by the coming of the Messiah. Theologically, Henry emphasizes that this restoration is not merely future hope but a present reality through Christ—the "wilderness" becomes a "pool" where God's grace flows, revealing that the true "way of holiness" is accessible, safe, and marked by the presence of the Redeemer. Christ is the fulfillment of this prophecy: He brings both judgment on sin and restoration, becoming the "way" that the lame leap and the dumb sing. Practically, Henry urges believers to strengthen themselves in faith, especially for the weak and fearful, trusting Christ's promise to come and save. This calls for active participation in spiritual renewal—seeking God's light, living in the "way" where the redeemed walk free from oppression, and finding enduring joy in Christ rather than worldly sorrows. The commentary concludes that true hope lies not in abstract promises but in Christ's completed work, urging believers to walk in holiness with confidence, knowing that sorrow and sighing will flee as the "ransomed" return to Zion with everlasting joy. This vision anchors faith in the sufficiency of Christ's redemption for present renewal and eternal rest. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 35 as a profound promise of divine restoration following God's judgment, where the "wilderness" symbolizes spiritual desolation and the "desert" represents the broken, barren condition of humanity. He emphasizes that this renewal is not merely a future Jewish restoration but a universal promise fulfilled through Christ's kingdom—the "day of renovation and restoration" (Acts 3:21). Theologically, Calvin stresses that God's prior judgment purges the world's sinfulness, making it receptive to His grace, and that Christ alone effectuates this renewal, as He "renews everything and restores it to proper order." The imagery of the healed blind, deaf, lame, and silent—along with the flourishing land—points to Christ's redemptive power dismantling spiritual death and bringing life to the broken. Practically, Calvin urges believers to find hope in Christ's present work: the "way of holiness" calls for active obedience, while the promise of "everlasting joy" encourages perseverance in suffering. This passage teaches that true renewal comes not through human effort but through Christ's coming vengeance on sin and His gracious salvation, transforming the desolate into a place of joy. Believers are thus to walk in humility, trusting Christ's promised restoration, which delivers the "ransomed" from despair and replaces sorrow with "songs of joy." Calvin's insight underscores that Christ's kingdom is the sole source of this renewal, enabling the church to live as a flourishing community where the broken find healing and the unclean are cleansed by the Lord's presence. (248 words)

Poole interprets Isaiah 35 as a profound messianic prophecy revealing Christ's redemptive kingdom, emphasizing that God's promised restoration of His people fulfills the wilderness imagery of spiritual desolation. The "wilderness" symbolizes Israel's barren state under enemy oppression, now transformed into a flourishing kingdom where the weak are strengthened (v3-4), the blind see, and the lame leap—physical and spiritual healing signifying Christ's power to conquer sin and death. Poole stresses that this vision is not merely historical but explicitly Christ-centered: the "lions" represent Satan's destructive power, defeated by Christ's victory; the "ransomed" (v10) are believers redeemed from spiritual bondage; and the "way of holiness" (v8) reflects the Church's path under Christ's guidance. Theologically, Poole connects this prophecy to the New Covenant, where Christ's presence replaces the law's harshness, creating a safe, joyful community where sorrow fades. Practically, Christians are called to embody this hope by actively comforting the vulnerable (v3), trusting Christ's restoration in their spiritual dryness (v5-6), and walking in the "way of holiness" with humility and purpose. This commentary underscores that Christ's kingdom transforms desolation into abundance, urging believers to find their identity in His victory rather than worldly struggles, fostering joy through the assurance of redemption. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 35 reveals this chapter as a profound gospel prophecy, not merely a future restoration but a vivid description of Christ's present reign. Barnes emphasizes that the "wilderness" symbolizes spiritual desolation—every state of moral barrenness—while the "blossoming as the rose" signifies divine transformation, where Christ's kingdom brings life to what was dead. The chapter explicitly connects to Christ through its promises: the healing of the blind, deaf, and lame directly parallels Jesus' ministry, the universal "glory of the Lord" points to the New Covenant community, and the destruction of enemies signifies Christ's victory over sin and death. Theologically, Barnes underscores that this vision transcends mere national redemption; it depicts a universal restoration where God's kingdom embraces all nations, accessible through faith alone—a "way for the pure" requiring spiritual renewal. Practically, believers today navigate their own "wildernesses" of doubt or isolation, finding hope in Christ's promise that the Spirit will awaken joy and healing. This passage urges active compassion—strengthening the weak and confirming the feeble—by modeling Christ's own ministry of restoration. For modern readers, it calls for humility in recognizing spiritual desolation and active participation in God's work, where Christ's transformative power turns barren places into flourishing communities of hope, reminding us that true joy flows from encountering the risen Lord, not from worldly achievements. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 36 illuminates a pivotal moment where Assyrian military pressure confronts Judah's faith. Rabshakeh's inflammatory speech to Hezekiah's officials reveals the profound theological tension: the king's desperate reliance on Egypt (a "broken reed") versus the covenantal trust in the living God. Henry emphasizes that Rabshakeh's mockery—questioning Hezekiah's faith and invoking the futility of other nations' gods—serves as a stark warning against idolatry and misplaced hope. Theologically, this passage underscores God's sovereignty over human power struggles, demonstrating that true security stems not from military alliances or false deities but from divine covenant faithfulness. Practically, Henry urges believers to critically examine their sources of trust during crises, rejecting temporary solutions that promise deliverance without divine alignment. Crucially, this chapter points to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of Isaiah's promise. Just as Rabshakeh's threats fail because Judah's trust in God (not Egypt) is genuine, Christ—the "true staff" that never breaks—overcomes all human weakness and enemy power. His resurrection validates God's covenantal promises, offering a permanent refuge that no Assyrian army, political alliance, or false god can destroy. Thus, the chapter's enduring lesson is that authentic faith in the living God, not human resources, secures deliverance and transforms fear into confident hope in Christ's victory. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 36 emphasizes the critical tension between misplaced trust and divine reliance during the Assyrian siege of Jerusalem. Calvin interprets Rabshakeh's challenge to Hezekiah as a profound theological test, revealing how the people risked their salvation by clinging to Egypt—a symbol of false security—rather than the living God who had previously protected Israel. Calvin stresses that true faith is not merely intellectual assent but active obedience, as Hezekiah's delegation of the city's fate to divine promise (not human alliances) demonstrated the nation's spiritual alignment. Theologically, Calvin connects this event to the universal human tendency to seek refuge in temporal powers, highlighting that idolatry manifests not only in worship of false gods but in misplaced trust in political or military strength. Practically, Calvin urges believers to avoid the modern equivalent of Egypt—relying on human systems, fleeting alliances, or self-sufficiency—instead anchoring their hope in God's promises. This has direct application for contemporary Christians facing crises: when external threats arise, they must reject the "broken reed" of human confidence and embrace the "unshakable staff" of Christ's victory. Crucially, Calvin links Isaiah's prophecy to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise. The Assyrian threat, which the text foretells would be overcome through divine intervention, prefigures Christ's triumph over sin and death—the true defender who secures eternal refuge. Thus, Calvin's commentary reveals that the city's deliverance is not merely political but theological: it points to Christ as the only one who can ultimately "deliver Jerusalem out of the hand of the king of Assyria," symbolizing the victory over all enemies through faith in the Messiah. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 36 illuminates the Assyrian siege of Jerusalem as a profound theological test of faith. He emphasizes Rabshakeh's deliberate strategy to undermine Hezekiah's trust in the Lord by mocking the futility of relying on Egypt (a "broken reed" that pierces the hand) and questioning the efficacy of ancient gods in delivering Judah from Assyrian power. Poole highlights how the Assyrian king's rhetorical challenge—asking if any god besides the LORD had delivered land from his grasp—exposes the human tendency to seek deliverance in temporary, earthly powers rather than covenantal faith. This narrative reveals a critical theological insight: true security stems not from political alliances or human strength but from the sovereign promise of the Living God, who transcends temporal threats. Crucially, Poole connects this historical crisis to Christ's ultimate victory. Just as the Assyrian invasion threatened Jerusalem's existence, sin and the adversary's power threaten humanity's salvation; yet the same God who spoke through Isaiah's prophecy would be fulfilled in Jesus—whose death and resurrection conquer the "broken reed" of human weakness and the enemy's dominion. Practically, believers are called to reject false security (like Egypt or worldly systems), maintain unshakable trust in Christ alone, and understand that God's deliverance is active and personal, not conditional on human performance. This passage urges faithful communities to resist despair in persecution, recognizing that the LORD's promises—like the covenantal faithfulness of Hezekiah—point decisively to the risen Christ as the true and sufficient deliverer. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 36 emphasizes the chapter's historical significance as the record of Sennacherib's military defeat and the subsequent recovery of Hezekiah, framing it within Isaiah's prophetic narrative that culminates in divine sovereignty over Israel's crisis. Theologically, Barnes underscores how this event demonstrates God's active protection—Sennacherib's army, a formidable threat, was destroyed by divine intervention despite his immense power, revealing that true security stems not from human strength but from God's covenant faithfulness. This historical account serves as a profound foreshadowing of Christ's ultimate victory over sin and death, where the "destruction" of the enemy (Sennacherib representing worldly power and rebellion) finds its fulfillment in Christ's resurrection. Practically, the chapter warns against the arrogance of Hezekiah's display of treasures to Babylonian envoys, illustrating the danger of self-reliance and misplaced confidence in temporal wealth during spiritual trials. It calls for humility, trust in God's provision during crises, and gratitude for divine deliverance—lessons vital for modern believers facing personal or communal threats. Barnes also addresses historical debates about the chapter's authorship, concluding it was likely composed by Isaiah himself to provide clear prophetic context, reinforcing that God's revelation is both timely and purposeful. This narrative thus challenges readers to seek God's protection in their own struggles, recognizing that Christ's victory—the ultimate "recovery" from spiritual death—remains the only true foundation for lasting security and hope. (248 words)

Matthew Henry emphasizes that Isaiah 37 vividly illustrates God's sovereign protection over His covenant people during acute spiritual and political crises. When Hezekiah faced Assyrian aggression through Rabshakeh's threats, his immediate response—renting clothes, covering himself in sackcloth, and seeking God's presence—demonstrates profound humility and reliance on divine authority rather than human strength. Henry highlights how Isaiah's prophecy directly confronts Assyrian arrogance by declaring their defeat through God's active intervention: the angel smiting 185,000 Assyrians and ensuring their retreat without entering Jerusalem. Theologically, this reveals God's character as the ultimate defender of His chosen ones, contrasting human pride (Sennacherib's boasts) with divine humility (Isaiah's role as God's servant). Critically, the promise that "the remnant that is escaped of the house of Judah shall again take root downward" points to Christ's future restoration of the church, where the "remnant" becomes the faithful community in Christ. Practically, this chapter encourages believers to avoid idolatrous security in worldly power, instead cultivating prayerful dependence when trials arise. Henry stresses that true safety comes from trusting God's covenant promises—specifically, His commitment to David's lineage (fulfilled in Christ)—not temporary political alliances. The Assyrian defeat foreshadows Christ's ultimate victory over sin and death, where the "zeal of the LORD" (Isaiah 37:32) becomes the church's spiritual renewal. Thus, believers are called to maintain faith in God's sovereignty during adversity, recognizing that His protection ensures His kingdom endures, ultimately pointing to Christ's victory as the only lasting hope. (248 words)

Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 37 emphasizes the profound theological contrast between human arrogance and divine sovereignty, particularly through Hezekiah's response to the Assyrian threat. When Hezekiah, facing Sennacherib's military aggression, humbly tore his garments and wore sackcloth, Calvin highlights this as a critical act of repentance demonstrating that true security stems not from political might but from trusting God's covenant promises. Calvin interprets Isaiah's prophecy that Sennacherib would "fall by the sword in his own land" (v7) not as mere military defeat but as a divine judgment against Assyria's idolatrous claims—reiterating that God's power transcends human systems. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ by noting how Isaiah's declaration that the "virgin daughter of Zion" mocked Sennacherib (v22) prefigures the true Messiah, whose divine origin and ultimate victory over all earthly powers are foundational to Christian hope. Theologically, Calvin stresses that God is the "alone God" who "made heaven and earth" (v16), rejecting Assyrian boasts about their "wood and stone" idols (v19) to affirm His eternal, transcendent nature. Practically, Calvin urges believers to emulate Hezekiah's humility: when trials arise, we must actively repent, seek God's presence, and reject false assurances of human strength. This passage teaches that true faith involves recognizing God's sovereignty in all circumstances—whether facing military threats or personal struggles—and trusting His promises to uphold His people, just as He delivered Judah through Isaiah's intercession. For modern readers, it calls for vigilant dependence on Christ, who is the ultimate "virgin" of God's promise and the one who "will bring it to pass" (v26) for the benefit of all nations.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 37 emphasizes the profound theological contrast between human arrogance and divine sovereignty, particularly through Hezekiah's response to Sennacherib's threat. Poole highlights how Hezekiah's immediate mourning, sackcloth covering, and fervent prayer demonstrate genuine repentance and reliance on God rather than human strength, a crucial lesson for believers facing opposition. The chapter reveals God's active protection—through the angelic slaughter of Assyrians and the eventual downfall of Sennacherib—affirming that even the most powerful nations are subject to divine judgment. Poole underscores the theological insight that God's covenant faithfulness to Israel (through David) transcends human threats, as seen in Isaiah's declaration that the city will be defended "for my servant David's sake." This passage foreshadows Christ's ultimate victory: the "virgin" (a prefiguration of Christ) who would defeat the enemy, just as God's power over Assyria prefigures Christ's triumph over sin and death. Practically, believers are called to emulate Hezekiah's posture of humility and prayer when confronted with worldly crises, avoiding reliance on human solutions or temporal power. Poole stresses that God's sovereignty ensures that His people endure through His provision, not human strength—encouraging faithful trust even in seemingly impossible situations, knowing Christ's victory guarantees ultimate deliverance and restoration. This historical narrative, therefore, serves as a timeless reminder of God's active care and the promise of His kingdom.

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 37 reveals a pivotal moment where divine sovereignty directly intervenes in human crises. When King Hezekiah, facing Assyrian threat, humbly sought Isaiah's counsel after his temple distress, the prophet declared God's assurance: the Assyrian army would be routed and Sennacherib himself destroyed. This chapter demonstrates profound theological insight—God's protection operates through human humility and faithful petition, not military might. Hezekiah's response—rent clothes, sackcloth, temple prayer—shows that true crisis resolution begins with acknowledging divine authority amidst oppression. Barnes emphasizes the "childbirth" metaphor for Jerusalem's precarious state, illustrating how God's deliverance comes when human strength fails. Crucially, this passage foreshadows Christ's ultimate victory over all enemies; just as Isaiah's promise ensures Assyrian defeat through divine judgment, Christ's resurrection triumphs over sin and death. Practically, believers today must recognize that overwhelming threats—whether spiritual, social, or existential—require similar humility: seeking God's counsel, mourning sin, and trusting His providence rather than human strategies. When crises overwhelm, the response modeled here—profound spiritual surrender and prayer—reminds us that God's power, not our strength, secures victory for His people. This historical narrative thus remains a timeless call to trust divine promises amid chaos. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 38 reveals a profound theological narrative of divine mercy in crisis. Hezekiah's life-threatening illness becomes the stage for a pivotal encounter where the prophet Isaiah delivers God's promise of fifteen additional years and deliverance from Assyrian threat, accompanied by the miraculous retrogression of the sun's shadow—a sign affirming God's sovereign power and faithfulness. Henry emphasizes that this story transcends physical healing to expose a deeper truth: God's promises in sickness, when received through repentant prayer, assure believers of both present provision and eternal security. Theologically, Henry connects Hezekiah's lament—where he cries, "I shall not see the LORD in the land of the living"—to the human condition of spiritual mortality, yet God's response demonstrates that true life flows from reconciliation with Him, not merely temporal survival.
