Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 49 presents this chapter as a profound Christ-centered prophecy, revealing God's sovereign plan for redemption through Jesus Christ. Poole emphasizes that Isaiah speaks of Christ being called from eternity—selected and sanctified in the womb—before his mission began, establishing his divine purpose from the very beginning. The text reveals Christ's dual role: initially sent to Israel (which rejected him), yet ultimately designated as "a light to the Gentiles" to bring salvation to the ends of the earth. Poole interprets key metaphors like Christ's "sharp sword" (His Word's power to pierce hearts and transform lives) and being "hid in the shadow of his hand" (divine protection through suffering) as illustrating Christ's unique identity as both the suffering servant and victorious redeemer. Theologically, Poole underscores that Christ's mission succeeds despite initial failure with Israel, demonstrating God's sovereignty in glorifying His servant through the Gentiles—a crucial truth for understanding the universal scope of the Gospel. Practically, this commentary encourages believers to embrace their role as living lights in a dark world, empowered by Christ's victory. Just as Christ's suffering ministry preceded His universal redemption, modern Christians are called to share the Gospel with courage and compassion, especially where rejection occurs, trusting that God's promise of ultimate glory will be fulfilled through Christ's work. Poole's insight—that Christ's mission to the Gentiles is the true fulfillment of Isaiah's vision—reminds us that our purpose is not merely to be faithful but to be instruments of God's light, transforming hearts and nations through the same powerful, sacrificial love that redeemed us. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that Isaiah 49 directly and personally addresses the Messiah, rejecting earlier interpretations that confined the chapter to the Jewish people, the prophet, or collective prophets. He argues that the chapter's language, consistent personal pronouns, and prophetic vision clearly point to Christ as the singular subject—the rejected Jewish servant who becomes the light to Gentiles and savior for the ends of the earth. Theologically, this reveals Christ's dual identity: the rejected anointed one whose mission transcends ethnic boundaries, fulfilling the promise that God would establish him as a mediator for universal salvation (Isaiah 49:6). Barnes underscores how Christ's ultimate success—gathering Israel, liberating the oppressed, and bringing global redemption—rests on divine promise, not human effort, highlighting God's sovereignty over historical outcomes. Practically, this calls believers to embrace Christ's mission despite cultural rejection, fostering courage in sharing the gospel across divides. It also encourages trust in God's faithfulness to Christ's work, assuring that even when the church faces persecution or seems insignificant, God's purpose of reconciling nations through Christ will prevail, motivating believers to be agents of hope in a fractured world. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 50 presents a profound Christ-centered interpretation of the prophet's words, revealing God's response to the Jewish people's suffering in Babylon. Henry emphasizes that the chapter addresses complaints from those who felt God had abandoned them, explaining that their afflictions stemmed directly from their sin, particularly idolatry and rejection of the covenant. Crucially, Henry connects this passage to Christ's fulfillment: the "servant" described—God's anointed one who speaks with divine authority (50:4) and suffers without rebellion (50:5-6)—is explicitly identified as Jesus. Christ's submission to the cross, where he "gave his back to the smiters" (50:6), demonstrates his obedience to God's will, while his unwavering confidence in God's help (50:7-9) points to his victory over accusation and death. Theologically, Henry underscores that Christ's suffering was both a divine act of atonement and a human response to sin, fulfilling the covenant promise. Practically, this commentary urges believers to trust Christ's victory rather than their own strength or worldly comforts. In darkness and persecution, as the text warns, true disciples must "walk in the light of your fire" (50:11) by relying on Christ's righteousness, not self-reliance or temporary pleasures. Henry's insight—that a godly person's path may be dark but their end is peace—challenges modern readers to find lasting hope not in fleeting human achievements but in Christ's unchanging faithfulness, where suffering serves the purpose of ultimate redemption and eternal light. (248 words)

Calvin meticulously interprets Isaiah 50:1-11 as a profound metaphor revealing the covenant relationship between God and His people, rejecting Jewish claims that God had wrongfully divorced them. He argues that the "bill of divorcement" and "creditor" metaphors expose the Jews' self-deception—they insisted God had abandoned them through unjust divorce, yet Calvin insists the real cause was their own sin, which severed their covenant bond. This "divorce" was not God's doing but a consequence of their transgressions, where they became "sold" by their own iniquity, much like debtors who surrender themselves to sin's bondage. Theologically, Calvin emphasizes that God remains the faithful husband who does not initiate the breach but holds the people accountable for their choices. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ's silent suffering: the "one who is not ashamed" (v7) directly foreshadows Jesus enduring humiliation without retaliatory anger, while the "tongue of the learned" (v4) prefigures Christ's authoritative teaching and the Spirit's guidance. Practically, Calvin urges believers to resist shame and oppression by trusting Christ's strength—just as the prophet stood firm despite physical abuse—reminding them that true freedom comes through Christ, not self-justification. This commentary thus anchors modern Christians in the reality that suffering and divine discipline arise from personal failure, not God's abandonment, while Christ's victory over sin provides the ultimate foundation for enduring trials without shame. (247 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 50 presents a profound theological critique of Jewish self-blame during the Babylonian exile, emphasizing that God's apparent abandonment of Israel stemmed solely from their own iniquities. Poole interprets the "bill of divorcement" and "creditors" metaphors as divine rebukes against the Jews' tendency to accuse God for their suffering while ignoring their role as the cause—comparing their spiritual condition to selling themselves through sin. The chapter vividly demonstrates God's sovereign power through natural phenomena (drying seas, blackening skies), asserting that divine justice and mercy remain unchallenged. Crucially, Poole argues that Isaiah 50:4—where God grants the prophet "the tongue of the learned" to comfort the weary—directly points to Christ as its fulfillment. Here, Jesus embodies the "tongue of the learned," speaking with divine authority to heal spiritual desolation, mirroring his ministry of rest and restoration (Matthew 11:28). Theologically, this underscores that human rebellion justifies divine judgment, yet God's redemptive power remains active through Christ. Practically, this commentary challenges believers to avoid shifting blame for suffering onto God while cultivating humility in accountability. It calls for active trust in Christ's finished work rather than self-reliance, urging spiritual renewal through Christ's compassionate words that address the weary and broken—providing hope that divine intervention continues even amid apparent abandonment.

Barnes' commentary on Isaiah 50 presents a dual theological framework for understanding the chapter's purpose and significance. The initial verses (1-3) address the Jewish exile in Babylon by refuting the claim that God's punishment was arbitrary or capricious. God explicitly states that the people had sold themselves through sin, becoming "divorced" from Him—using the marriage metaphor to emphasize covenant fidelity—while His power remained unshaken, capable of both devastating judgment and deliverance. This section underscores that suffering stems from moral accountability, not divine weakness or injustice. The second part (4-11), Barnes argues, is most profoundly fulfilled in Christ, not the prophet himself or a contemporary figure. The speaker who endures opposition with meek submission, trusts God alone, and warns the unrepentent finds its ultimate identity in the Suffering Servant of Isaiah 53. This Christ-centered interpretation reveals the Messiah as the obedient servant who voluntarily endured humiliation and rejection—spitting, scolding, and suffering—while maintaining unwavering trust in God's sovereignty. Theologically, this affirms God's righteous judgment rooted in covenant faithfulness and the necessity of Christ's self-sacrificial obedience. Practically, believers are called to reject self-reliance in suffering, cultivate meek submission to God's will, and heed Christ's warning against spiritual complacency. Barnes' insight that this passage directly points to Jesus' fulfillment (as confirmed by Luke 18:32) offers profound hope: our suffering, when rooted in Christ's example, becomes part of His redemptive work, urging us to trust God's purpose even in opposition and to seek His kingdom rather than our own comfort. (282 words)

Henry observes that Isaiah 51 offers profound comfort to the redeemed by framing God's sovereignty over suffering and restoration. The passage emphasizes that true believers, shaped in sin but hewn from the "rock" (Christ) and dug from the "hole of the pit" (sin), find their identity in divine grace rather than their own righteousness. Theologically, Henry highlights the contrast between transient earthly woes—like the "fury of the oppressor" and "cup of trembling"—and Christ's eternal salvation, which remains "for ever" and "from generation to generation." This divine permanence counters the fear of death and destruction, as the "arms" of God (Christ) ultimately judge the nations and secure deliverance for the redeemed. Practically, Henry urges believers to cultivate humility before God's mercy, recognizing their need for Christ's atonement, while trusting His promises in trials. The commentary's Christ connection is central: Isaiah 51's "arm" that "cuts Rahab" and "dries the sea" directly points to Christ's power over sin and death, fulfilled through the cross and resurrection. This promise assures believers that God's comfort—releasing them from the "cup of trembling" and securing their "everlasting joy"—is not conditional on human effort but rooted in Christ's victory. Thus, the passage calls for active hope: when distress arises, believers should "awake" to Christ's sustaining power, knowing their security lies not in their own strength but in God's unchanging covenant. This theological foundation transforms suffering into an opportunity for deeper reliance on Christ, fostering resilience and joyful perseverance in a world of turmoil. (248 words)

Calvin emphasizes that Isaiah 51 serves as a profound exhortation to the remnant of God's people enduring exile, urging them to fix their hope not in their diminished numbers but in the eternal covenant established through Abraham. He interprets the "rock whence ye are hewn" as Christ—God's unshakeable foundation of salvation—while the "hole of the pit" symbolizes the depth of human sinfulness that Christ alone redeems. Calvin highlights how God's promise to restore Zion (turning desolation into Eden) finds its ultimate fulfillment in Christ, who dries the sea and opens pathways for the redeemed, directly connecting the passage's imagery to Jesus' divine power and sacrificial mission. Theologically, Calvin stresses that Christ's victory over despair is secured by his role as the "cup of trembling" (the cup of God's wrath), which he bears to secure salvation for his people. Practically, this commentary calls believers to anchor their hope in Christ's eternal promises rather than temporary circumstances, especially during times of persecution or spiritual desolation. Calvin urges active trust in God's sustaining hand, as the "redeemed" will return to Zion with joy, a vision fulfilled through Christ's resurrection. For modern readers, this means embracing the reality that suffering is temporary while Christ's victory—where the "fury of the oppressor" is overcome—provides unshakeable hope, transforming present struggles into opportunities to participate in God's redemptive work through faith in the risen Lord. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 51 emphasizes a Christ-centered call to the faithful amidst divine restoration. He interprets the "rock whence ye are hewn" and "hole of the pit" as profound metaphors for God's miraculous intervention, tracing Abraham's singular call and blessing—where God transformed impossible barrenness into abundant life—to reveal Christ's role as the ultimate fulfillment of covenant promises. Poole connects this to the New Testament, noting that just as God raised Abraham from spiritual desolation, Christ's incarnation and work provide salvation for those who seek Him, transforming spiritual barrenness into eternal life. The chapter's promise of Zion's restoration—turning desolation into Eden-like flourishing—points to Christ's redemptive work, where His "righteousness" (salvation) and "arms" (divine authority) establish a new covenant order that transcends temporary earthly structures. Practically, Poole urges believers to anchor themselves in Christ's eternal promises during trials, recognizing that God's comfort and judgment are active in the present. In a world of fleeting stability, the faithful should "lift up their eyes" to Christ—the unchanging Rock who transforms desolation into hope—avoiding worldly anxieties and trusting His salvation that outlives temporal decay. This commentary thus bridges ancient prophecy and modern faith, showing how Christ's work fulfills Isaiah's vision of a restored community grounded in divine grace, not human effort, calling believers to persevere in righteousness despite present affliction. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that Isaiah 51 functions as a cohesive comfort message for exiled Jews in Babylon, intricately linked to the subsequent Messianic prophecies in Isaiah 52:13-53:12. The chapter addresses a community despondent over their captivity, urging them to fix their eyes on God as their unshakeable foundation—specifically, the "rock whence ye are hewn," symbolizing Abraham, the humble ancestor God sovereignly called and blessed to become a nation. Theologically, Barnes highlights God's promise that His salvation is eternally secure ("more permanent than the heavens"), contrasting the temporary nature of human systems with divine permanence. Crucially, this passage foreshadows Christ as the ultimate "rock" and fulfillment of the promise; the Messiah, who would be "hewn" from the people yet become the true foundation of salvation, is implicitly prepared here for the coming suffering and redemption detailed later in the chapter. Practically, this calls believers to anchor their hope in God's character rather than circumstances, especially when facing oppression or exile—remembering that God's past deliverance (like parting the Red Sea) demonstrates His power to liberate. The text assures that enemies will be consumed like moth-eaten cloth, offering profound comfort for current struggles. For modern readers, this means trusting God's eternal promises in times of weakness, recognizing Christ's role as the true rock of faith, and finding enduring hope in His sovereignty that transcends present suffering.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 52 emphasizes the gospel's call to liberation and the profound Christ-centered significance of this chapter. He observes that the passage vividly depicts Zion awakening from spiritual bondage, where the "uncircumcised and unclean" are no longer permitted to enter—a metaphor for sin's exclusion from God's presence. Henry stresses that this liberation is secured by Christ's sacrificial blood, not human effort or wealth, highlighting the free grace that liberates the weary from sin's weight. Theologically, Henry connects this to Christ's dual role as both the suffering servant (Isaiah 52:13-15) who bore the curse of sin and the reigning king who brings salvation to His people. Practical applications emerge strongly: believers are called to shed the dust of fear and doubt, trusting Christ's protection rather than rushing in haste. Henry insists that true freedom involves holiness—living clean and blameless as vessels for God's purpose—while recognizing that Christ's victory over sin and death ensures stability for those who follow Him. This commentary underscores that the gospel's promise of redemption, proclaimed by faithful servants, brings joy to the broken and restores hope to the desolate, urging believers to walk in the confidence of Christ's eternal reign without fear of the unclean or the fleeting. (248 words)

Calvin emphasizes that Isaiah 52 functions as a profound call to awakening for God's redeemed community, interpreting the passage's urgent commands—such as "awake, O Zion" and "shaking off dust"—as divine interventions that liberate believers from spiritual stagnation and the corruption of the unclean world. Theologically, Calvin stresses that the "uncircumcised and unclean" symbolize all sinners who oppose God's holy people, while the promise of redemption "without money" reveals God's grace alone, not human merit. Crucially, Calvin identifies the "servant" in verse 13 as Christ Himself—the anointed one who suffers and brings salvation, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecies through his ministry of peace and reconciliation. This Christ-centered interpretation shows how God's active restoration of Jerusalem prefigures the Church's redemption and the global spread of the gospel through Christ's atoning work. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject spiritual complacency, embracing joy in God's promises while maintaining purity of heart—just as the text commands "be ye clean" to bear God's vessels. The passage's practical application lies in recognizing that Christ's triumph over sin and death (the "sprinkling" of nations) enables believers to participate in God's redemptive mission, fostering hope that the Lord will "go before" them and "reconcile" the broken. Thus, Calvin's commentary transforms Isaiah's ancient vision into a living call to Christ-dependent hope, where the redeemed community's joy flows from trust in the finished work of the Messiah who brings peace to Zion and the ends of the earth.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 52 emphasizes the active redemption of God's people and the imminent establishment of Christ's kingdom. He interprets the call to "awake, awake" as a command for the church—Zion—to rise from spiritual desolation, shed its "uncircumcised" (impure) associations with the world, and don "beautiful garments" signifying restored purity and divine glory. Poole connects this vivid imagery to the historical context of Babylonian captivity, where God's people were "sold for nought" yet "redeemed without money," revealing a divine promise that Christ's coming fulfills this redemption completely. Crucially, Poole links Isaiah 52:7's "feet of him that bringeth good tidings" to the Messiah himself—Christ as the one who proclaims peace and salvation, declaring "Thy God reigneth" in a way that transcends mere political liberation. Theologically, this underscores that true redemption is not merely from external oppression but involves the internal purification of the church through Christ's authority, replacing worldly alliances with divine unity. Practically, believers are called to actively reject worldly impurity, embrace Christ's redemptive work as the foundation for community life, and become instruments of the gospel's peace—especially in a world saturated with spiritual "uncircumcision." Poole's insight that the church's identity is defined by Christ's active presence ("behold, it is I") challenges modern congregations to live with bold hope, recognizing that their true strength and beauty stem from their intimate connection to the reigning King, not human achievements or worldly alliances. (247 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 52 reveals this chapter as a profound bridge between the immediate hope of Israel's deliverance from Babylon and the ultimate Christ-centered prophecy unfolding in Isaiah 53. Theologically, Barnes emphasizes that Jerusalem's call to arise from dust (v1-2) symbolizes the spiritual liberation of God's people from sin and bondage, while the promise of redemption without cost (v3-6) echoes God's faithfulness throughout history. The vivid imagery of the messenger bringing restoration (v7-8) and the joyful response of the city (v9-10) underscores that true restoration involves communal participation and divine initiative. Crucially, Barnes highlights the pivotal shift at v13, where the focus transitions from Babylonian exile to Christ himself—this verse functions as the essential introduction to the Messiah's suffering and glory in the following chapter. Theological insight here lies in understanding that the "uncircumcised and unclean" reference (v1) points not to exclusion but to the future purity of the redeemed church in Christ's kingdom. Practically, this text challenges believers to actively shed their spiritual dust—releasing anxiety and shame—while awaiting Christ's return as the true fulfillment of restoration. It calls for daily renewal through Christ, where the believer's identity is rooted not in external status but in the transformative work of the Messiah who redeems through suffering. For modern readers, this chapter reminds us that God's promises of deliverance and purity find their ultimate completion in Christ, urging active participation in His kingdom while maintaining hope in His coming restoration. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 53 presents this chapter as the clearest Old Testament prophecy of Christ's suffering and exaltation, emphasizing how the Messiah's humble, silent endurance contrasts sharply with Jewish expectations of a triumphant ruler. Henry underscores that Christ's mission was not to glory but to bear humanity's sin—his wounds and death becoming the means of healing and justification. Theologically, this passage reveals Christ's substitutionary atonement: he became sin for us, carrying our griefs and sorrows while remaining without sin himself, thereby reconciling us to God and securing eternal life through his sacrifice. Practically, Henry urges believers to confront their own sinfulness and respond to Christ's suffering by repentance and faith, recognizing that his death was the only way to atone for their transgressions. This prophecy calls for living in light of Christ's victory over sin, death, and Satan—motivating humility, sacrificial love, and a deep trust in his finished work. Henry concludes that by focusing on Christ's shared humanity and divine purpose, believers find unshakable hope, knowing their salvation rests not in their own efforts but in the Lamb who was "numbered with the transgressors" and who, through his suffering, brings redemption and righteousness to all who believe. This text remains a powerful foundation for Christian hope and obedience in a fallen world.

Calvin meticulously unpacks Isaiah 53 as a divine prophecy revealing Christ's redemptive role, emphasizing that the suffering servant is none other than Jesus. He interprets the opening query—"Who hath believed our report?"—not as a rhetorical lament about universal unbelief but as a profound theological statement about the necessity of God's extraordinary revelation for salvation. Calvin stresses that the "arm of the LORD" refers to the Spirit's special work, not Christ himself, highlighting that true faith requires divine intervention beyond human reasoning. The passage reveals Christ's silent bearing of humanity's sin, his rejection by both society and God, and his ultimate atoning death—where his wounds heal sinners and his suffering reconciles the broken. Theologically, Calvin underscores that Christ's humiliation is the means of reconciliation, his "soul" offered as a sacrifice for sin, and his resurrection as the vindication of this atonement. Practically, this commentary calls believers to recognize that genuine faith cannot be achieved through mere hearing or intellectual assent but requires the Spirit's work. Calvin warns against complacency in evangelism, noting that few accept the gospel despite its universal call, and urges Christians to lament unbelief while trusting God's sovereign provision. This passage, he argues, remains vital today: it reminds us that Christ's obedience to the cross—suffering, death, and resurrection—satisfies divine justice and offers hope to all who believe, transforming our understanding of grace and the necessity of Christ's work for our redemption.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 53 emphasizes the profound contrast between Christ's divine nature and his apparent human weakness, revealing how Jewish disbelief preceded his redemptive work. Poole interprets the opening question—"Who hath believed our report?"—as highlighting the Jews' widespread rejection of the Messiah's humble origins, noting their expectation of a powerful ruler rather than a "tender plant" growing from "dry ground." This imagery underscores Christ's undignified earthly beginnings—without physical beauty or social standing—yet Poole stresses that this apparent weakness was divinely ordained, foreshadowing his role as the "root of Jesse" who would bear humanity's sins. Crucially, Poole connects the verse where Christ "was wounded for our transgressions" to the atoning nature of his suffering: his stripes became the means of healing for sinners, demonstrating that Christ's rejection by humanity was purposeful, bearing the "chastisement of our peace" to reconcile us to God. Theologically, this passage reveals Christ's voluntary substitution—suffering not for his own sin but for others', transforming rejection into redemption. Practically, Poole's insights urge believers to embrace humility in service, recognizing that Christ's apparent weakness (like his suffering) becomes strength when it aligns with divine purpose. Christians are called to see their own struggles as part of this redemptive narrative, understanding that true healing flows from Christ's wounds, not human merit, and responding with grace toward those who suffer, just as the rejected Messiah did. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 53 emphasizes the profound tension between the Messiah's divine purpose and human rejection. He interprets verse 1 as a rhetorical question highlighting the universal disbelief in the prophet's message: "Who hath believed our report?" Barnes stresses that Isaiah groups himself with other prophets, noting the Messiah's announcement was consistently disregarded by the nation. The "arm of the LORD" here signifies God's active power through the Redeemer, yet this power was largely unseen by the masses. Verse 2's vivid imagery—"a tender plant, a root out of dry ground"—describes the Messiah's humble origins and unappealing physical presence, deliberately contrasting expectations of a powerful ruler with reality. Barnes argues this synecdoche (using part for whole) portrays Christ emerging from spiritual barrenness, lacking conventional beauty or status. Theologically, this underscores Christ's mission as a suffering servant whose value lies not in human perception but in divine purpose. Practically, it challenges believers to recognize that true salvation comes through humility and sacrifice, not self-image or worldly success. It reveals that Christ's exaltation (verse 12) flows from his prior rejection and suffering, teaching us that God's power is most evident in the overlooked and afflicted. For modern readers, this commentary encourages embracing Christ's identity as the rejected Servant—urging humility, active compassion for the marginalized, and trust in God's redemptive work that transforms the broken, rather than seeking human approval. (280 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 54 presents a profound message of divine covenant renewal for the church, emphasizing Christ's central role as the ultimate fulfillment. He interprets the "barren" and "desolate" woman as the New Covenant community—initially vulnerable but destined for abundant spiritual offspring through Christ. The text reveals God's promise to expand His people's influence across nations (v3), a direct foreshadowing of the Church's global mission through Jesus. Crucially, Henry highlights Christ as the "Holy One of Israel" and "Redeemer" (v5), whose name becomes "God of the whole earth," signifying the universal scope of the gospel. The passage's core theological insight lies in God's paradoxical yet secure love: He temporarily withdraws ("a small moment") from His people (v7-8), yet this abandonment is always followed by "everlasting kindness" and covenantal protection far surpassing human failures or even the removal of mountains (v10). This dynamic—temporary testing followed by unshakable grace—finds its Christological completion in Jesus' atoning work, where the "waters of Noah" (v9) symbolize the final cleansing of sin through Christ's sacrifice. Practically, Henry urges believers to rest in this covenant security amid trials, understanding that God's purpose for them—establishing righteousness and peace (v14-15)—outlasts all opposition. This promise encourages perseverance: just as the Church's foundation is built on Christ's eternal love, believers find courage to endure persecution, knowing their true identity and inheritance rest not in their own strength but in the faithful promise of their Redeemer. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 54:1-17 as a profound promise of divine restoration for the Church, addressing her spiritual barrenness through the lens of Christ's redemptive work. He emphasizes that the "barren" and "widow" imagery denotes the Church's condition of spiritual desolation before God's intervention—where outward appearances suggest destruction, yet divine promise guarantees abundant spiritual offspring far exceeding natural fertility. This "more children of the desolate" (v. 1) signifies the Church's future flourishing through Christ, whose death and resurrection ensure her restoration as the "bride" of God. Calvin connects this passage directly to Christ's sacrificial death for the Church, arguing that without this foundation, believers could not fully grasp the efficacy of Christ's work. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereign promise that His covenantal love transcends human weakness and shame, transforming the "widow" into a thriving community. Practically, Calvin urges believers to find hope in God's enduring mercy despite present trials, recognizing that Christ's victory over death guarantees their future inheritance. This passage challenges the Church to embrace God's active care in their spiritual life, knowing that the "covenant of peace" (v. 10) and Christ's "everlasting kindness" (v. 8) will ultimately dismantle all oppression and fear. For modern readers, Calvin's commentary offers vital encouragement: in moments of spiritual desolation, believers can trust that Christ's sacrifice ensures their restoration, fostering confidence that God's purpose for His people will surpass all present circumstances. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 54 emphasizes the profound theological shift where the "barren" Jewish church, historically unfruitful in genuine spiritual bearing, becomes the vessel for God's expansive blessing through Christ. Poole argues that the "desolate" (Gentiles) outnumber the "married wife" (Jews) in Christ's new covenant community, a direct fulfillment of God's promise that the gospel would bring far greater spiritual multiplication than the ancient Jewish people. This vision, Poole insists, points decisively to Christ as the true "seed" who overcomes barrenness—both the spiritual infertility of the Jewish people before his coming and the Gentile world's initial spiritual desolation. Theologically, this reveals God's covenant faithfulness: he transforms rejection into reconciliation, turning the "forlorn" and "widowed" state of the church into a vibrant, enduring union with his eternal husband. Practically, believers are called to embrace their own "barren" condition—spiritual dryness or past failures—while trusting Christ's power to break forth in new life and mission, not through human effort but through God's active inclusion of the Gentiles. Poole's Christ-centered interpretation underscores that the church's true identity and future security rest not in ethnic heritage but in Christ's redemption, who alone fulfills the promise of "forgetting the shame of youth" and becoming "the bride" of God. This calls believers to actively expand God's kingdom without pride, recognizing their strength comes solely from the Holy One who calls them home. (248 words)

Barnes interprets Isaiah 54 as a profound promise of divine restoration for God's people, particularly in the context of exile, centered on the Messiah's future work. The chapter's core theological insight emphasizes that God's covenant with His people remains eternally secure despite temporary desolation—Jerusalem, depicted as a "barren" woman, will experience extraordinary spiritual and numerical expansion through the inclusion of Gentiles under Christ. This "enlargement" (v. 2–3) transcends physical boundaries, signifying the universal scope of the Church, where the "desolate cities" become inhabited by God's people through the Messiah's redemptive mission. Crucially, Barnes links this to Christ's fulfillment: the "children of the desolate" (v. 1) represent the Gentile believers grafted into the Church, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy that the Messiah would "make the desolate cities to be inhabited" (v. 3). The chapter's assurance of unshakable covenant (v. 10) and divine protection (v. 15–17) echoes Christ's promise of eternal security in His kingdom, contrasting temporary human struggles with God's eternal design. Practically, believers today are called to trust God's provision beyond current circumstances—whether in spiritual barrenness or societal isolation—by anchoring hope in Christ's completed work. This promise encourages active participation in God's mission: cultivating spiritual abundance (the "sapphire foundation" of v. 12), teaching others (v. 13), and finding liberation from fear through Christ's victory. Ultimately, Barnes shows that Isaiah 54's consolation flows not from immediate restoration but from the Messiah's eternal promise, empowering believers to live with confidence in God's unfolding kingdom. (248 words)

Henry emphasizes that Isaiah 55 presents a universal, Christ-centered invitation to spiritual refreshment, where God's grace transcends human limitations. The "water" and "wine and milk" imagery (v1-2) symbolize the sufficiency of Christ—accessible without cost, satisfying even the deepest spiritual hunger. Henry connects this directly to Jesus' own declaration in John 7:37, where he identifies himself as the "fountain" of living water, revealing that true fulfillment comes only in Christ, not in worldly possessions or temporary pleasures. Theologically, Henry underscores that these blessings are "sure mercies of David" (v3), covenant promises paid for by Christ's blood (1 Peter 1:19), making salvation freely available to all who respond. Practically, this calls for active engagement: recognizing spiritual thirst, repenting of self-reliance (v6-7), and obediently turning to Christ as the only path to mercy. Henry warns against treating God's grace as an opportunity for sin, stressing that genuine reception requires a transformed heart—shifting from "wicked ways" to "the ways of the Lord" (v7-9). The passage's ultimate hope (v12-13) lies in Christ's redemptive work: those who heed his call experience joy, renewal, and a transformed creation, where the "thorn" yields "fir trees" for God's eternal glory. This commentary urges believers to embrace Christ's free gift immediately, understanding that true rest and lasting satisfaction arise only through his atoning love and the new covenant he establishes.

Calvin interpreted Isaiah 55 as a profound summons to spiritual renewal, emphasizing that true "thirst" reveals a soul starving for divine sustenance rather than being satisfied by worldly pursuits. He argued that the "waters," "wine," and "milk" symbolize the full spectrum of Christ's gift—doctrinal clarity, the Holy Spirit, and spiritual nourishment—necessarily received without monetary exchange, underscoring God's gratuitous grace. Crucially, Calvin connected this passage to Christ as its fulfillment: the "living water" John describes (John 4:14) directly embodies the eternal life offered through Jesus, transcending human effort or self-sufficiency. Theologically, Calvin stressed that the "thirsty" are those who recognize their spiritual emptiness despite external fulfillment, a condition only Christ can satisfy by breaking the power of self-reliance. Practically, this demands active pursuit—believers must cease relying on their own resources and instead cultivate a hunger for Christ's presence, as the passage warns against the dangerous complacency of those "swollen with wind" who reject spiritual truth. Calvin's insight reveals that true abundance flows not from human initiative but from Christ's covenant, requiring daily surrender to His provision. This transforms believers into active participants in God's kingdom, where the "everlasting covenant" (Isaiah 55:3) becomes lived reality through reliance on the Lord who "makes the waters flow" (Isaiah 55:10–11).

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 55 presents this chapter as a profound invitation to Christ for all people—Jews and Gentiles alike—emphasizing God's boundless grace and the immediate accessibility of spiritual life without cost or condition. He interprets the "water" as the living Spirit's gifts, "wine and milk" as spiritual nourishment, and the command to "buy without money" as Christ's freely offered salvation, accessible even to the poor and sinful who genuinely thirst. Theologically, Poole connects this passage to Christ as the true David (v.3), the everlasting covenant-keeper who fulfills God's promises to Abraham, and the universal savior who calls nations to himself (v.5), where Gentiles respond to Christ's call because of God's glory. This reveals Christ's role as the "witness" and "leader" (v.4) who reconciles all people to God through the covenant of grace. Practically, Poole urges believers to actively seek God while he is near (v.6), repent, and embrace Christ's free gift—rejecting worldly pursuits that satisfy only temporarily. The commentary highlights that true spiritual fulfillment comes not from self-effort or money but from Christ's resurrection power, which brings life and an ever-expanding community of believers. In modern terms, this calls Christians to proclaim Christ's universal invitation with urgency, recognizing that God's grace is available to anyone who truly thirsts, regardless of status or past sin, and to live in response to that grace with joyful obedience. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 55 emphasizes this chapter as a profound theological statement emerging directly from the Christological framework of Isaiah 53:1-12, presenting the universal invitation to salvation as the direct consequence of the Messiah's atoning work. Theologically, Barnes stresses that God's provision in this chapter reveals an unreserved, abundant grace—salvation is freely available to all, regardless of wealth or sin, without cost or condition. This universal accessibility underscores that Christ's sacrifice has already secured eternal life for the entire world, dismantling barriers of poverty, status, or perceived unworthiness. Practically, this invitation calls believers to immediate response: to abandon self-reliance and spiritual thirst, turning toward God's free gift of life and blessing. Barnes explicitly connects this passage to Christ himself, noting how Jesus' declaration in John 7:37—"Whoever thirsts, let him come and drink"—directly echoes Isaiah 55:1, framing Christ as the living water that satisfies spiritual hunger. This Christ-centered perspective transforms the chapter into an urgent call to embrace God's grace, assuring that no one—regardless of their circumstances—can claim exclusion from salvation. The practical application, therefore, is clear: individuals must actively seek Christ, recognizing that his completed work guarantees abundant life without monetary or moral transaction, fostering both personal transformation and universal hope for the gospel's reach. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 56 reveals God's universal call for righteous living and inclusive blessing through Christ. He emphasizes that true obedience—keeping judgment, doing justice, and honoring the Sabbath as holy rest—reflects a heart aligned with God's character, not mere ritual. Theologically, Henry highlights how God actively welcomes the marginalized: eunuchs, foreigners, and the "strangers" who serve Him faithfully, promising them a place of honor and an "everlasting name" surpassing biological lineage. This directly points to Christ as the fulfillment of Isaiah's vision, where the "son of man" (Christ) unites Jews and Gentiles into one fold under His shepherding. The prophecy's promise of spiritual restoration—turning mourners into joyful worshipers—finds its climax in the New Covenant, where believers, regardless of background, participate in God's house. Henry stresses that Christ's sacrifice reconciles all who keep His commandments, dissolving barriers of ethnicity and social status. Practically, this calls believers to cultivate holy obedience in daily life, actively embrace diverse communities in worship, and reject spiritual complacency. It challenges leaders to be vigilant watchmen, not blind shepherds, ensuring Christ's people find rest in Him rather than worldly pursuits. Ultimately, Henry teaches that God's grace extends to all who turn from sin and cling to Christ, transforming the "dry tree" into a thriving branch in His kingdom.

Calvin emphasizes that Isaiah 56 calls believers to a holistic obedience encompassing both the first and second tables of the Law—specifically, active justice in relationships and the sacred observance of the Sabbath—framed by God's near salvation and revealed righteousness. The passage's profound inclusivity, extending salvation to Gentiles and eunuchs who covenant with the Lord, challenges ethnic and social barriers, revealing God's desire for genuine spiritual alignment over ritualistic compliance. Calvin connects this to Christ by highlighting how Isaiah's vision prefigures the New Covenant: Jesus becomes the true "house of prayer for all people" (Isaiah 56:7), where barriers of nationality and gender dissolve, fulfilling the promise that God's people will be "a name better than sons and daughters" (Isaiah 56:5). Theologically, Calvin stresses that true righteousness cannot be earned by human effort but is God's gift received through obedience to His revealed will—a concept he ties to the gospel where Christ's sacrifice provides the only access to divine righteousness. Practically, this means believers must actively engage in justice and Sabbath rest as living expressions of faith, not mere rituals, while recognizing that God's grace extends to all who turn from self-reliance. Calvin warns against hypocritical piety, urging Christians to avoid the "blind watchmen" of spiritual complacency described in Isaiah 56:10–12, instead embracing the transformative call to live with integrity and hope in Christ's redemptive work.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 56 reveals God's profound commitment to universal inclusion within His covenant, emphasizing that salvation and righteousness are accessible beyond ethnic or ritual barriers. Poole interprets the "sabbath" synecdochically as the entire worship of God, highlighting that true devotion—marked by consistent adherence to God's commands, not mere ritual compliance—opens the door for all who turn from idols. Theologically, this passage underscores God's active dismantling of human divisions: eunuchs (symbolizing those excluded by Levitical law) and Gentiles ("strangers") who embrace Christ become co-heirs of the covenant, receiving a "name better than sons" (eternal blessing) and full participation in God's temple. Poole explicitly connects this to Christ, identifying "my salvation" as the imminent Messiah's work and "my righteousness" as fulfilled through Jesus—the one who reconciles the broken covenant. Practically, this calls churches today to actively welcome the marginalized—those historically excluded by cultural or religious norms—into meaningful worship and community, not as temporary guests but as permanent participants. Christ's fulfillment of the law (as seen in the Sabbath) ensures that true worship, centered on relationship with God, transcends human divisions. The "house of prayer for all people" becomes a living testament to this truth: when believers diligently pursue justice and holiness, they participate in God's mission to gather a diverse body where all—Jew and Gentile, able and disabled—find belonging through Christ's redemptive work. This transforms the church from a segregated institution into a sanctuary of universal grace. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 56 reveals a Christ-centered message deeply rooted in the prophetic continuity of the Messianic age. This chapter, building on Isaiah 52–55, emphasizes that God's salvation is near—specifically the imminent fulfillment of the Messiah's work—and calls for active holiness in preparation. Theologically, Barnes highlights how the text explicitly extends divine favor beyond Jewish boundaries: strangers, foreigners, and eunuchs (v3–6) are promised equal privileges with God's people, signifying the universal scope of the gospel. This inclusion anticipates Christ's role as the bridge for all nations, where ethnic and social barriers dissolve. The Sabbath observance (v2) is interpreted not as rigid ritual but as a symbol of authentic, unchanging worship—foreshadowing Christ's ultimate fulfillment of the Law as the true rest for the redeemed. Practically, this demands believers actively cultivate humility and justice (v1), embrace diverse communities without prejudice, and reject worldly selfishness and idolatry (v9–12) that threaten the kingdom's integrity. Barnes underscores that the "salvation near" promise (v1) points to Christ's imminent arrival—not as a distant event but as a present reality for those who live righteously, urging active participation in God's kingdom rather than passive expectation. This vision challenges modern Christians to embody inclusive love, prioritize genuine holiness over ritualism, and remain vigilant against spiritual complacency, ensuring the gospel's transformative power reaches every corner of the world through Christ's universal mediation. (278 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 57 presents a profound contrast between the fate of the righteous and the destructive path of the wicked. He emphasizes that the righteous, though often unnoticed in their passing, enter into divine peace and rest upon death—a reality the careless world disregards. This section sharply condemns those who substitute false idols for God, describing their self-deception in idolatry, unrepentant sin, and the futility of their rituals, which ultimately lead to spiritual desolation and "no peace" (v. 21). Henry connects this to Christ by revealing that true peace—unlike the troubled sea of the wicked—is found only in the "high and holy place" where God dwells with the contrite and humble (v. 15). Christ, as the fulfillment of this promise, provides the atoning work that heals the broken spirit and restores communion with God, overcoming the "troubled sea" of sin. Theologically, Henry underscores that God's wrath is not perpetual but is tempered by His mercy toward those who humble themselves, emphasizing that salvation depends not on human effort but on Christ's finished work and the resulting "new heart." Practically, this calls believers to examine their hearts: to renounce idolatry (whether in sin, worldly pursuits, or false securities), embrace humility, and seek Christ's peace through repentance and reliance on His grace. True restoration, Henry insists, comes only through God's active intervention, offering hope that the wicked who turn to Him will find healing and inheritance in His holy mountain—a promise fulfilled in Christ's redemptive mission for all who trust Him. (248 words)

Calvin emphasizes Isaiah 57's profound theological tension: the paradoxical fate of the righteous who perish without recognition, while the merciful are unexpectedly taken away, revealing God's sovereign judgment that transcends human understanding. He interprets this not as mere punishment but as God's deliberate removal of the righteous to purify His people, exposing the self-deception of those who claim mercy while living in transgression. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ as the ultimate "high and holy place" (Isaiah 57:15), where the truly contrite find restoration—Christ himself is the living embodiment of this divine dwelling place, the only source of true peace. The passage's vivid critique of the wicked—like restless seas producing mire—serves as a stark contrast to the righteous who, though seemingly destroyed, are ultimately healed by Christ's atoning work. Practically, Calvin urges believers to move beyond worldly anxieties and self-deception, actively examining their hearts for hypocrisy and unconfessed sin. True mercy, he stresses, flows only from Christ, not human effort; the "stumbling block" in the people's path (Isaiah 57:14) must be removed through Christ's reconciliation. This commentary challenges Christians to seek genuine spiritual rest in God's mercy rather than futile worldly security, recognizing that the righteous who perish are being gathered for eternal life—only through Christ's sacrifice and the Spirit's renewal does the "healing" promised in Isaiah 57:19 become real.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 57 reveals a stark theological contrast between the suffering of the righteous and the pervasive idolatry of the Israelites, emphasizing God's justice and the peril of spiritual complacency. Poole interprets the "righteous perisheth" (v1) not as a general fate but as a specific judgment where God's holy people die without lamentation or repentance, highlighting their moral corruption and the nation's widespread idolatry—both in worship practices and internal character. He notes that true righteousness ("mercy" and "uprightness") is threatened by the idolatrous behaviors described: sacrificing children (v5), setting up altars in high places (v7), and forging false covenants with idolatrous systems (v8). Crucially, Poole connects this passage to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of the "righteous" who dies in peace (v2), contrasting the Jewish rejection of Him with the Christian understanding that Christ's sacrificial death provides the only true rest and forgiveness. Theologically, this underscores that genuine righteousness cannot coexist with idolatry, as the "righteous" must walk before God with integrity. Practically, it warns believers to examine their worship practices and relationships for hidden idolatry—whether in false securities, worldly pursuits, or compromised moral standards—while urging repentance for the failure to lament God's judgments on sin. Christ's death resolves the tension of Isaiah 57: the righteous suffer in this world but find eternal peace through Him, offering a path to true reconciliation rather than the doomed idolatry that Poole depicts. This commentary thus serves as a powerful call to spiritual vigilance and Christ-centered hope in a world rife with false idols. (248 words)

Barnes situates Isaiah 57 within the context of intense moral decay during the reign of King Manasseh, linking it closely to the preceding chapter to emphasize the nation's spiritual blindness despite severe persecution of the righteous. The chapter reveals a profound theological tension: the ungodly nation remains stupendously indifferent to the violent removal of the pious—those "taken away" by divine judgment—while the righteous suffer persecution yet find rest in God's care. Barnes stresses that this indifference ("no man layeth it to heart") demonstrates the nation's guilt and spiritual death, as they neither acknowledge God's purpose in removing the righteous nor fear the coming judgments of foreign invasion. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereign justice: He exposes idolatry, unfaithfulness, and moral corruption (v. 3–11), yet offers a path to mercy for the repentant. Practical application demands vigilance against spiritual apathy—when we ignore the suffering of the righteous or the signs of societal decay, we risk becoming part of the "stupid" crowd. Christologically, the chapter foreshadows Jesus as the ultimate "righteous one" who suffers persecution (v. 1) while the "stumbling-block" (v. 14) points to Christ's role in removing barriers to faith. Believers today must heed this warning: active compassion for the persecuted, honest repentance for moral compromise, and trust in Christ's promises of peace amid judgment prevent spiritual blindness. True hope lies not in avoiding suffering but in surrendering to God's mercy, ensuring that even in the midst of chaos, those who turn to Him find rest and restoration. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 58 powerfully critiques superficial religious practices, emphasizing that genuine repentance must transcend ritualistic fasting and self-denial. He argues that true fasting—defined by liberating the oppressed, feeding the hungry, and breaking chains of injustice—reflects a heart transformed by Christ's love, not mere ritualistic sorrow. Henry stresses that the "fast" described in Isaiah 58 is not about personal penitence but active, compassionate engagement with societal brokenness: freeing the oppressed, comforting the naked, and honoring the Sabbath as a sacred space for God's presence rather than a day of work. Theologically, Henry connects this prophetic call directly to Christ, revealing that Jesus fulfills Isaiah's vision by embodying the "repairer of breaches" (Isaiah 58:12)—he heals fractured relationships, restores the marginalized, and establishes the Sabbath as a divine gift of rest and renewal. Practically, Henry urges believers to move beyond performative piety: actively serve the poor, cease exploiting the vulnerable, and honor the Sabbath as a deliberate break from worldly busyness to cultivate spiritual depth. This Christ-centered application transforms fasting into tangible acts of mercy, demonstrating that true righteousness—where "the Lord shall guide thee continually" (Isaiah 58:11)—is lived through obedience to God's command to love neighbor and rest in His holiness. The chapter thus calls Christians to see Christ's work as the ultimate fulfillment of Isaiah's vision, where genuine restoration flows from selfless compassion rather than empty rituals. (248 words)

Calvin interprets Isaiah 58 as a profound critique of hypocritical religious performance, emphasizing that true fasting and righteousness transcend ritualistic self-denial. He argues that the people's "fasting" focused on empty displays—strife, personal affliction, and outward mourning—without tangible acts of justice or compassion was futile and rejected by God. Theologically, Calvin highlights that authentic worship requires dismantling oppression (loosening "the bands of wickedness"), actively feeding the hungry, covering the naked, and honoring God's Sabbath as restorative communion—not as a rigid schedule but as liberation from sin's burdens. This vision directly points to Christ, who fulfills Isaiah's prophecy as the ultimate "repairer of breaches" (Isaiah 58:12), bearing the yoke of sin to liberate the oppressed and restore relational wholeness. Practical application demands believers move beyond superficial piety to concrete, daily engagement: actively listening to the marginalized, resisting systems of injustice, and celebrating Sabbath as sacred time for community restoration rather than productivity. Calvin stresses that such actions—like Christ's ministry—make "the light break forth as the morning" (Isaiah 58:8), transforming spiritual hunger into tangible hope and healing. In a modern context, this means rejecting performative faith to cultivate authentic discipleship where every act of mercy becomes a living proclamation of Christ's redemptive love. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 58 sharply critiques Jewish religious hypocrisy, revealing how their ritualistic fasting—characterized by self-imposed suffering without genuine repentance—became a tool for self-deception rather than divine communion. He argues that the Jews claimed to seek God daily and delight in righteousness, yet their "fasts" were marred by active oppression: engaging in strife, exploiting debtors, and indulging sinful desires despite outward austerity. True fasting, Poole insists, demands inward transformation—humility, justice, and compassionate action—where the soul is truly afflicted by repentance, not merely external penitence. Theologically, this exposes a critical tension in worship: ritual without relational integrity remains empty, while authentic righteousness flows from active love for neighbor and God's law. Practically, this challenges believers to move beyond performative piety, urging concrete actions like resolving conflicts, practicing mercy, and refusing exploitation—actions that align with Christ's model. Poole's analysis finds profound Christ connection: Jesus explicitly rejects ritualistic religiosity (Matthew 6:1-18), teaching that true righteousness manifests in compassionate service and humility. In Christ, the "fast" is perfected—through his sacrificial life, which fulfills Isaiah's call for justice and mercy. This commentary thus equips modern Christians to evaluate their worship through the lens of transformative love, ensuring that spiritual disciplines become pathways to genuine reconciliation with God and others, not mere ritualistic performances.

Barnes argues that Isaiah 58 sharply critiques Jewish religious hypocrisy, revealing how the nation performed external rituals—fasting, Sabbath observance—yet remained spiritually barren due to oppressive practices, social injustice, and insincere devotion. The prophet condemns their "vain dependence" on outward forms while continuing economic exploitation, interpersonal strife, and hollow piety, emphasizing that God's acceptance demands tangible acts of liberation: freeing the oppressed, ending burdens, and prioritizing the poor. Theologically, Barnes stresses that true worship transcends ritual compliance, requiring active righteousness that aligns with God's heart for justice. This chapter finds profound Christological fulfillment in Jesus himself, who embodies the "true fast" of Isaiah 58—through his ministry of healing, feeding the hungry, and liberating the oppressed (e.g., Luke 4:16-21). Christ's atoning work resolves the Jewish people's spiritual isolation by reconciling sinners through grace while inaugurating the kingdom of justice where oppression ends and the marginalized are honored. Practically, believers today must move beyond ritualistic religiosity to embody this call: actively dismantling systems of oppression, advocating for the vulnerable, and cultivating genuine compassion that reflects Christ's sacrificial love. Barnes' insight compels us to recognize that authentic worship is measured by how we live among the poor and oppressed, ensuring that our faith transforms society rather than merely sustaining superficial religious performance. This Christ-centered application reveals that true spiritual renewal begins where justice meets mercy in the everyday. (248 words)

Henry's commentary on Isaiah 59 emphasizes the profound separation caused by human sin from God, revealing that divine withdrawal of hearing and favor stems not from God's inability but from human rebellion and unrepentant iniquity. The passage vividly depicts how sin—manifested in bloodshed, deceit, and destructive systems—blocks divine justice and peace, rendering human efforts futile and leading to spiritual blindness and destruction. Theologically, Henry underscores that God's active presence (His "hand not shortened") remains, yet sin creates a chasm where righteousness cannot enter, highlighting the absolute necessity of Christ as the only bridge. Practical application demands that believers confront their own sinful patterns, recognizing that unconfessed sin actively distances them from God's presence and work in their lives, making true prayer ineffective without repentance. Crucially, Henry connects this chapter to Christ's fulfillment: the "Redeemer" described here—whose righteousness becomes a "breastplate" and who "puts on garments of vengeance" against enemies—reveals Jesus as the ultimate intercessor who, through His atoning death, bridges the gap sin created. This Christ-centered solution transforms the hope of Isaiah 59 from despair to assurance, demonstrating that God's justice and mercy converge in Jesus, who secures eternal peace for those who turn from sin. For modern readers, this commentary calls for humility in recognizing sin's cost and active reliance on Christ's finished work, where true righteousness is not self-generated but received through faith in the Messiah who alone makes the way for divine restoration. (248 words)

Calvin emphasizes that God's power and willingness to save remain unbroken—His hand is not shortened, nor His ear heavy—yet human sin creates a chasm between people and God. This profound theological insight reveals that divine accessibility is obstructed by pervasive sin: hands stained with blood, lips speaking lies, and hearts conceived of iniquity. Calvin argues that the human condition described in Isaiah 59—where justice is absent, light turns to darkness, and people grope like blind men—directly exposes the futility of self-reliance and the universal need for divine intervention. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ as the ultimate resolution. The "Redeemer" who comes to Zion (v. 20) and whose covenant promises endure forever (v. 21) is the fulfillment of God's active hand reaching across sin. Christ's work reconciles humanity to God by bearing the iniquity that had separated people, making the "hand" and "ear" imagery active in Christ's atonement. Practically, Calvin's commentary urges self-examination: believers must confront their own "blood-stained" actions and "lies" to break the barrier between God and self. It calls for active faith in Christ's fulfillment of the covenant—where God's righteousness becomes a protective armor (v. 17) and His salvation is not distant but present through the cross. This transforms the lament of Isaiah 59 into hope: true peace comes not from human efforts but from Christ's redemptive work, which bridges the gap and restores the relationship shattered by sin.

Poole emphasizes that Isaiah 59 reveals God's unchanging accessibility—his hand is not shortened (omnipotent) nor his ear heavy (attentive)—contrasting sharply with the human reality where sin creates an insurmountable barrier between God and people. This separation, Poole explains, stems from specific sins: bloodshed, injustice, deceit, and spiritual blindness that hide God's face, rendering His hearing and help ineffective. The vivid metaphors of hatching "cockatrice eggs" (malicious, self-destructive schemes) and weaving "spider's webs" (delicate, intricate traps designed to ensnare others) illustrate how human wickedness operates with premeditation and inevitable ruin. Theologically, Poole underscores that the problem lies entirely with human sin, not God's capacity or willingness, pointing to a divine reality where God remains active despite human failure. Practically, this calls for urgent repentance and community accountability—addressing injustice, truthfulness, and the hidden corruption that blinds us. Crucially, Poole's commentary foreshadows Christ's role: the barrier sin creates is only overcome through Jesus, who, as the ultimate fulfillment of Isaiah's promises, bridges the chasm by bearing the sin that separates us, restoring divine access and fulfilling the covenant of redemption. This Christ-centered resolution transforms the "spider's web" of human sin into the "covenant of the Redeemer" where God's help becomes real and effective.

Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 59 reveals a profound theological emphasis on the consequences of pervasive sin and the divine response to human failure. He argues that this chapter directly addresses Israel's religious hypocrisy—where external rituals masked inner corruption—illustrating how their unrepentant sins, including bloodshed, deceitful speech, injustice, and destructive thoughts, created a "partition" between them and God. Crucially, Barnes stresses that Yahweh's judgment stems not from divine inability but from human rebellion, preventing misplaced blame-shifting. Theologically, this underscores sin's power to sever divine intimacy, where even righteous actions become ineffective without genuine repentance. Barnes highlights the chapter's Christ-centered fulfillment: the "redeemer" who resolves this separation—characterized by righteousness, vengeance, and zeal—points unambiguously to Jesus Christ, who alone bridges the gap created by sin. Practically, this calls believers to examine their motives: Are our hands defiled with unconfessed wrongdoing, our lips speaking truth or lies? The chapter urges active repentance, not passive ritual, as the path to restoration. In modern application, it challenges Christians to move beyond superficial piety, recognizing that true reconciliation requires confronting sin's pervasive nature in daily life. Christ's role as the only intercessor who both bears the wrath of God and secures forgiveness exemplifies how divine justice and mercy converge in the cross—a reality that transforms suffering into hope for the repentant heart. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 60 reveals this chapter as a profound prophecy of Christ's future global impact and the transformed church. Henry emphasizes that while the Old Testament Jewish church is referenced, the prophecy's fulfillment centers on the New Covenant community where Christ, as the divine light and glory, illuminates the nations. The "light" and "glory" explicitly point to Jesus—the eternal Son who brings salvation and God's presence. Henry notes the passage describes Gentiles gathering from distant lands, kings submitting, and the church becoming a beacon of holiness and blessing, reflecting Christ's universal reign where all nations find refuge in Him. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereign plan: His glory actively transforms the church into a light for the world, purifying it through the Spirit's work and uniting diverse peoples in worship. Practically, Christians are called to embody this vision—actively welcoming sinners as "doves to their home," living with Christ's light that dispels darkness, and building communities where mercy flows freely. Henry stresses that this hope calls believers to trust God's timing, knowing His promises of peace and righteousness will ultimately prevail, urging active participation in God's redemptive work rather than passive expectation. The chapter's climax—where Christ's light replaces the sun and moon—affirms that true discipleship finds eternal security in Him alone, transforming lives and nations through the gospel. This Christ-centered hope motivates believers to be instruments of light in a broken world. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 60 reveals a profound theological vision where God actively restores His people through Christ's triumphant presence. Calvin interprets the "arise, shine" command not as a generic call but as God's sovereign intervention, lifting the afflicted Church from prostration to radiant glory. He emphasizes that this light is Christ himself—fully revealing God's glory and overcoming universal darkness, as seen in verses 19-20 where the sun and moon cease to govern, replaced by Christ's eternal light. Theologically, Calvin stresses that this prophecy transcends physical restoration; it points to the spiritual illumination of the Church, where God's glory "is risen upon thee" as the true Light of the world. The gathering of Gentiles, kings, and nations signifies the universal scope of Christ's redemptive work, fulfilling Old Testament promises while revealing God's sovereignty over all nations. Practically, Calvin urges believers to live as active lights in their communities, recognizing that their individual lives reflect Christ's light to a world in darkness. This involves sharing the Gospel with humility and faithfulness, as the "sons of strangers" (v.10) become part of the Church's mission. Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ's fulfillment: the "eternal excellency" (v.15) and "branch of my planting" (v.21) point to the Church as Christ's eternal kingdom, where the "milk of the Gentiles" (v.16) becomes the Church's mission to nourish others through Christ.
