Poole's commentary on Isaiah 60 presents a dual vision of divine restoration and global evangelism, deeply rooted in Christological significance. He interprets the call to "arise, shine" as both a promise of Jerusalem's post-exilic renewal and a prophetic typology for the Gentile church's flourishing under Christ. The "light" and "glory" explicitly point to Jesus—the true Light (John 1:9) who brings salvation and transforms lives, while the "glory rising upon thee" signifies Christ's active presence and future fulfillment of God's kingdom. Poole emphasizes that the "darkness covering the earth" represents spiritual blindness and idolatry, contrasted with Christ's rising glory that dispels this gloom. The prophecy's core theological insight is that Christ's coming enables universal inclusion: Gentiles and even kings are drawn to the light of the gospel, fulfilling Isaiah's promise that the church would become a global community where "thy sons shall come from far" and "thy daughters shall be nursed at thy side." This vision reveals Christ as the unifying source of hope and belonging. Practically, believers are called to actively embrace this hope in their current circumstances—seeing Christ as the transformative light in trials, trusting His rising glory for salvation, and extending welcome to others regardless of background. The commentary urges active participation in the church's mission, recognizing that the "flow together" of diverse believers into Christ's community mirrors the universal outpouring of grace, requiring humility, evangelism, and joyful unity in the Spirit as the church reflects Christ's reconciling light to a darkened world. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 60 presents a vivid prophetic vision of the future "golden age" under Christ's reign, emphasizing its Christ-centered nature and universal implications. Barnes interprets the chapter as a glorious declaration where the "light" and "glory of the LORD" specifically rise upon the church (Zion), signifying the gospel's illumination and Christ's manifested presence. Theologically, this passage reveals God's promise of global conversion—where Gentiles from distant lands (Sheba, Kedar) flock to Christ, bringing their wealth and resources as acts of worship, directly foreshadowing the Church's universal mission and the cross-cultural nature of the gospel. Crucially, Barnes underscores that the "light" is Christ himself, the "glory" is His divine nature, and the "arising" calls the church to active participation in God's redemptive work rather than passive waiting. Practically, this commentary urges believers to embody Christ's light in darkened contexts: actively sharing the gospel with neighbors and strangers, trusting God's promise of global redemption despite present spiritual darkness, and recognizing that true prosperity flows from Christ's reign, not human efforts. It challenges Christians to be agents of hope in a world enveloped in "gross darkness," understanding that their role is not merely to receive but to shine brightly as Christ has shone, reflecting the transformative power of the gospel that turns nations toward the Redeemer. (248 words)

Henry observes that Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 61 centers on Christ as the definitive fulfillment of the prophet's vision, revealing how Jesus uniquely embodies the "anointed" described in the chapter. Theologically, Henry emphasizes that Christ's Spirit differs fundamentally from the temporary empowerment of prophets, granting him perpetual authority to preach liberation to the meek and oppressed—freedom from sin's dominion and Satan's power. This liberation, Henry argues, is not merely physical release but profound spiritual transformation: the "garments of salvation" and "robe of righteousness" symbolize Christ's imputed righteousness covering believers, enabling them to become "kings and priests" who live in joyful service to God. Crucially, Henry stresses that these blessings are exclusively for the humble and brokenhearted, rejecting the self-sufficient who remain "bound" by sin and ignorance. Practical applications demand believers actively embrace Christ's liberation, cultivating meekness and humility to receive God's grace, while living as salt and light in the world—using their newfound freedom to build up others and proclaim righteousness. Henry warns that true blessing arises only through Christ's work, not human effort, urging Christians to reject spiritual poverty and actively participate in God's kingdom by restoring broken relationships and embodying the "trees of righteousness" described. Ultimately, the chapter's promise—of eternal joy, doubled blessings, and global impact—finds its complete realization in Christ's ongoing work to establish righteousness and praise among all nations through the faithful. (248 words)

Calvin meticulously interprets Isaiah 61 as Christ's self-fulfilling prophecy, emphasizing that Jesus explicitly claims this passage as his own mission (Luke 4:18). He argues that while Isaiah's vision originally pointed to future restoration, Christ's fulfillment transforms it into a definitive declaration of his person and work. Theologically, Calvin stresses that the "anointing" signifies divine empowerment—not merely a title but the Spirit-bestowed authority enabling prophetic ministry and service to God's people. This contrasts sharply with human claims to spiritual authority; true ministry must demonstrate Christ-like humility and obedience, not self-proclaimed power. Practical applications arise from Calvin's warning against false teachers who boast of the Spirit without evidence of Christ-centered transformation—like historical movements Calvin critiques. Believers must actively seek the Spirit's anointing for their own service, focusing on liberation for the oppressed and restoration of broken relationships, as Christ modeled. Crucially, Calvin shows how Christ's fulfillment in Isaiah 61 reveals that God's justice and mercy converge in his work: binding the brokenhearted, proclaiming liberty, and establishing eternal covenant with the righteous. This passage, thus, anchors modern discipleship in Christ's active role as the "anointed" one who restores, comforts, and brings righteousness to all nations through his sacrificial love and the indwelling Spirit. The practical takeaway is clear: our ministry must flow from Christ's anointing, not human ambition, to truly liberate and glorify God. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Isaiah 61 centers on Christ's fulfillment of this prophecy as the foundational declaration of Jesus' mission. He meticulously argues that the phrase "the Spirit of the Lord is upon me" signifies Christ's anointing by the Holy Spirit—both the divine indwelling and the prophetic authority—confirmed by the Spirit's visible descent at Jesus' baptism. Crucially, Poole emphasizes that Isaiah 61:1-3 describes Christ's unique triple office: prophet (bringing gospel to the meek), priest (binding the brokenhearted through healing), and king (proclaiming liberty to captives and opening prisons). The "meek" here specifically denotes the "poor in spirit"—those burdened by sin and guilt, not merely the socially disadvantaged. Poole highlights how Christ applies this text to himself immediately after baptism (Luke 4:18), revealing its universal scope: the "acceptable year" signifies God's gracious initiative through Jesus, while the "day of vengeance" points to Christ's ultimate judgment against spiritual enemies. The transformative imagery—"beauty for ashes," "oil of joy for mourning"—depicts how Christ replaces spiritual desolation with divine restoration, turning mourners into "trees of righteousness." Theologically, this passage underscores Christ's active role in redeeming humanity from sin's bondage. Practically, it calls believers to embrace their spiritual liberation, actively participate in God's work of healing and freedom, and cultivate joyful perseverance in service—recognizing that Christ's anointing continues to empower the church to proclaim liberation to those bound by sin or despair. This Christ-centered interpretation remains vital for understanding the gospel's depth and application. (249 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 61 reveals this chapter as a foundational Messianic prophecy, intricately designed to declare the Savior's purpose and effects. Barnes emphasizes that the phrase "the Spirit of the Lord God is upon me" directly refers to Christ's anointing at baptism (Matthew 3:16), signifying His divine consecration for ministry. The "meek" here denotes the oppressed and brokenhearted—those suffering captivity or spiritual bondage—highlighting Jesus' specific mission to liberate the afflicted. Crucially, Barnes connects the "proclamation of liberty" to the Jubilee concept, indicating Christ's work liberates from sin's slavery, not merely physical chains, with profound implications for social justice. Theologically, this passage shows Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of Old Testament promises, where the Messiah's coming brings restoration (v4-5), divine favor (v6-9), and universal joy (v10-11). Practically, it calls believers to actively proclaim freedom to the broken, heal emotional wounds through compassionate service, and embody liberation by rejecting systems of oppression. Modern application demands recognizing that Christ's promise of liberation extends beyond individual salvation to societal transformation—urging Christians to be instruments of justice, healing, and hope in a world still shackled by injustice and despair, reflecting the gospel's transformative power in both spiritual and communal contexts. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 62 reveals God's profound covenant love for His people, particularly Jerusalem, as a divine promise of restoration and identity. He emphasizes that God's delight in His church—calling it "Hephzibah" (married) and "Beulah" (a holy ground)—signifies the end of abandonment and the beginning of a new, eternal relationship where God actively seeks His people. This transforms the church from a "desolate" state to a "crown of glory" (v. 3), reflecting Christ's role as the bridegroom who joyfully reunites His bride (v. 5). Theologically, Henry connects this to Christ's fulfillment: the "new name" (v. 4) points to the Church as the redeemed community, while the promise of God's provision (v. 8–9) anticipates Christ's kingdom where His people share in the blessing of the Lord's table. Practically, Henry stresses that believers must become "watchmen" (v. 6–7)—persistent in prayer and joyful proclamation—since God's presence is the foundation for true peace. This active hope, rooted in Christ's promise of redemption, calls believers to live holy lives that bring honor to God, ensuring their identity as "the sought-out city, not forsaken" (v. 12). The commentary thus affirms that Christ's coming fulfills Isaiah's vision: through His work, God's people experience divine delight, security, and a restored relationship, urging believers to live in prayerful expectancy of His kingdom. (248 words)

Calvin argues that God will not cease speaking for Zion or Jerusalem until the Church's restored righteousness shines like light and salvation burns as a lasting lamp, emphasizing divine commitment amidst persecution. He interprets this promise as a response to the impending Babylonian captivity, where the people's sin had concealed their righteousness before God. Theological insight reveals that this "righteousness" is not human achievement but the Church's restoration through Christ's work—where God's grace actively regenerates and protects His people from destruction. The imagery of Jerusalem being "married" (Hephzibah) and "a city not forsaken" underscores Christ as the ultimate bridegroom, fulfilling the covenant through redemption rather than human effort. Practical application demands that believers maintain unwavering hope despite trials, actively proclaiming Christ's coming salvation like watchmen on Jerusalem's walls, and embracing the community of the "holy people" who share in this redemption. Calvin stresses that this promise transforms the church's identity from a forsaken people to a beloved community, rooted in Christ's atoning work and eternal faithfulness. For modern readers, this calls for persistent witness in a world of division, trusting that Christ's victory over sin and death ensures the church's restoration and purpose—where righteousness and salvation, now manifested in Christ, become the lamp guiding the community toward God's kingdom. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 62 emphasizes God's active, unyielding care for the church, framing its future glory through Christ-centered promises. Poole interprets the "righteousness" and "salvation" described as the church's divine identity—Christ Himself, who is "her righteousness," manifesting through the gospel to transform the church from desolation to luminous brightness. Theologically, Poole connects the "new name" (Hephzibah, "my delight"; Beulah, "married") to God's redefinition of the church's identity: no longer "forsaken" or "desolate," but redeemed and intimately united to God, reflecting the covenantal marriage between Christ and His bride. This identity shift, Poole argues, fulfills the prophecy by replacing the old Israel with the new community of believers, called "Christians" through God's sovereign naming. Practically, Poole urges believers to function as vigilant "watchmen" (spiritual shepherds and prophets) who never cease proclaiming God's promises of restoration, especially in times of hardship. This active witness, he stresses, is vital for the church to experience the "joy" of Christ's presence and the "renewal" of its fellowship with God. Crucially, Poole ties the bridegroom imagery (Isaiah 62:5) directly to Christ—God's joy over His church as the bridegroom rejoices over his bride—showing that the church's ultimate purpose is to be a "crown of glory" in Christ's hand, celebrated by all nations. This commentary thus anchors modern believers in Christ's promise of divine restoration, urging faithful, prophetic engagement that anticipates the church's full glorification through Christ's return. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that Isaiah 62 offers profound consolatory hope for God's people, particularly the exiles in Babylon, while simultaneously pointing decisively toward the Messianic age. The chapter's core message revolves around God's unceasing commitment to restore Zion's glory and secure her ultimate vindication. The speaker's declaration—"I will not hold my peace... until the righteousness thereof go forth as brightness"—reveals God's active intervention, where divine justice and salvation will radiate globally, transforming Zion from desolation into a radiant beacon. Barnes notes the chapter's dual focus: the immediate assurance of God's protective care (v. 8–9) and the urgent call to prepare for Christ's coming (v. 10–12), where the "crier" heralds the Lord's arrival. Theologically, this passage illuminates God's covenant faithfulness, wherein His people become the "crown of glory" (v. 3) and "royal diadem" (v. 3) through Christ's redemptive work—a metaphor signifying His unique, exalted authority and the Church's destined role as the world's light. Practically, believers are urged to maintain persistent, prayerful vigilance (like the watchmen in v. 6–7) and actively cultivate readiness for Christ's return, embracing their new identity in Him. Christologically, the "righteousness" and "salvation" that "go forth" (v. 1) and the "new name" (v. 2) directly point to Jesus as the fulfillment of prophecy—His righteousness illuminating the world and His name bestowed by the Father, establishing a new covenant community. This chapter thus challenges Christians to anchor their hope in God's sovereign promise while actively participating in His kingdom work through faithful devotion and communal preparation.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 63 presents a vivid vision of Christ's triumphant return after conquering His enemies, with Edom symbolizing opposition to the Messiah. Theologically, Henry emphasizes Christ's self-sufficiency in victory—He "treads the winepress alone" (v. 3), crushing adversaries without human aid, a stark contrast to His earthly weakness where He "poured out His blood" for atonement. This passage reveals the "day of vengeance" (v. 4) as both a fixed divine judgment and an imminent call to repentance, while the bloodstained garments signify the cost of redemption. Henry connects this to Christ's second coming in "the greatness of His strength," where He will fully execute divine justice and restore His people. Practically, the commentary urges urgent response: sinners must seek reconciliation with God before His "year of the redeemed" arrives, as the text warns that divine wrath "approaches apace." The Jewish lamentations in verses 8–19—acknowledging God's past mercy but lamenting rejection—serve as a universal reminder that human rebellion provokes divine withdrawal, yet Christ remains the eternal "Saviour" who redeems through His mercy. Henry stresses that true hope lies not in avoiding spiritual judgment but in turning from rebellion to Christ, whose "fury" (v. 6) ultimately brings restoration. This vision compels believers to live with awareness of Christ's imminent return, actively pursuing reconciliation with God while avoiding sins that harden hearts and invite divine separation. The practical takeaway is clear: respond to Christ's "I come quickly" with repentance and faith, for the "year of the redeemed" depends on timely obedience. (248 words)

Calvin meticulously clarifies that Isaiah 63:1-19 describes God Himself as the avenging and redeeming Lord, not Christ in a metaphorical sense. He directly addresses the common misinterpretation that the "red garments" symbolize Christ's blood, emphasizing instead that the Prophet portrays God the Father returning from vengeance against Edom—those who persecuted the Jews—drenched in their blood. This vivid imagery serves to awaken the Israelites from spiritual complacency, demonstrating God's active justice against enemies who had spurned His people. Theologically, Calvin highlights God's dual nature here: both the impassioned avenger who "treads the winepress alone" (v. 3) and the sovereign redeemer who "bears" His people (v. 9). This chapter reveals God's covenant faithfulness in the midst of suffering, where His wrath is purposeful purification and His mercy is enduring redemption. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject the temptation of spiritual apathy—like the Edomites' arrogance—by trusting God's ultimate sovereignty in their trials. Christians should recognize that God's "anger" (v. 3) is not capricious but a necessary response to sin, while His "redemption" (v. 4) remains secure through Christ's work. This passage challenges believers to live with both humility before God's justice and hope in His mercy, understanding that their true identity is "thine" (v. 19), sustained by a God who redeems through suffering and victory.

Matthew Poole interprets Isaiah 63:1-6 as a divine revelation where Christ identifies Himself as the triumphant conqueror, described by the prophet in ecstasy as "glorious in his apparel" with "dyed garments" from Edom (a synecdochical symbol for all God's enemies, particularly the ancient, inbred hostility of Esau's lineage). Poole emphasizes that this imagery—red garments, winepress treading, blood-stained robes—depicts Christ's sovereign victory over enemies *alone*, without assistance, fulfilling His role as a kingly warrior who crushes opposition with decisive power. Theologically, this passage reveals Christ's preeminence: He is "the one who speaks in righteousness" and "is mighty to save," distinct from false gods, asserting His absolute authority and faithfulness to save His people. Poole clarifies that the blood mentioned belongs to enemies, not Christ Himself, distinguishing this scene from the passion narrative and highlighting Christ's victory over spiritual forces through His own strength. Practically, this commentary urges believers to view current trials through the lens of Christ's completed victory—knowing that God's wrath against opposition is already executed, and His mercy toward His church remains active. It reassures Christians that their suffering is part of a larger narrative where Christ, having "trod the winepress alone," secures ultimate redemption and purification, encouraging trust in His sovereignty rather than fear of opposition. This perspective transforms present struggles into evidence of Christ's ongoing work, fostering resilience and hope in the believer's journey. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 63 emphasizes that the vision of a blood-stained warrior returning from Edom (Bozrah) depicts Yahweh's sovereign triumph over Israel's enemies, not Christ's suffering. Barnes meticulously rejects interpretations linking this passage directly to Christ as stained with his own blood, arguing the warrior's blood represents vanquished foes—consistent with the context of Edom's historical oppression of Israel and the passage's focus on divine victory. Theologically, this underscores Yahweh's active role as a conquering deliverer who acts alone to secure his people's freedom, contrasting with later New Testament understandings of Christ's redemptive death. Barnes stresses that while the passage shares thematic echoes with Christ's ultimate victory (e.g., Revelation 19), its imagery depicts a triumphant, unharmed Messiah—distinct from the suffering servant—highlighting God's unilateral power in executing justice. Practically, this encourages believers to trust Yahweh's decisive intervention against current oppositions, recognizing that God's deliverance arises from his sovereign authority, not human efforts. It calls for confidence in his past victories and active hope in his future judgments against adversaries, fostering community resilience without conflating this vision with Christ's atoning death. Barnes concludes that the passage functions as a responsive song affirming God's relentless protection, urging faithful reliance on his character as the ultimate defender of his people. (249 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 64 reveals a profound meditation on human sinfulness and God's gracious response. He emphasizes how the chapter opens with a desperate plea for God's visible presence—a cry that resonates with Christ's second coming, where God will ultimately descend to fulfill His people's destiny. Henry underscores that human righteousness is utterly inadequate, describing believers as "unclean" and their good works as "filthy rags," highlighting sin's destructive power that "withers and ruins" the soul. This state of spiritual uncleanness, Henry argues, necessitates Christ as the only true purification, where His atoning sacrifice resolves the "filthy rags" problem and reconciles the sinner to God. Theologically, Henry connects this lament to God's wrath against sin but also His patient mercy, stressing that true salvation depends not on human effort but on Christ's work. Practically, the commentary urges earnest repentance, honest confession of sin, and persistent prayer—specifically calling for believers to "stir themselves to take hold of" God in faith, rather than relying on self-deception. Henry's insight is that Christ's return and redemption are the ultimate answer to this chapter's cry: God's people must trust in Him, not their own efforts, understanding that their salvation is secured through Christ's finished work, not their fleeting righteousness. This bridges the lament of Isaiah 64 to the hope of Christ's return, where God's wrath is replaced by mercy and His presence becomes the true dwelling place of His redeemed. (249 words)

John Calvin interprets Isaiah 64:1-12 as a profound prayer of desperate faith revealing human sinfulness and God's sovereign grace. The chapter opens with a plea for God to "rend the heavens" and descend, a vivid cry for divine intervention that Calvin connects to the Exodus and Sinai—their past encounters with God's power where fire and thunder revealed His majesty. He emphasizes that the "melting fire" imagery signifies Christ's atoning work: just as divine fire consumed the unclean, God's sacrifice purifies sinners, transforming them from "filthy rags" into living vessels of holiness. Calvin stresses that the people's failure—being "unclean," "like a leaf," and "consumed by iniquity"—points not to divine abandonment but to their complete dependence on Christ. Theologically, this underscores God's eternal sovereignty: He is "our father" and "the potter," yet He remains accessible through Christ's work, not human effort. Practically, believers today face the same crisis of sin and spiritual desolation; Calvin urges confession of sin, trust in Christ's finished work, and active participation in the community of grace. The "holy cities" described as wildernesses reflect how sin's consequences—broken relationships, spiritual desolation—contrast with Christ's resurrection power that renews the community. Crucially, Calvin ties this to the cross: Christ's descent to earth (as the "melting fire") enables salvation where human righteousness fails, showing that true restoration comes only through Christ's atoning sacrifice and the believer's surrender to His sovereign grace. This commentary challenges believers to embrace humility and active faith in Christ, not self-reliance, recognizing that God's glory is revealed through His redemptive acts. (280 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 64 reveals the Jewish people's desperate prayer for divine intervention, interpreting verses 1-5 as both a lament for their spiritual condition and a prophetic anticipation of the Messiah. Poole emphasizes that the cry to "rend the heavens" and "melt the mountains" symbolizes the intense desire for God's powerful manifestation—historically recalling events like Mount Sinai or the Exodus plagues—where God's fiery, transformative action would both dismantle obstacles and reveal His sovereign glory to enemies. The passage's theological core lies in this stark contrast: the people confess their utter spiritual corruption ("we are all as an unclean thing") and the futility of their efforts ("our righteousnesses are as filthy rags"), underscoring total depravity and alienation from God. Crucially, Poole connects this lament to Christ, highlighting how Isaiah's vision of God's coming down in judgment and mercy foreshadows Jesus' descent to earth, His sacrificial atonement that "melts" sin, and His role as the only means of reconciliation. Practically, this commentary urges believers to embrace profound humility before God's holiness, recognizing their sinfulness as the "filthy rags" metaphor implies, while clinging to Christ—the one who "comes down" to save and "melt" the mountains of sin through His death and resurrection. It calls for active trust in Christ's finished work, where repentance and faith in His righteousness replace futile human efforts, offering hope not in self-righteousness but in the one who bears the weight of sin and transforms the heart. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 64 reveals a profound lament following national devastation, where the people urgently plead for God to "rend the heavens" and cause mountains to "flow down" at His presence—a vivid plea for divine intervention after the temple's destruction and exile. Barnes interprets "rend" (qāra) as a violent tearing, contrasting with gentler imagery in other translations, emphasizing God's imminent, wrathful descent to execute judgment against enemies. This imagery draws from biblical patterns of God's majestic power (Psalm 18:9, Habakkuk 3:5-6), where His presence melts obstacles like mountains under intense heat. Theologically, Barnes underscores that this chapter highlights God's dual nature: His just wrath against sin and His ultimate mercy in restoration. Crucially, the passage's Christ connection becomes central—Jesus, the one who "rended" heaven (John 3:13) and "flowed down" as flesh (John 1:14), fulfills the prophecy by taking the divine wrath upon Himself through the cross. Practically, believers must grasp that God's justice precedes grace; true restoration requires acknowledging sin's destructive power (the "mountains") and trusting Christ's sacrificial work to "boil" the waters of sin. This chapter teaches that God's glory is revealed not in passive blessings but in His active, fiery intervention against evil—now completed in Christ, who makes all obstacles dissolve for the redeemed.

Henry observes that Isaiah 65 reveals God's active pursuit of the lost while condemning the unrepentant Jews who rejected Him. The chapter contrasts the righteous and wicked: the ungodly "sacrificed in gardens" and "eat swine's flesh" (v. 4), declaring themselves holier than God, while God's servants experience divine favor (v. 8–10). Theologically, this underscores God's sovereignty in choosing the unchosen (v. 1) and His covenant faithfulness despite human rebellion. Christ is the fulfillment of this promise—the "new wine" in the cluster of Israel (v. 8) becomes the living Christ who reconciles sinners, while the "new heavens and earth" (v. 17) point to eternal restoration. Practically, this warns against self-righteousness and spiritual complacency, urging believers to abandon idols and embrace God's grace, as the ungodly "leave their name for a curse" (v. 15). The promise of a future where "the wolf and the lamb shall feed together" (v. 25) challenges us to live in harmony, reflecting Christ's reconciling work. For the Christian, this chapter affirms that God's grace transforms the broken (v. 19–20), ensures eternal security (v. 18), and calls us to joy in His promises rather than worldly anxieties. It compels active obedience: as "workers with God," we find true blessing in Him alone, not in fleeting possessions or self-declared righteousness, knowing His presence brings healing and eternal renewal. This divine promise remains a living hope for the faithful. (278 words)

Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 65 reveals God's profound sovereignty in His active pursuit of the unseeking and the covenantal hope for a renewed creation. He emphasizes that God is "sought by those who did not ask" and "found by those who did not seek" (v.1), highlighting His initiative in grace that transcends human effort. Calvin contrasts this with the rebellious Jewish people who persist in idolatry and self-righteousness (v.3-5), their actions becoming "a smoke in my nose" (v.5) due to their persistent rejection of God's holiness. Theologically, Calvin stresses that God's judgment is not arbitrary but rooted in the covenant's fidelity: the ungodly face destruction ("numbered to the sword," v.12), while His servants experience abundant provision and joy (v.13-14). Crucially, Calvin connects this passage to Christ as the fulfillment of the "seed of Jacob" (v.9), the one who establishes the new covenant where "the wolf and lamb feed together" (v.25). This vision points to Christ's redemptive work—where His people, redeemed by grace, experience true restoration and the elimination of sin's destruction. Practically, Calvin urges believers to reject self-sufficiency and idolatry, embracing God's active presence ("before they call, I will answer," v.24). This fosters humility and trust in God's promises, preventing the fate of the unrepentent. For modern readers, it means living in the reality that God's grace reaches the lost, and Christ's return will bring the "new heavens and new earth" where suffering ends—calling believers to participate in this hope through faithful, Christ-centered living. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 65 reveals a profound theological shift centered on God's proactive grace toward the Gentiles after Jewish rejection. Poole emphasizes that the prophecy describes how God is "sought of them that asked not for me" and "found of them that sought me not," highlighting divine initiative where Gentiles—previously "without God in the world" (Ephesians 2:12)—are discovered through grace before they actively seek Him. This contrasts sharply with the Jewish people's "rebellious" refusal to align with God's will, their idolatrous practices (sacrificing in gardens, burning incense on brick altars), and self-imposed holiness that led to divine wrath. Crucially, Poole connects this text to Christ's fulfillment: the "nation not called by my name" refers to Gentiles converted through Christ's crucifixion, the ultimate rejection of Jewish expectations. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereignty in salvation—grace precedes human effort, and true righteousness flows from Christ's atonement, not self-righteousness. Practically, this calls believers to humility in evangelism, recognizing that God finds those who have not sought Him, and to avoid judging others' spiritual journeys. It challenges churches to embrace the Gentile inclusion promised here, understanding that Christ's death reconciled all nations to God, transforming the "rebellious" into a community of grace where the new Jerusalem's peace (Isaiah 65:17-25) becomes a reality through Christ's redemption, not human effort.

Albert Barnes's commentary on Isaiah 65 reveals a profound theological framework addressing Israel's exile while pointing forward to Christ. He emphasizes that this chapter responds to Jewish complaints by clarifying God's purpose: salvation extends beyond Israel to those who never sought Him (v1), challenging the notion that covenant membership guarantees salvation—highlighting a universal gospel principle where Gentiles become God's chosen people (Romans 10:20). The chapter details Israel's rejection due to persistent rebellion, idolatry, and self-righteousness (v2-7), stressing that punishment stems from righteous justice, not caprice. Yet Barnes underscores God's faithfulness to preserve a remnant (v8-10) who will ultimately flourish under Christ, while the unrepentant face destruction (v11-16) that serves as a necessary contrast to divine grace. Most significantly, the concluding vision (v17-25) depicts the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise—a new creation where Jerusalem thrives in peace, and the natural order is transformed under Christ's reign, with the "wolf and lamb" imagery symbolizing the New Covenant's reconciliation. Theologically, this reveals God's sovereign grace in rejecting a people who refuse Him while extending salvation to the lost; practically, it encourages believers to trust God's purpose despite current trials, actively share the gospel with those who have not sought Him, and live righteously knowing that Christ's return will establish true peace. Barnes's commentary thus powerfully connects the chapter's dual themes—judgment and redemption—to Christ as the fulfillment of God's promise to a world reconciled through Him.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Isaiah 66 presents a profound contrast between human religious efforts and God's true requirement for worship. He emphasizes that God's heavenly throne and earth are His own, rendering all human temples—however grand—useless before Him; satisfaction comes only from a heart truly contrite and poor in spirit, who trembles at God's word. The chapter sharply critiques hypocritical religious rituals, noting that offering sacrifices according to the law or burning incense amounts to rejecting Christ's atoning work, as these acts become idolatrous in God's eyes. Theologically, Henry underscores that God's ultimate acceptance rests not on human performance but on genuine repentance and a surrendered heart, positioning the true "temple" as the transformed inner life. Practically, this calls believers to examine their worship motives: are they focused on divine holiness or human ritual? Christ is the central fulfillment here—His sacrifice replaces all animal offerings, and His presence becomes the true sanctuary. Henry connects the chapter's promise of restoration to Jerusalem with Christ's future reign, where the redeemed will experience divine comfort and joy. The passage assures that God will judge the wicked severely but also bring overwhelming blessing to the humble, who find their true sustenance in Christ's promises. This leads to practical application: Christians should seek daily renewal in Christ, trusting His finished work rather than human traditions, and find their deepest joy in Him alone—a joy that sustains through trials and points to eternal hope in the new creation. (248 words)

Calvin's commentary on Isaiah 66 emphasizes God's transcendent sovereignty and the profound need for genuine humility before Him. He interprets the opening declaration—where heaven is God's throne and earth His footstool—revealing that human efforts to build a permanent dwelling for God are futile, as true worship must originate from the heart, not ritual. Calvin stresses that God will "look" not at the religiously observant but at the "poor and contrite spirit" who trembles at His word (v.2), highlighting that true righteousness emerges from humility and repentance, not external obedience. The passage critiques empty ritual (v.3-4), where sacrifices become abominations when motivated by self-interest, pointing to Christ as the only acceptable offering—the humble Son who became the true temple (v.1). Calvin connects this to Christ's incarnation: the sudden birth of God's people (v.7-8) foreshadows Christ's arrival, where God's judgment and mercy converge in the one who brings salvation. Practically, this calls believers to examine their hearts, abandon self-centered worship, and seek Christ's humility. The promise of Jerusalem's restoration (v.10-14) and the "new heavens and earth" (v.22) reveal Christ's ultimate kingdom, where all nations will worship Him. For modern readers, Calvin's insight underscores that authentic faith transforms ritual into relationship, and Christ's coming brings not just judgment but restoration—inviting believers to find their true "rest" in Him, whose blood cleanses and whose kingdom brings eternal peace. This vision challenges us to live in Christ's humility while anticipating His return with fire and judgment, yet also with the "abundance of glory" that sustains the faithful. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Isaiah 66 underscores God's profound transcendence and the futility of ritual worship without genuine heart transformation.
